name: Helga Stevens
text: Rapporteur. – To this day, the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the only international convention on human rights that has been ratified by the European Union as a whole. In addition, it is important to note that all EU Member States have signed the Treaty and that 27 Member States have ratified it. So there is a very strong political support for this treaty politically. The treaty is considered the first human rights treaty of this century, the 21st century. The treaty is legally binding and the European Union must now take action to fully implement it. All legislation, both in the future and in the past, must be fully in line with the UN Convention and ensure full and equal participation of persons with disabilities in society, including at European level. The UN Convention does not give new or additional rights to persons with disabilities, but explicitly clarifies that persons with disabilities can also claim fundamental rights that have already been written down in other treaties, such as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the Convention on the Rights of the Child and other international treaties. I am really proud to have been able to involve a record number of committees in my report, from the Committee on Transport and Tourism, Legal Affairs and Development To the Committee on Petitions. This proves that disability is not just a social issue, but a theme that permeates all aspects of life. Remember that this UN convention is a human rights treaty. We are therefore talking here about the human rights of people with disabilities. In the spirit of the treaty and of the slogan of the movement of people with disabilities, namely "Nothing about us without us", I wrote my report together with organizations of and for people with disabilities. From the outset, I have been able to consult constructively with the European Disability Forum and its members. I would therefore like to thank the organisations and individuals who have supported me very much. Representatives of those organisations sit above in the public gallery. I would very much like to give them a round of applause, because they tirelessly continue to claim their rights as persons with disabilities in our society [applause], a society that does not always take them into account and which does not always understand the obstacles faced by people with disabilities every day. I would like to reiterate and stress that people with disabilities should not be treated as second-class citizens in Europe. They must enjoy the same rights to live and work in the EU, just as citizens without disabilities. The European institutions must lead by example. Employees with disabilities should be supported so that they have equal access to work and occupation. Citizens with disabilities should also have equal access to public information and events in the European Parliament and other institutions. We cannot ask the Member States to apply the treaty if we do not do it ourselves. I look forward to working with my colleagues here and in other institutions to ensure that the rights of people with disabilities are respected and taken seriously throughout Europe.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: drafts member of the Committee on Petitions. – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mrs Helga Stevens for having produced this report. It is the first Treaty of International Law, on Human Rights, which is signed by the European Union and ratified as a whole and is therefore part of the EU's own legal order. In August last year, the United Nations prepared concluding observations on the fulfilment by Member States and the Union itself of all the parameters of this Convention. This Convention is not the end, it is the principle of consolidating the principle of equality of all the rights of persons with disabilities. Many comments were made in them, basically around the European Union's need to harmonize all its legislation in order to get in line with the Convention. Comments were also made on accessibility, access to justice and, ultimately, a principle of equality and diversity that enriches us all. The European Union has to be a leader in these issues and that is why I repeatedly call for the unblocking of the Non-Discrimination Directive, which needs to be adopted and which has been blocked for many years in the Council. The Accessibility Directive, as regards the labour market, with reasonable adjustments, as well as education, is also concerned. And I end up calling for respect for difference and acceptance of people with disabilities as part of diversity and the human condition.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Stevens, for her report on the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The UN Convention has set the gold standard for the full and equal participation of people with disabilities in society. Its implementation on the ground requires a joint effort by all the European Union institutions and Member States, and also the involvement of people with disabilities. We have achieved good results so far but, as we all know, much remains to be done. That is also why I welcome your comprehensive and valuable recommendations. While I cannot be exhaustive here, I would like to address some of the key issues raised in your report. Significant inequalities persist regarding the participation and opportunities of people with disabilities in our society and our economy. Your report refers, notably, to access to employment, education and social protection. Indeed, across the Union, the employment rate for people with a disability is around 48%. Only 27.8% have completed third-level education and one-third are at risk of poverty or social exclusion. This Commission is committed to job creation and employment opportunities for all people. We are working to ensure that European legislation prohibiting discrimination on the grounds of disability in employment is fully implemented. That includes the obligation for employers – public or private – to make the necessary adaptations enabling all to work on an equal basis. Our efforts are backed up by our financial instruments, in particular the European Social Fund, which is worth EUR 86 billion. Thanks to the European Parliament, Member States must reserve at least 20% for social inclusion. Many impressive projects show how people with disabilities can be supported to find work and enabled fully to enjoy their rights in society. European funds can – and should – be used for supporting conditions for independent living. In order for Member States to access these funds, we have introduced as a pre-condition that they demonstrate their administrative capacity to implement and apply the UN Convention. In addition, only actions which help to establish the conditions for independent living should be supported. Empowering people with disabilities means that they should not live in institutions. So far, EUR 3.1 billion has been allocated by Member States to social infrastructure. This should contribute to our goal of transition from institutional care to community-based services. Our 2010-2020 European Disability Strategy aims for a barrier-free Europe. Free movement is a basic right in the EU and persons with disabilities should not be excluded from it – either in their local living environment or when traveling abroad. That is why the Commission is currently implementing, with eight Member States, a pilot project on the European Disability Card. The card will allow people with disabilities to access certain benefits in the areas of culture, leisure, transport and sport on the same conditions as nationals of the countries concerned with disabilities. The Commission has made over EUR 1.5 million available in support. To break down barriers in the daily lives of people with disabilities I have put forward – and presented here in plenary in December 2015 – a legislative proposal for a European Accessibility Act. I am happy to report that there has been good progress in the Council under the Dutch Council Presidency and I am counting on the Slovak Presidency to keep up the pace. I am confident that you will also contribute to reaching an agreement on this important proposal in due time. The European Accessibility Act aims to improve the functioning of the internal market by harmonising accessibility requirements in the European Union, but it will also serve as a catalyst for social inclusion, by giving people with disabilities access to everyday products and services. To be crystal clear, this is about putting the internal market at the service of people. The concluding observations of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities provide the EU with important guidance. They highlight the positive aspects as well as gaps and difficulties in terms of implementation. The Commission is committed to following up on the recommendations. We are currently preparing a progress report on the implementation of our 2010-2020 European Disability Strategy. It will be published before the end of this year. Your report provides practical and useful input. We are also analysing the numerous contributions received during the public consultation on the strategy, which was carried out earlier this year. I would also like to highlight the fact that the outline for a European Pillar of Social Rights, which I proposed in March of this year, includes a principle, No 16, on disability. I am therefore glad to use this opportunity to invite you all to contribute to the ongoing consultation. As to the recommendations specifically underlined by the UN Committee, the Commission also announced its intention to withdraw from the European Monitoring Framework and has stopped participating in the meetings of the Framework. We are currently in the process of legally formalising this action and we are also advancing in preparing a list of legal acts, which will complement the EU Declaration of Competences attached to the Council decision for concluding the Convention. Reading your report confirmed my conviction that we share a joint commitment and we should work together towards achieving these goals. I agree that the EU itself should make sure that we set an example by being a disability-inclusive organisation in line with the Convention. We need to look at our own institutions and pay attention to our own employees with disabilities by providing the support and protection that they and their families need, and by ensuring the accessibility of our own venues. We need to act on our commitments in consultation with, and with the participation of, organisations representing persons with disabilities. As was highlighted in your report, we continue to provide financial support for organisations representing a variety of disabilities at European level, and to work on a daily basis with them. They contribute significantly to the proper implementation and monitoring of the Convention at European and national levels. In the end, we all share the objective of a Europe where all people can fully enjoy their human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Martina Anderson
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Mr President, the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is exactly the sort of thing that the EU institutions should be working on. I want to commend the rapporteur and the other MEPs who were working on this file, and I look forward to working with them in the future. I am happy that the institutions of the EU have acknowledged their shortcomings in relation to persons with disabilities. However, I am unhappy at the fact that the much-talked-about replacement to David Cameron, Theresa May, has wedded herself to repealing the Human Rights Act – the Act which gives us access to the European Convention on Human Rights. That will damage those who are trying to get access to those rights for people with a disability. I want to say that I and my party, Sinn Féin, as a delegation here in the GUE/NGL Group, will challenge that if it is the outcome of the contest that is taking place at the moment, because we cannot have a situation where persons with a disability are denied access to the European Convention on Human Rights. In relation to the implementation of this report, I commend the work of all who have been involved in it.

name: Richard Howitt
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, firstly this is a human rights convention and it is right that the European Union’s human rights mechanisms are used to support its implementation. So it is now in the Action Plan on democracy and human rights and I welcome that, but I would like to see the Special Representative on Human Rights, human rights dialogues with third countries and country strategy papers on human rights, really champion the Convention and champion the rights of people with disabilities in terms of Europe’s influence worldwide.  Secondly, I say to our friend Ms Thyssen – and I think we will be working even more closely in the next period – do not just do what you would have done anyway in the Disability Strategy. You and your colleagues do some good things and we support you in doing it, but the Convention is a different legal obligation for us in the European Union and we have to show that we are acting differently because of that legal obligation, and not simply redress what we would have done anyway, and pretend it is to do with the Convention. We have to do better than that.  Finally, I was involved in the lobbying for the Convention. I am deeply proud of that and people with disabilities were there, and their organisations, it was fantastic, but when the review came out, the Commission did not undertake a formal consultation with people with disabilities and their organisations – they did informally but not formally. I want to ask you, when it comes to the next review conference, every time you send a delegation to the UN to discuss the Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities, to involve disabled people, involve disabled people’s organisations – nothing about us without us. I know you say those words. When you do it, make sure you do it, and on this occasion, I am sorry but you did not.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President, it is crucial to fulfil the rights of persons with disabilities in the European Union’s development and humanitarian action. We must ensure that the implementation plan of Agenda 2030, the Paris climate agreement and the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction is being carried out in line with the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. We also have to take into account the pledge to leave no one behind, which is in the remit of Agenda 2030. Disabled people suffer disproportionately during crisis situations. This is especially true for disabled women and girls. Their empowerment to become actors in humanitarian crisis situations is a step towards ensuring that their needs are also addressed. I would like to highlight the importance of giving support to the organisation and participation of persons with disabilities in the process of drafting legislation in partner countries. This would be an efficient way of ensuring respect for their rights, and civil society is particularly important in this respect.  Finally, the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is central in working towards ‘Nothing About Us Without Us’ and this must equally be fulfilled in EU external action. This report and the rapporteur, Helga Stevens, are an important embodiment of that principle.

name: Davor Škrlec
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Transport and Tourism Committee. – Dear President, respected colleagues, I would first like to thank My Colleague Stevens for her very open and fruitful cooperation and acceptance of a large number of TRAN Committee opinions and I take the opportunity to thank both my colleagues and fellow shadow rapporteurs of the TRAN Committee for their excellent report on the fact that its bulk was actually accepted in Parliament's final report.  Freedom of movement for European citizens is a fundamental right that is actually denied to almost 80 million of our citizens and they cannot be equally involved in our society and culture, but also tourism, which is also an important economic branch of the European Union. In our report, we highlighted several facts on which the Commission, the Council, parliament and in fact the whole of European society should work together.  Thus, one intermodality of transport that enables, in addition to new technologies, the development of new jobs, the development of new services and jobs not only for citizens of the European Union who are employed today, but also for people with disabilities who can thus participate equally as members of society. The European Disability Card is a project for all Member States to accept.  And that is why I urge the Commission and the Council to incorporate precisely these values into any future amendments to directives and regulations to encourage Member States that today still have too large barriers in public transport, in tourism, in inaccessible to all those cultural and artistic facilities where people with disabilities and persons with reduced mobility should participate as should all other citizens of the European Union.

name: Silvia Costa
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture, Youth, the Media and Sport. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is very important that we adopt this report today on monitoring the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in the European Union, which, I would remind you, is binding and is an integral part of the Union's legal order. It provides not only, in Article 3, for the prohibition of all forms of discrimination but, in Article 21, the right to education, inclusive training, cultural and civic life, sport and creative activities. And it is not acceptable that, even today, in many education systems in some Member States, the realities of school and training segregation, the rejection of students with disabilities and also the lack of family support services, guidance and educational support persist, which, I would remind you, must be personalised and implemented throughout life.  In this regard, I would like to point out – and I am very pleased about this – that next year in Italy we will be celebrating the 40th anniversary of the law that has included handicapped children in all schools of all levels. Of course, there is still much to be done, but this is an important fact. We call in our opinion – which has been taken on board and I thank the rapporteur very much for this – that the European mobility and educational and voluntary exchange programmes be open to disabled boys and girls and that the financial support already provided for in the Erasmus+ programme be strengthened.  Access for disabled people to communication, culture and information technologies appropriate to different disabilities is also crucial, and we call for the Marrakesh Treaty to be transposed for the blind. It is absolutely necessary to define the structured dialogue with representative associations and to involve them already in the formulation of implementation policies and the Convention from the Accessibility Act.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. – Mr President, it is my pleasure to speak on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs. It is important to note that that committee also adopted its opinion in full unanimity. So we all agree how important it is that the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities will be fully implemented and that all EU and Member State legislation will be brought into line with the Convention. This requires a thorough evaluation of all EU legislation. I want specifically to highlight the importance of access to justice. Access to justice is not just about fair legislation: it is about legal procedures which must be adjusted to the needs of persons with disabilities, inter alia through EU judicial training programmes. There must also be an individual and tailor—made complaint mechanism to ensure that all the rights encompassed in the Convention are provided not just on paper but in reality. This Convention brings added value to the EU legal system because it enables us to understand that people have special needs vis-à-vis justice, as elsewhere. I wholeheartedly ask all of you to support Ms Stevens in today’s vote.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – Mr President, I am intervening because I was, on this second occasion, draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Women.  Of the 80 million women and men with disabilities, half of them women - almost 46 million, which makes up 16% of the population of the European Union - and I would like to refer in this second shift especially to them.  They face multiple discrimination—women and girls—often face many obstacles in order to exercise their rights; they undoubtedly have a much greater risk of violence, injury, exploitation and ill-treatment and are therefore often in more vulnerable conditions.  There is no doubt that their access to employment and education is also more difficult. If we compare the employment rates of women without disabilities and women with disabilities there is also an abyss; also in their access to education, for which we demand in these concluding observations an inclusive education, an education for all.  In this case, the committee's concluding observations are very clear: they call for the gender perspective to be considered in all areas in which the Union works and, in particular, in the disability strategy and the gender equality strategy.  They also have the right to enjoy their sexuality as all human beings and like all persons without disabilities and, therefore, they are denounced and asked to ban coercive abortion and compulsory sterilization of these women; break a spear, therefore, to defend women and girls with disabilities more than ever.

name: Ádám Kósa
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, honourable Colleagues, Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. This report is of historic importance because the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities was ratified by the EU in 2010, the first of the various UN conventions. In 2015, we reached the point where the Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities sent the EU final conclusions with strong proposals. Today, the European Parliament is debating and voting on this subject. On behalf of the European People's Party, I was able to work very well with the reporting woman. The report points out that the scope of crpd principles is much broader than the issue of discrimination. I would like to draw attention to the importance of digital techniques, as they facilitate social inclusion for persons with disabilities, including assistive technologies.  I regret that a disproportionate number of people with disabilities in Europe do not yet have access to the Internet and therefore are missing information and opportunities. The unemployment rate among persons with disabilities, especially women, is extremely high and it is therefore necessary to go beyond the framework of protected employment and create employment conditions for people with disabilities that introduce them into the open labour market. Finally, on education: I am convinced that equal opportunities can only be achieved if the conditions for inclusive education must be ensured in all areas, including the different types of education and training and lifelong learning. If we provide these, then the change will be truly noticeable. That's what we all work for.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Dear colleagues, Commissioner, first of all, I sincerely thank the rapporteur for the excellent report and for our close cooperation for people with disabilities, and I am pleased that this cooperation has led us to strengthen certain aspects of the report which are very important for people with disabilities. And indeed, in the report, we are now paying more attention and highlighting those employment problems for people with disabilities and the obstacles they face and hindering their entry into the labour market. And indeed, one of the most important persistent problems is discrimination against people with disabilities in the workplace. We must combat this, and I congratulate both the European Parliament and the European Commission on taking certain steps to strengthen the protection of persons with disabilities against discrimination in all countries of the European Union. However, we still have a long way to go to make jobs in the Member States truly accessible to people with disabilities, and also to create working conditions that enable people with disabilities to work. We must also ensure equal access for people with disabilities to education and vocational training. All these aspects are essential to create real conditions for people with disabilities to work and live as independently as possible, to realize themselves in the professional field, and thus to contribute to society. I therefore agree that we must call on the Member States to grant employers certain tax incentives and other incentives to actually employ people with disabilities. And of course this is only one of the incentives, but states need to take full advantage of them, the opportunities available to encourage the employment of people with disabilities. Another very important area that I want to draw attention to is social protection for people with disabilities. Social state support for people with disabilities, whose employment rates are indeed low, often becomes the only source of livelihood. Without social assistance in the European Union, as many as 70% of people with disabilities would live on the brink of poverty. The United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities stresses in particular the negative impact of indiscriminate austerity measures on the social protection of persons with disabilities. After all, austerity has indeed been made first and foremost at the expense of the most vulnerable people. We must therefore correct this, adopt specific measures in the Member States to improve social security for persons with disabilities.  And one more thing I want to draw attention to, all the more so because the honourable Commissioner is here. The Commission is late in the 2010-2020 a mid-term review of the European Disability Strategy. Indeed, I believe that that mid-term review would be of great use to those decisions that we need to take both at European Union level and in individual Member States, because we will simply know then the real situation of our disabled people.  (The speaker agrees to answer the blue card question of the person who raised the Blue Card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Dear President, thank you for accepting this blue card of mine. You were talking about the needs of disability benefits. My question is: do you agree with me that state benefits and assistance should also go towards local and regional self-government units and utilities, public companies employing people with disabilities? So, do you think cities, municipalities and regions should also receive assistance from the state in the event of such employment, and do you think they should be included in this report?

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: answer to the blue card question. – Thank you for your question. I am, in principle, in favour of the real functioning of social enterprises for people with disabilities in our Member States of the European Union, which can directly employ people with disabilities. Such companies are working, but is that sufficient to support it, it is unlikely. It needs to be strengthened so that people with disabilities can actually work and those companies do not go bankrupt. But here is one side. The other side is that not only people with disabilities in social enterprises can work in social enterprises, but also in the overall labour market, so that employers have an interest in recruiting people with disabilities in the open labour market. That is when we combine these two options, when we are interested and employers actually recruit disabled people, then a good result will surely be achieved.

name: Czesław Hoc
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to thank Helda Stevens very much for her titanic work on this report. It is estimated that 80 million people in the European Union are people with disabilities – that is a lot. This number makes us aware of the great challenges, how much responsibility and how much work still lies ahead. It is said that the measure of modern civilization is its attitude towards people with disabilities. Another motto is also known: there is no disabled person, there is a man. It is therefore our sacred duty to ensure that persons with disabilities have an inalienable right to dignity, the right to equal treatment, independent living and full participation in family and social life, and to ensure the development of the capacity of children with disabilities and their right to complete integration into school.  But we must also bear in mind very important issues: the disabled do not need comfort, only understanding, they do not need pity, only genuine respect, nor do they need extra legal solutions, only legal guarantee of equal opportunities and equal treatment. So, in order to help them effectively and realistically, we need to shape the consciences and attitudes of the environment in which they live in parallel.

name: Marian Harkin
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the first and only international treaty that the EU has ratified. Three countries including my own, Ireland, have still to ratify, but I hope we will do so by the end of the year.  Today we are discussing Parliament’s response to the CRPD concluding observations as to how we are implementing the Convention, and in this context I want to thank our colleague, Helga Stevens, who has been an excellent rapporteur.  So what is Parliament saying? Well, the process of drawing up the document was as important as its content, and in that context people with disabilities were involved in all committee meetings which were accessible. So the phrase ‘nothing about us without us’ was taken seriously by the rapporteur. We also see that the principle of stakeholder consultation is woven right throughout this report. The report takes a rights-based approach and in order to vindicate those rights we need adequate legislation. We already have anti-discrimination in the area of employment and occupation etc. but we need to find some solution to the fact that the anti-discrimination directive which would ensure equal treatment outside the labour market is stuck in Council. Our role here is as legislators, as is that of the Commission, and in that context we have to ensure that all legislation is disability-proofed – both current and future regulation. In this context also I want to agree with my colleague Richard Howitt when he asks the Commissioner to go above and beyond what is already in the pipeline.  The rights of persons with disabilities must be mainstreamed in our work here; it must never be an add-on. Once we have that mind-set, I believe we are on the right road. There are excellent proposals in this report but I shall just highlight three which I think are of crucial importance. First of all, support for independent living, secondly equal opportunities for employment, and thirdly equal access to the digital society.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam Representative, I would like to highlight two elements from your comment. One is that you have also remembered that this is the first convention in which the European Union, as such, is a party and mentioned future legislation. I ask you whether you see an opportunity to move our attention to criminal law, i.e. to punish violence against people with disabilities in a similar way throughout Europe?

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: Blue-card answer. – This is the first international treaty that the EU has ratified. I think the question was about future legislation and whether there is some way that people can vindicate their rights in court, because that is sometimes the only way that people can vindicate their rights. Well, obviously, with any European legislation that is ratified by Member States, people with disabilities or other persons can always vindicate those rights in court. For example, we saw a case some years back where a woman who had a child with disabilities in the UK was able to vindicate her rights as to, if you like, second—hand discrimination, in the ECJ, because of the fact that she was treated unfairly because she had a child with disabilities. Actually indirect discrimination is the proper term for that. So that is an example of how somebody was able to vindicate their rights in court because of the legislation that we had here in the Parliament.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank Helga Stevens for this report, and congratulate all the committees of the European Parliament for their contribution. The European Parliament thus becomes the leader in the implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. We are also demonstrating what work we can do and why the role of the European Parliament in the implementation of the Convention needs to be upgraded.  The convention is a groundbreaking text. However, it can be left on paper if it is not fully implemented. And that's where the problems start. While this is the first time that the European Union has signed an international convention as a transnational entity, it unfortunately does not take the lead when it comes to implementing the Convention on The Disabled. The Commission is 'playing hide-and-seek'. While, for the implementation of the UN Convention it "raises its hands high" and refers to the Member States, in other matters it appears combative when, for example, it is going to put forward tough budgetary measures. For the contract it declares not competent. I shout, with all my might, that the rights of people with disabilities outside the common European policy must be an incentive to create this common policy.  I call on the Commission, on this sensitive issue, to stop hiding behind the institutional deficits of the European Union. To take new legislative initiatives to ensure the universal and uniform application of the Convention in all Member States. The implementation of the Convention is a 100% political issue. If the European Union wants to become a real Union, it must not hesitate to implement it fully, even if changes to the Treaties, new legislation and new funding resources are needed.

name: Tatjana Ždanoka
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would also like to congratulate Mrs Stevens for her really great job. We have a very useful and well—balanced report which focuses on those recommendations that fall only within the EU’s competence and pays special attention to the EU institutions, which are to be a role model in implementing the Convention. The Commission and the Member States have to take the necessary measures to mainstream disability in all legislation, policies and strategies. All persons with disabilities are entitled to full participation in society and support from publicly funded systems. We therefore have reasonable concerns that the European structural and investment funds are being misused to promote institutionalisation. Therefore it is extremely important that the report contains strong recommendations on spending, withdrawing and recovering payments if the obligation to respect the fundamental rights of persons with disabilities is breached. Being a long—standing member of the Committee on Petitions, I can confirm that a considerable number of petitions from persons with disabilities are submitted to the Parliament every year, demonstrating their difficulties with regard to access to work, employment, education, transport or participation in political, public and cultural rights. It is very important that we also collect data on violations of these rights, which must be disaggregated data collected by the EU social services.

name: Laura Agea
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the first thing I would like to do this morning is to thank Mrs Stevens, because with this work you are one of the few times that, here in the European Parliament, we bring the people who will benefit from this Convention and this implementation. You have had this merit, because the people with whom you have worked out this work are exactly the people who will benefit from it and will be able to say: 'We have entered these rooms, which very often keep us out'.  I am extremely pleased about this because the subject, as well as this subject, touches me closely and I am glad that our position is one of those times in which it is shared. It is sometimes strange to see that on certain issues Parliament has such shared positions when we seem so far apart from each other. Instead, the rights of people with disabilities must be a priority, a commitment, one that does not make discounts, that does not allow any kind of deprivation, that sees us committed and united in order to guarantee them.  Unfortunately, austerity and the economic crisis have, alas, placed a huge burden on people with disabilities. But we have talked about the need to support independent living, concepts that, unfortunately, are still far from being fully implemented in Italy today. In Italy it is still difficult to talk about care givers, de-institutionalization, support for independent living. May this be a commitment, let this be a starting point to be able to fully implement this convention in our country. Architectural barriers are still a reality, unfortunately, in schools and the first commitment is precisely to support education, to include children with disabilities in the world of education so that they become a resource.  People with disabilities must be an extraordinary resource, a resource for which our commitment must be worth whatever effort we must make. This work, I think, is proof that no commitment is ever enough when it comes to people who are not vulnerable. We are used to thinking of these people as if they were vulnerable. These people are an extraordinary resource and let me say that this work, today, I would like to dedicate it to my nephew, to Diego.

name: Joëlle Mélin
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, this report on the implementation of the Convention on Persons with Disabilities signed with the United Nations is obviously a problem. On the form, it is part of the first and only agreement signed with the United Nations, with this anomaly that, 28 Member States having already signed, the European level is supernumerary. On the form again, the multiplicity of commissions consulted makes the final text totally inaudible. On the merits, the systematization of the criterion of subjectivity of disability, by definition vague and unvaluable, is in total contradiction with certain national laws, including French law, which recognises that the handicap, admittedly suffered, is above all a functional and objective deficit, which is the indispensable condition for a fair regal regal compensation. In substance, this text also multiplies the commonplaces not only in that it admits disabled people of all categories, but also in that it considers as victims of discrimination children, women, the elderly, the sick, migrants, the poor and LGBTI people, which, de facto, determines that the only standard for you would be a young man , healthy, rich, sedentary, in full possession of his intellectual and physical means and heterosexual. It is not me who says it, it is the exact mirror of your right-of-hommist discourse. So I'll let you think. In the end, all your demonstrations concerning the acts of personal, family, professional and societal life do not lead to any proposal or concrete application in the face of the sometimes exhausting difficulties faced by disabled people. This text is, in fact, an affront to people who are truly disabled. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Blue card question. – Madam Representative, we have debated this several times in the preparatory meetings, and this issue has been raised several times, so I would like to ask you now before the plenary session: the UN Convention says that the rights of persons with disabilities must be approached on the basis of human rights and that we need to look at what their capabilities are and should be developed, and not what is missing? Do you agree with that?

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, thank you, Mr Kosa, it is clear that this text raises the right questions about people with functional deficits, not personal feelings of difficulty. However, this whole text is, in fact, only subjective. We have discussed this a lot in committee. The reality is that disabled people - anyone with functional deficits, whether cognitive, physical, sensory or otherwise - should have the same opportunities as others, and that is what should be offered to them, not endless speeches which, as Mr Howitt said earlier, lead to few concrete proposals.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr President, this report manages to bring to the fore the many important problems faced by people with disabilities. I congratulate the editor on her work in this area.  Unfortunately, however, not all disabled people enjoy the same rights in the European Union and the situation is not the same in all the countries of the Union. Unfortunately, my country, Greece, has been a very negative example in this area, especially since the economic crisis for which the Union is not without responsibility has broken out.  Memorandum obligations and economic cuts did not exclude disabled people. Reductions in disability pensions, the abolition of tax relief, deliberate reductions in disability rates by committees, the difficulty of access to high-cost medicines and access to the national health system, the lack of qualified teaching staff, the under-functioning of educational institutions, reductions in the salaries and pensions of parents with disabled children, have brought these individuals and their families to despair. The biggest victims of the economic crisis are the disabled in Greece.  The report would be more comprehensive with a firm recommendation to memorial governments and lenders to exempt the disabled from economic policies that de-impoverished them and lead them to The Canada.

name: David Casa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Helga Stevens also for her excellent work. I welcome this report. It brings us a step closer to achieving equal rights and opportunities for people with disabilities. It highlights amongst other things elements related to employment and education, which are particularly important if we are to help people achieve independence and realise their full potential. I especially encourage further development of incentives for employers who offer jobs to people with disabilities. Opportunities need to be created so that everyone can become as independent as possible and participate in all domains of life. If these issues are not addressed, they will only result in greater social exclusion and poverty and we cannot allow that. I believe that limited access to education for individuals with disabilities is bound to have a negative impact later on in their lives and limit the choices and possibilities at a later stage. So I call for provisions that will help people with disabilities participate in courses which will enhance their competences and skills, including participation in apprenticeships. There is still a lot that needs to be done, but we must remember that one—size—fits—all solutions are not the answer. We need to focus on the diversity of problems that people with disabilities face on a daily basis.  Finally, the European Union should act as a beacon in promoting the rights of persons with disabilities. We have made big strides at EU level in this regard, and I am proud of that, but unfortunately disregard for the rights of – as well as discrimination against – people with disabilities are still felt within the EU despite the fact that they are all embedded in our Treaties.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Welcome, Commissioner. Over 80 million people in Europe live with a disability, and for many it means fewer opportunities to live the life they want to live. It is against this background that the European Parliament's proposals to comply with anti-discrimination legislation and to meet the requirements for a European Accessibility Act should also be seen. In order for this to become a reality, more hard facts are needed about the living conditions of the disabled. Above all, a broader and deeper commitment is needed from all Member States. A concrete proposal that we could implement at European level is to open up existing EU programmes for citizens with disabilities, such as the Erasmus+ programme. In the field of employment, there are, of course, a number of incentive and support programmes in terms of the conditions and establishment of people with disabilities. It is not enough, but it is important that it exists, because this often means that other non-disabled people have better and more human health and safety at work. So we all serve as citizens of society or as employees of a company. We all benefit from a community building that assumes that everyone has rights and that everyone is needed. Whether we are young or old, whether we have a visible handicap or an invisible one, or are simply part of Europe's ageing population. Thank you for your job, Helga.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, I would like to congratulate Mrs Stevens on her excellent suggestion. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities aims to combat discrimination and social racism against such persons. In Europe there are currently 80 million people with disabilities, of whom around 46 million are women and girls. At the same time, the participation and access of people with disabilities to the labour market is particularly problematic, as within the Union only about 48% work, while only 27.8% have completed higher education studies.  Moreover, in countries such as Greece, the troika has greatly reduced disability pensions, leading people with disabilities even further to social exclusion and making their standard of living more difficult. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to take the lead in respecting and promoting the human rights of people with disabilities, to put an end to austerity policies affecting their rights, thus vindicating the hundreds of petitions we have received in the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I am proud that both my country and the EU as a whole are parties to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. We have agreed to ensure and promote these rights. Article 4 is very clear in this regard; but the article continues ‘To this end, States Parties undertake to adopt all appropriate legislative, administrative and other measures for the implementation of the rights.’ The Commission has been working hard to implement this convention: you have proposed both the Web Accessibility Directive, which I am honoured to be rapporteur for, and recently you proposed the Accessibility Act. But it is the Member States that must translate those proposals into real actions on the ground. It took the Council four years to accept web accessibility and the speed which is being applied to the Web Accessibility Act is regrettable. We cannot afford to wait forever and neither can our citizens with disabilities. So, Commissioner, I encourage you to stress this fact to the Council. Accessibility is not a cost but a right for all our citizens, and I think our governments must honour this right.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, approximately 15% of the world's population, or 900 million people, has a disability. But 80% of these people live in developing countries. 50% of disabilities can be avoided because they are directly related to poverty. Poverty is an obstacle to access to basic needs such as nutrition, health care and water, and these factors, in turn, can lead to disability. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development is clear in addressing this problem. However, our foreign policy and, above all, trade further impoverishes developing countries by undermining, interlessing, public services and thus undermining fundamental human rights. We must help strengthen public services in developing countries, especially health and education, and not undermine them by seeking the profit of our businesses. Only in this way, with quality public services, early medical care and less inequality, we will be addressing the real problems of people with disabilities in the world. And in the European Union the main enemy of these people is austerity, it is cuts and privatisations of public services, so let us be consistent, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is not a service to people with disabilities to impose, in a debate as sensitive as this one, considerations relating to the sexual identity of persons or the status of migrants. Do you realize that these ideological excesses are likely to discredit and weaken the thinking on the issue of disability? Similarly, you are aware that unrealistic or excessive approaches are counterproductive. That is why I proposed, in the course of my committee's opinion, to talk about difficulties in accessing care, rather than barriers. At the same time, I have advocated a pragmatic approach to improving access to care for people with disabilities where possible. It should be noted that this text still defends respect for people, in particular by stressing the importance of their free consent. That is why it is regrettable that the best aspects of this text are polluted by the migratory obsession and the communitarian prism, which are not, let us be honest, the main concerns of people with disabilities.

name: Marek Plura (PPE).
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Dear Helgo! At the outset, I would like to congratulate you on a great report and the commitment of a wide representation of people with disabilities, and thank you for your excellent cooperation. I share the view that accessibility is as important in the physical environment as it is in relation to information and communication technologies. Digital skills or the use of modern technologies are becoming an indispensable precondition for the functioning of the labour market, so the availability of technologies and equipment and the promotion of employment-friendly skills education are crucial for building an inclusive society in which all citizens can exercise their rights and contribute to the common good. New technologies, while an opportunity to remove barriers, can also be a source of limitations. The widespread introduction of touch screens prevents visually impaired people from using elevators and many other devices on their own. Can a solution that leads to the exclusion of a large group of citizens be called modern? Certainly not. I believe that dynamic work on the European Accessibility Act will avoid such pseudo-progress in the future.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR).
text: – The European Union acceded to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities almost six years ago. I would like to express my views on this important issue, not only as a politician, but also as a person who knows these issues deeply. We must do our utmosted to make life easier for people with disabilities. It is also necessary to ensure adequate social support and old-age pensions for parents and carers of persons with disabilities, whose daily devotion to loved ones can be described boldly as a manifestation of heroism. The Convention makes it clear that all human rights must be guaranteed to people with disabilities. Unfortunately, these provisions have not been fully implemented since ratification. And one of the most important human rights is precisely the right to a dignified life. This noble objective can be achieved by increasing not only the budgetary expenditure of the Member States, but also by means of targeted grants from the European Commission. Thanks for the attention.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: "Mr President, Commissioner, Mrs Stevens, I would like to thank you for the pleasure of working with you on this report, for your passion and determination.  From the Committee on Petitions we believe that this report on the implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is a real milestone for the European Parliament: it is the first human rights treaty of the 21st century and the first to sign the European Union on human rights.  But let me tell you that I am particularly concerned about two articles of this Convention, 24 and 30, which guarantee the right to inclusive, non-discriminatory and equal opportunity education. So, why am I worried? Because the Council, with a blocking minority, remains deactivated and has not implemented eer the Anti-Discrimination Directive or the Marrakesh Treaty.  I would please ask you, from here, that the Three-Year Marrakesh Treaty should be ratified at once and that these seven countries, led by Germany and Italy, deactivate all their preventions — because they have a lot to do with the publishing industry and only 10% of the millions of books published in Europe are accessible to visually impaired people.  So, let's do something else to complete this deployment.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, universal suffrage is not a reality in Europe. In the Spanish state there are 80,000 persons with disabilities who are denied the right to vote for having a court incapacity sentence. Article 29 of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities says that "political rights and the ability to enjoy them on an equal footing" will be guaranteed "to persons with disabilities". The Spanish Government ratified this text in 2008. However, it does not comply. It is preventing the exercise of a fundamental right. The United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities asked the Spanish executive to amend the electoral law allowing this discrimination. But the Spanish government has not. It is preventing thousands of people from participating in political life. This is an electoral apartheid; they are prevented from exercising the right to vote, to decide on the future of their country, by having a disability. It is a flagrant breach of international law. Is the European Commission planning to do anything?

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in my view we cannot ignore three points: access for people with disabilities to the labour market and decent pay is essential. Children with disabilities need increased protection and the families and caregivers of these citizens need monitoring, information and training in order to reduce the risk of abandonment or institutionalization. The solutions also include creating awareness-raising initiatives, both with companies and with civil society on the potential of these citizens, by creating specific tools or programs for the adaptation of infrastructure, by encouraging the creation of monitoring and welcoming entities complementary to family action and by using programs such as Horizon 2020 to make a bet on research in this area. Commissioner, all persons with disabilities have the right to live in a society with equal opportunities. It is the duty of the European institutions to honour this Convention in future documents and legislation, and Member States must make the necessary efforts to comply with its provisions. Only in this way can we fulfil our commitment to an inclusive Europe without barriers for its citizens.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is indeed a serious document and I am glad that the European Parliament is dedicated to it.  I believe that we should emphasise as much as possible the relationship between availability, quality and price intensity. People with disabilities are already exposed to a significant amount of financial costs. I therefore believe that the provision of healthcare should take this into account.  In general, I think that health care should be free of charge. However, for people with disabilities, ness is an absolute necessity, given the very specific situation in which they find themselves. The health care system must accommodate these people and do everything possible to avoid complicating an already difficult life situation. They have to take into account their needs and possibilities and I am glad that the draft report remembered this.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have great respect for my colleagues who have disabilities, who are here with us and overcome obstacles every day. This is an example to me of huge motivation and tremendous personal commitment and I want to thank them for their work here.  I think it is important that the European Union does not forget people with disabilities and that it supports the Member States in their efforts. We must also do our homework at EU level, and in this we can rely on the first monitoring report of the UN Human Rights Committee.  Our response at the moment is this comprehensive report, which really addresses all areas of disabled citizens in their daily efforts for a dignified life and a full life, and I want to thank my colleague Helza Stevens for this comprehensive report.  I think there are some fundamental things that make life possible, whether it's education, access to the labour market or also supporting families and assistants who help these people. I would like to say that the Czech Republic has made great progress in this area and is dedicated to the integration of children. Of course, we also see the task of supporting teachers in their improved preparation, in conditions to work with handicapped pupils, and in this area the Czech Republic has made significant progress and I think it is an example of the integration of disabled children.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the first international treaty on human rights ratified by the EU and signed by all 28 EU Member States and ratified by 27 Member States. It is also the first time that a UN institution has monitored the EU's fulfilment of international human rights obligations. Thanks to these factors, the relevant regulatory legislation is mandatory in the EU and its Member States, so it can be said that people with disabilities can see real progress and say that the EU is paying attention to their problems and specific needs. I believe that this can be achieved in other areas of human rights, which can be a successful recipe: the EU must join – because the Treaty of Lisbon provides for this – other human rights conventions, so that the provisions currently only at recommendation level, which have already been signed and ratified by most EU Member States, can be verified and enforced.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, from the outset I would like to congratulate our colleague Helga on all her performance, not just for this report. Human rights must not be negotiated, it must be applied and this report says what we need, but the Commission, the Council and the Member States must find the way for people to be treated the same. We don't have two categories of people, we have people. There must be accessibility to jobs in the labour market, to tourism, to education, to culture, to all the diversity of life. That is why, as an MEP on the TRAN and IMCO committee, I have also argued and iadvocate in my country that we must find ways to do education and the population in order to have fair treatment for these colleagues of ours, these people, these people who have another physical possibility. I believe that the Commission and the Member States have this responsibility to apply what we are now asking for in this report, and I congratulate Helga once again.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: –  Mr President, implementing the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is highly important, and we should admit that there is still a lot to be done in order to guarantee equal access to inclusive and quality education and training for all people with disabilities and to give them real opportunities for personal and professional development. To achieve this, systematic and close consultations between representative organizations of persons with disabilities, policy-makers, businesses and other relevant stakeholders must be initiated. Furthermore, the establishment, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of all policies related to education, training, culture, sport and youth should be conducted while taking into account the outcomes of those consultations. Like that, we can ensure that the real needs and requests of people with disabilities will be addressed. Further efforts are needed in order to facilitate and enhance the participation of people with special needs in different mobility programmes. That will benefit their self-government, self-development and self-assessment and give them life-changing experience and broaden their social network.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – I recently organised a consultation with people with disabilities in my country, Slovenia, on the European Accessibility Act. There I was warned that, of course, it is still a long way from the equality of people with disabilities in society that they want to be heard more. Although I can say that Slovenia has handled this area pretty well. People with disabilities have also pointed out that they face different forms of discrimination, not only in society as such, but above all they have pointed to discrimination still present in the labour market. In addition to the proposals set out here in the report, which will certainly help people with special needs to achieve independence in life, I believe that it is essential that we adopt the Accessibility Act as soon as possible.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: – Mr President, accessibility of transport is essential for people with disabilities. As shadow rapporteur for the Socialist and Democrat faction on the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I am glad that a number of points that we have supported here by a large majority have appeared in the final report.  People with disabilities face a number of barriers, starting with searching for information about the appropriate connection, orientation in stations, accessibility of infrastructure and transport services themselves. We must ensure that the rights of persons with disabilities are fully respected in European legislation on passenger rights for all modes of transport, and that it is also properly implemented. I am also very glad that the report contains a call for the extension of the European Disability Card to include Member States that did not initially join the pilot project, which also applies, for example, to the Czech Republic. Finally, I would like to thank all the colleagues who participated in the report, and in particular the rapporteur, Helza Stevens, for the very open approach she has taken to the report.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE).
text: –  I use the English language today, not my mother tongue, Maltese, to raise awareness that some people on the autistic spectrum in my country learn only one language – English – but in a dual-language country this should not continue to impede their educational development. I want to nudge policy-makers to stop looking at disability and to focus on the person. True, what meets the eye is the wheelchair, for example, but what should meet our minds and hearts is the person in that wheelchair. This report gives us an opportunity to show our citizens that we value the potential and the ability of each one of us. Employment, education, sports, these are our culture. Since culture is the narrative of our lifestyle, the way we live, what we do every single day, let's make sure that all persons, even those whom the environment disables, have space to participate. We need the abilities and potential of every person, so let's stop pushing people out of our societies.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the first major human rights treaty of the new millennium. It is a very important document for the promotion of a new culture of disability, but standards alone are not enough. We need policies, cultural policies first and foremost, because the culture of rights must be regained every day. Unfortunately, disabled people still face a wide range of obstacles preventing them from making progress towards equal opportunities, independence and full social and economic integration. And although the Union has responded to this challenge by taking a number of legal and political initiatives to remove these obstacles, there is still a long way to go.  The European Union must implement the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in a strict manner. It is necessary to give concrete answers to the many citizens and their families, who all too often suffer in silence from conditions of great discomfort.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Many thanks to Mrs Stevens for this strong performance, also in the interests of the European Parliament, and to you, Commissioner, for the implementation of the UN Convention. It is an important step in social Europe. Let me also take this opportunity to raise an issue that is taking place on the margins, namely the attempt to finance a major event for the disabled, namely the Paralympics, next year. Unfortunately, we learned yesterday that there are major problems here. I would ask you, Commissioner, to help and help us to support the funds in the area of the budget and Erasmus+ as a means of support, which can send out this great signal for social Europe, which is a strong signal for the disabled throughout the world. I thank you in advance for these efforts, Mrs Thyssen.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: –  Mr President, I have listened to the debate very carefully and there are three points I just want to mention. Firstly, employment has been mentioned, and I think especially with flexibility in employment now, so much can be done over the internet, etc. and there are far more opportunities to employ people with a disability than ever before. Secondly, education has been mentioned and obviously the figures of those going on to the third level are very small – somebody mentioned 28%. We should aim to double that as one of our 2020-2030 targets. Thirdly, Mr Becker referred to sport and I agree completely with him: Paralympics, Special Olympics, do fantastic work for people with disabilities. I had the honour, when I was president of the GAA, of hosting the Special Olympics in Croke Park a few years ago and the result of that is that we have such wonderful movements as the Kerrys Stars. My own organization has introduced hurling for people in wheelchairs – wheelchair-hurling – and I think these are initiatives that can help people with disabilities to get independent living and enjoy life the same as the rest of us.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It must be as natural for people with a disability as it is for all other people to live a self-determined life, to participate in social life, to enter a building, to use means of transport or to have unrestricted access to information and services. Unfortunately, I still experience far too often that people with disabilities are marginalised or face almost insurmountable obstacles in everyday situations, a fact that we need to change immediately. This issue already affects 80 and soon more than 100 million people in the EU. I am therefore very pleased that today, as the European Parliament, we in the European Parliament are launching an own-initiative report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities to date, supported by so many committees. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Stevens, for her excellent work. We have produced a balanced report which is a good basis for our further work. There is still a long way to go.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Mr President, people with disabilities are the most sensitive and often the most neglected and wronged group of any society, especially the Greek one, which suffers from the consequences of the memorandums. Despite the big mouth about protecting human rights, the European Union is not pressuring lenders to exclude from austerity measures the funds allocated to people with disabilities. With few exceptions, people with disabilities are sensitive people, have good character and love everyone else, and they grieve because we, who are able to do so, do not care to the extent that we can and should for them.  So first as people and then as citizens it is necessary to press the state to take care of people with disabilities, to make sure that they integrate them into society, to educate them, to find them a job and to enable them to develop their qualifications in order to thrive. In addition, these individuals want our support.  These people have not always been disabled, nor are they responsible for their disability, and in the end I will say what the ancient Greeks said: common luck and the future invisible. No one can know what's going to happen to us, who are able-bodied, in the next moment.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This report makes valuable recommendations to the institutions of the European Union in the area of the implementation of the UN Convention. There are more than 80 million people with varying degrees of disability living in the Member States of the European Union, of whom only 58% are in the labour market. Among women with disabilities, the employment rate is downright alarmingly low, at 44%. It is therefore very clear that a significant proportion of people with disabilities remain outside the labour market and that those who have employment largely do not make full use of their competences and skills.  In order to tackle the demographic problems facing Europe and maintain the current standard of living, all the labour resources at our disposal, including people with disabilities, will have to be fully exploited. Social economy and the new technology sector make disability very often no longer a significant obstacle to work. There are still barriers in our heads. The Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities was intended to help us change the perception of people with disabilities. However, practice shows that there is still a huge problem with this. I do not understand why the Council did not agree to include disability documents within the scope of the Regulation on the recognition of public documents. After all, this will make it very difficult for people with disabilities to find work across Europe.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. I have heard a great deal of congratulations here with regard to the rapporteur and the rapporteurs of the various committees that have contributed to this report, and I would like to reiterate my support. This is an excellent report. I would also like to thank you all for today's constructive discussion. I would also like to point out that there has been excellent cooperation between the three political European institutions to conduct dialogue with the United Nations Committee. This too is proof that there is a real common will to make progress on the application of the UN convention. Today's discussion has shown that there is indeed a strong commitment to apply and implement the Treaty, to respond to the challenges we have faced in giving people with disabilities, men and women, the full opportunity to exercise their fundamental rights, their human rights. We must not forget, as you rightly pointed out in the report and as Mr Howitt also pointed out, that this is indeed a human rights issue that goes beyond social law, employment and social policy. Only by ensuring a coherent application through the various political policy areas will we be able to effectively shape our commitments. A lot of specific questions and comments have been made. It is leading us too far and there is no time to go into it in detail, but this is nevertheless the case: the accessibility bill, which as you know is pending in Parliament and in the Council, is making reasonably good progress in the Council. I hope that this proposal will continue to work hard in Parliament, so that it can reach conclusions quickly. With regard to the pending proposal for a horizontal directive against discrimination against people with disabilities, you know that at the beginning of this legislature the new Commission withdrew a number of proposals that had been pending for a long time in the context of good governance. However, we have not withdrawn this proposal, because it is precisely the Commission that attaches great importance to it. Moreover, Mr Jourová continues to urge the Council to make further progress so that this proposal can eventually become law. Another specific question concerned the Marrakesh Convention on Copyright. In this context too, you know that a proposal is pending and that we hope that the Council will eventually act properly so that we can work effectively with it. A question has also been asked in the interventions of the "catch the eye" procedure on the funding of the Paralympics. I will be happy to keep in touch with Mr Becker and Kelly to inform me exactly about the state of play so that we can see what we can do. You know that the budget is a complex matter, but I would like to listen in more detail to the concerns to see if we can do something. I would also like to say something about the involvement of civil society. I want to assure you that I attach great importance to this, and so do the people in the gallery. We attach great importance to the input of people with disabilities and to good, permanent contacts, almost on a daily basis, with their organisations. We therefore welcome the alternative implementation report of the European Disability Forum. In preparing the Commission's report to the United Nations, there have been several meetings with the organisations. They have also been involved in the study that my services have commissioned in preparation for our report. We also convened the interested parties in the autumn of last year for a specific session devoted to the final remarks of the United Nations. Finally, the Commission has invited the supervisory structure, which includes the European Disability Forum, to join our delegation in Geneva for the evaluation of the United Nations in the summer of 2015. However, the supervisory structure has chosen to participate separately in this meeting. That is why she was not a direct member of our delegation. To conclude, I would like to point out that the comprehensive nature of Mrs Stevens' report is a great help in preparing our progress report on the European Strategy for People with Disabilities, on our mid-term review. It also certainly helps to make further efforts, which for my part go beyond our strategy for people with disabilities. The report encourages us to make further efforts to address the comments we have received from the Committee of the United Nations is really adequate to respond. I hope that we will continue to work together as well in the future as in the past. Congratulations again on your report.

name: Helga Stevens
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank all colleagues and committees again for their valuable input in their areas of expertise, which allowed for a very concise and comprehensive report. I would also like to highlight the support from my colleagues at the Disability Intergroup and I am very glad that we have Commissioner Thyssen with us today making disability a priority at Commissioner level, and I hope it stays that way. The involvement of people with disabilities was crucial during the whole process, and we should not forget that the Convention puts new obligations on the EU. I can only reiterate that freedom of movement, especially for workers, is also a right for people with disabilities and this also includes full and equal access to the Erasmus + programme. With regard to the exercise of political rights, this is just one example of where people with disabilities continue to be left out. Changes must be made so that people with disabilities can fully exercise their right to vote and to stand as candidates during elections. Again, I would like to mention the Disability Intergroup, who signed many amendments and were actively involved in the whole process of the report. This cross-party support from all EU countries is a significant indicator of how important the protection of the rights of persons with disabilities is everywhere, and not only in one or two areas or regions. Madam President, I will do my utmost to make sure this remains not just a piece of paper, but can have a real impact on person with disabilities here at the European institutions and across Europe. Remember this is about human rights, not more not less. The report has shown once more that the rights of persons with disabilities are to be taken seriously and are not merely a minority issue.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing.
