This report, which I approved, is an opportunity to remind people with disabilities that they have the right to live in a society where they have the same opportunities as other citizens in order to ensure their full integration and participation.  The EU and Member States must take measures to ensure the implementation of the rights of people with disabilities, the promotion of their autonomy, accessibility, employment and social integration. This includes the end of austerity policies, which we know are the most vulnerable. It is time to revive social investment. It is also time for respect for the rights of people with disabilities to be addressed in the work of the European Semester. Improving the consideration of their rights also requires a permanent and structured dialogue with organizations representing people with disabilities.  Finally, I would like to stress the importance of informing not only about the rights but also about the talents of people with disabilities, which are a real asset for our society.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. – I believe that awareness-raising activities on the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities should be continued, that prejudices should be combated and that a better understanding of all persons with disabilities should be promoted so that decisions can be taken on the basis of their real needs. I support initiatives aimed at drawing society's attention to the difficulties faced by persons with disabilities and to make people with disabilities more aware of their opportunities and contributions, including through special school education programmes. I would like to stress that the importance of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities lies essentially in changing cultural attitudes, acknowledging that disability is not in persons, but rather in the social and economic environment causing obstacles for people.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. – The integration of persons with disabilities into society must remain a priority for the European Union, and this requires the removal of all barriers and obstacles preventing their integration into education systems, the workplace, public life and their community. I support the rapporteur's proposal for information, awareness and training campaigns on the rights of people with disabilities, their diversity, skills and talents, on the one hand, but also to help remove obstacles that limit their participation in society, on the other. The European Union and the Member States must also cooperate to take the necessary measures to prevent any forms of abuse of persons with disabilities, in particular women and children, but also to implement harmonised policies to integrate the rights of persons with disabilities into all EU international cooperation policies and programmes.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. – People with disabilities are much more often struggling to access quality healthcare than others. This further exacerbates existing inequalities and has negative consequences for their ability to lead independent lives, jointly and on an equal footing with others. I therefore believe that it is important that EU Structural Funds, together with national measures, be used as a tool to improve the quality of life of people with disabilities and to promote the accessibility of healthcare, including electronic services, applications and devices.  Patients with disabilities should be able to benefit from the rights provided for in the Cross-Border Healthcare Directive in the same way as other patients. In many cases, for them, planned treatment abroad is associated with additional costs, which the state of insurance does not always reimburse. In practice, this has a deterrent effect.  In addition, information on treatment options should be provided in formats accessible to people with disabilities.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union acceded to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in 2010. This is the first bilateral agreement on human rights ratified by the European Union as a whole at international level. In view of its accession to the Convention, the European Union is required to draw up a report, the content of which will concern the action taken to comply with the conditions laid down in the Agreement. I am totally opposed to discrimination against people with disabilities, and I believe that everything must be done to combat it. Every citizen should have unrestricted access to all services and should therefore be able to fully enjoy the rights that the European Union gives. Persons with intellectual, physical and psychosocial disabilities should receive assistance and support. I believe that a dialogue involving the Commission and organisations of persons with disabilities should be developed in order to make the European Union's political strategy as beneficial as possible for people with disabilities.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is a debate on seven motions for resolutions on the situation of albino people in Africa and in Malawi in particular [2016/2807(RSP)].

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Madam President, today's resolution particularly focuses on the desperate plight of albinos in Malawi, but this is a problem that extends far beyond those borders to many other parts of Africa. The one statistic that remains in my mind is that 98% of those with albinism in Africa die before the age of 40, often from terrible skin cancers, but also from acts of violence against albinos, which are unfortunately only too common. In Malawi alone, there have been 65 recorded violent incidents since 2014. A mixture of folklore and belief systems that openly stigmatizes the condition by association with omens and bad luck versus ideas of the magical healing powers of dismembered limbs has resulted in an extremely dangerous and hostile environment for those poor individuals with albinism. The associated social stigma has devastating consequences for employment prospects and access to health care, as well as often having adverse effects for the social standing of other family members. There is a clear need for educational programs and of course for efforts by the criminal justice authorities to bring those to justice who have carried out acts of violence attacking albinos. I am pleased on behalf of the ECR today that we have raised this subject in the European Parliament, and I am very happy, as a doctor of medicine myself, to have signed today's joint resolution.

name: Maria Heubuch
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Violence against people with albinism is unimaginable. People with pigment disorders living in poorer countries suffer from social exclusion, often from very practical problems. They do not have adequate access to health care – we have just heard it – and they often do not have access to very simple means such as sunscreen. They are much more likely to develop skin cancer, and in Tanzania, 9 out of 19 people die with albinism before they turn 30. And now, in addition to the discrimination against this minority, there is also this monstrous wave of violence. They are murdered and mutilated because their body parts promise special powers. Albino children and babies are murdered, they live in terror, which is hard to imagine for us. In Malawi alone, an estimated ten people with albinism are at risk of murder. Authorities therefore need to protect potential victims much better. I very much welcome the fact that in Malawi, in Tanzania, there are announcements of measures from regional initiatives, but also from the United Nations, and that we will have an exchange of best practices. I also very much welcome – and I hope that the European Union can support this – when there is human rights training, for example, for police officers and they are strengthened in their position there. I am glad that we have given these people a voice here in Parliament today. I very much hope that in future we will no longer have to adopt a resolution on this issue, that we can deal with this unworthy issue really well and help the people on the ground.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative, when we talk about albinos in Malawi and in the region in general, we are talking about a truly absurd situation, given that they suffer violence of all kinds, mutilation, murder and have no peace even after death because, as Mrs Heubuch said, parts of their bodies are sold because they are believed to have magical value and act as amulets. Moreover, we have read that women are being raped because it is believed that aids are cured through sexual relations with them. We are talking about a truly tragic situation.  We have economic relations with Malawi: in addition to the Cotonou Agreement, we have international cooperation relations in which we should try to point out how important it is to protect this minority, which is at the mercy of criminal gangs, which in fact speculate, precisely, by selling these people, by popular belief.  Let us be firm in asking the authorities to intervene and to protect this minority.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà
text: Author. – Madam President, the joint resolution we are debating today should serve to send a clear message to African countries, which is in which the rights of people with albinism are violated.  People with albinism suffer the worst forms of persecution and violation of human rights: they are often verbally and physically assaulted, even mutilated or killed. These unacceptable aggressions not only occur in Malawi, they also occur in Tanzania, Burundi, Mozambique and Kenya.  People with albinism are socially discriminated against, excluding them from access to public services, including health care. Given the high rate of skin cancer cases among these people, their exclusion from the public health system is a death sentence.  Some of these countries have made efforts to remedy this dramatic situation, but it is not enough: they must take prevention and training measures and end impunity for aggressors.  From the European Union we must follow these facts that violate the most basic human rights and offer our cooperation to those affected to fight the aggressors.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the silent tragedy of albinos in Africa takes place in various forms, as has been said, first and foremost in the physical, with violence and mutilation perpetrated because of popular beliefs that give phantom powers to their body parts. But persecution also results in discrimination in society, when albino children are isolated because they are considered disabled or unable to continue their studies. This means abruptly interrupting their school education, limiting their access to work and better life chances.  I believe that with this resolution we want to call on the Government of Malawi and other African states to punish strictly those responsible for the repulsive crimes against albinos, and to launch an education and awareness-raising campaign that overcomes superstitions towards people suffering from mountaineering and allows them full integration into society, and we believe that the European Union must exert the necessary pressure to achieve these objectives.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: author. – Madam President, here in Europe when a baby is born, the parents are happy whatever the colour of the eyes or the hair. But in other places like Malawi, this is not the case. There, white babies with white hair and red eyes are watched with great superstition. Many parents believe it is a punishment from God. And these misconceptions, combined with the beliefs spread by wizards that certain body parts of albino people have magical powers, result in their being hunted like animals, and this in 2016. Their bones are sold for USD 75 000 – can you imagine this! It is unacceptable that people with albinism are hunted and killed just because they are born with another colour. I hope that Europe and the world do not close their eyes and look away, but react firmly to protect people with albinism and give them a normal life.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: Author. - Madam President, in Africa, people with albinism face some of the most extreme forms of persecution and human rights violations ranging from widespread social discrimination and harassment to murder, kidnapping, rape and mutilation. These threats come from superstitions according to which albinos possess magical powers, for example, there is a belief that having sex with them can cure AIDS. This causes gangs of traffickers to murder them to get parts of their bodies that are believed to bring health and wealth. On the part before us, the Union's external action sometimes undermines or impairs the public services of the southern countries, encouraging privatisations through totally unfair trade agreements. We must be consistent and realize that the most effective measure to address this reality is to strengthen the public services of these countries, especially education, to end these myths. Education, training and quality public, universal and quality health services are what they need.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, I would like to first welcome the high representative's presence in our debate and then add that I have proposed to my group to draft an emergency resolution on the situation of people with albinism in Africa and that I welcome the support of other political groups. It must be said that the starting point was The recent Amnesty International report on Malawi. But as other colleagues have mentioned, brutal attacks and savage killings have taken place in other countries. These include Tanzania, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Burundi and Côte d'Ivoire. In all of these countries, horrific crimes are being committed against people with albinism and the idea was to put this item on the agenda of today's meeting. I am pleased to see that all groups are concerned about the situation of these populations.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the birth of albinos in certain parts of Africa today means risking death, it also means risking mutilation, every day. Today we are here to deal with a very delicate issue: there are many people who are born like this, without pigmentation, and who are subjected to a series of inhuman practices and subjected to a stigmatization, every day.  So we are here to ask the government, not only in Malawi, but also in all the countries where these practices take place, to apply and invest in a policy of inclusion, a policy that must have a very strong plan and a strategy against all discrimination.  I believe that every person must be considered for what he is; each person must be considered for his capacity, for his human capital. That is precisely why we are addressing the Government of Malawi and saying that the albinos will not be forgotten, nor left to a sad fate of death and are with us today.

name: Diane James
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, within the last few weeks the British press reported once more instances where religious superstition and witchcraft have had a devastating impact on albinos’ lives in Malawi. Now quite clearly overseas aid, even that given on a conditional basis, is shown not to be effective in dealing with the education, employment and income issues that might, if improved, deal with the awful prosecution and persecution of defenceless albinos. Now the European Union should look to itself and end its punitive trade barriers against African agricultural products, those trade barriers that block much needed national economic development. Only via national economic development do properly funded health and education policies that will lessen the superstition and witchcraft practices have any chance of improving African societies for all citizens, not just albinos. The Commonwealth of Nations will undoubtedly take the necessary lead from now on in this matter, but I urge the European Union to look at its African trade practices, which are not helping the plight of albinos or the African poor and thus the African continent's future.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – As I look at the fetus of this consensus, it is doing me badly: it calls, regrets, welcomes, believes – this is your 'shit'. If we want to do something, let's do something concrete. When the Americans were in trouble, because the liberated African-Americans could not cope, they bought them a piece of land in Africa and created a state of Liberia, where later these African-Americans took for the murders of African-Americans. Maybe let's buy a piece of Africa – after all, African governments ensure that they will help, they will give a piece of land. Let's make a state for albino, let's add some money. It would be something concrete, because what we are talking about here is simply worshipful talk that will not help anyone at all. I ask: why can't you make a state for albino people in Africa?  More besides, I think that the European Union should be destroyed.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Madam High Representative, i would like to thank you for your excellent work Albinism is 10-15 times more common in the Southeast African region than anywhere in the world. Those affected by this disease live in constant fear of attacks, mutilation or even rape, which according to their beliefs would cure AIDS. Children for safety are placed in special centers, but after they have become of majority, the problem of life-threatening returns. According to the UN, there have been around 70 attacks on people with vitiligo in Malawi since the end of 2014, of which there are around 10 000 in the country. This indicates a growing and real threat to the lives of this part of the population. National authorities must be more committed to protecting this vulnerable group, and to emphasise educating citizens and promoting the rights of people with albinism. It is important that the Union, its Member States, in cooperation with south-east African countries, monitor the situation and provide all possible assistance, from the exchange of good practices to technical support, in order to stop these barbaric acts of violence.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in Malawi people with albinism are killed and mutilated and their body parts sold for use in ritual practices. Amnesty International also denounces the massacres of albinos in Africa, where albinos are killed and torn to pieces to manufacture talismans used in traditional medicine. Last April, according to NGO reports, was the bloodiest month, killing at least eighteen people.  The Humanitarian Organization, in its Report We are not animals to be hunted or sold, claims that since 2014 cases of abduction and murder have increased, forcing albinos to live constantly in terror. The European Union and the international community must take all possible action to force the Government of the Republic of Malawi and the other African republics to guarantee effective protection for albinos and to guarantee their rights to life and personal security.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, Africa is one of the continents where some of the most extreme forms of racism and human rights violations occur. One such case is the persecution of people with affism in various African countries, notably Malawi. As you know very well, these unfortunate people are abused, attacked, socially excluded, mutilated, raped, prejudiced and murdered.  Because I am opposed to any discrimination based on race, gender, colour and specificities, I strongly condemn this racist behaviour of African governments and, above all, of the Government of Malawi towards people with affism. It is not acceptable for African governments, which complain about racism against Africans, to behave in a way that refuses others to behave. Furthermore, I am concerned that among the hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants who have flooded Greece and Italy, there are people with such extreme and dangerous tendencies.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the NI Member Korwin-Mikke made a rather bizarre suggestion: he said the European Union should be destroyed and yet at the same time the Union he wants to destroy should buy a piece of land and create a state for albinos. My God, such logic! I have a different proposition: when you look at the problem here, it is based mainly on superstition. So if you get rid of the superstition you will be able to solve the problem. Could we not in conjunction with United Nations organize major educational conferences in Malawi where we will be able to highlight to the people that their superstitions are groundless, baseless, and show them that albinos are the exact same as everyone else. And if that idea prevailed in these countries, I think that would be one way of ending this unfortunate situation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, I support the joint resolution which I too have co-signed. Discrimination against people suffering from leukopathy and violation of their rights is a frequent occurrence in many African countries, notably Malawi, which is one of the poorest and least developed countries in the world, with 50.7% of the population living below the poverty line. According to Malawi police, at least 65 incidents of violence against people suffering from leukopathy were recorded in 2014, of which 18 people were killed, while incidents of illegal trade in bones and body parts of these individuals are very common.  In the face of the ever-increasing repression of human rights in Malawi, the European Union should take immediate measures to protect people suffering from leukopathy and to condemn the murders and exploitation of these people. In addition, it should support equal access for these people to health care, education, and social and legal protection.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I share the surprise of our colleague any time that we hear people saying what the European Union should or should not do and then saying that it should not exist. I see that contradiction and actually see the contradiction of their sitting in this Hemicycle – that is probably the first contradiction they are living.  Anyway, I would like to thank you for this unanimous work on a very important issue. Over the past two years, Malawi has faced a very worrying increase in human rights abuses against people with albinism, including children. These abuses include violent attacks, as you have all described, abductions and killings. Such violence exposes very deep-rooted problems of discrimination against people with albinism across many parts of sub-Saharan Africa, not only in Malawi, but also in Tanzania, Mozambique, Burundi and other countries. On 13 June we marked International Albinism Awareness Day, which was proclaimed by the UN General Assembly. That was an important step to raise awareness, together with the recent appointment of the first-ever UN independent expert on the enjoyment of human rights by persons with albinism. We support this kind of global awareness steps, we actively support them and look forward to working together with the United Nations in this educational and awareness-raising campaign, not only Malawi but also in other countries.  In line with these international commitments we need to take all possible measures to provide greater protection to persons with albinism at risk and to investigate crimes committed on that basis. The prejudice at the root of these discriminations needs to be addressed and confronted very openly, so we constantly urge the governments of the countries where these attacks take place to raise awareness throughout society regarding persons with albinism, including at the family level, and to enforce respect for their rights and dignity.  Comprehensive strategies to eradicate discriminatory practices against persons with albinism are needed, including to ensure that they have adequate access to health care, social services, employment and education. This issue does not only relate to Malawi, as I said, but to many parts of Africa. It is then important that countries also share best practices in protecting and promoting the rights of persons with albinism and work together for the prevention of cross-border crimes related to this issue. The European Union, through our delegation, is working and will continue to engage with governments and with the civil-society actors in these countries. Some people believe that there is not much we can do to change social behaviour, prejudice, superstitions. I do not agree. Norms and attitudes can evolve if we embrace a cooperative approach to our partners, if we work together with them and try to change on a daily basis the roots of a behaviour that can and must be changed.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. Albinism is a congenital disease that affects about one in 20 thousand people worldwide, but whose incidence rate is particularly high in sub-Saharan countries. Subjected to discrimination, aggression and continuous forms of persecution, albinos are generally excluded from the social team, due to beliefs and superstitions. Despite the international importance of the issue and the adoption of a number of laws in some of the countries concerned, killings, abductions and other forms of human rights violations do not seem to cease. The European Union should engage not only in further awareness-raising campaigns, but in ensuring active support for civil society and local authorities to combat such persecution.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – In the countries of sub-Saharan Africa, we can see the most extreme forms of persecution, human rights violations against people with albinism. They face social discrimination, verbal attacks, exclusion from public services. They are at risk of death, kidnapping, rape or mutilation. Discrimination can lead to lifelong traumas and psycho-social problems. People with albinism usually do not have sufficient health care or the right to education. Despite the international mediaisation of this problem and the adoption of new legislation, there are still very few people prosecuted and convicted and there are still criminal offences and torture. The greatest threat to people with albinism in Africa is widespread superstition about the special, magical abilities of their bodies that bring happiness, wealth, and health. This leads smugglers to hunt for albinos and then trade in their bodies. In 2015, there were 448 attacks on albinos in 25 African countries, and this is probably even lower than in reality, as the authorities do not systematically monitor and document such crimes. It should be remembered that people with albinism have the right to live like anyone else without fear, as the 1948 Declaration of Human Rights states.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – Today we voted on a draft resolution on the alarming treatment of albinos on the African continent, particularly in Malawi. This minority is constantly discriminated against, e.g. by exclusion from anti-poverty rescue programmes, it is under attack and its fundamental human rights are permanently violated. Physical attacks and violent crimes often ending in loss of life are no exception, and the perpetrators of these flows are usually not detected. I am of the opinion that it is our immanent duty to protect human rights. I supported the joint draft resolution.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. – It was only february ago that we denounced the human rights situation in Bahrain. Then we called for an end to the torture of Mohammed Ramadan and other political prisoners. What has changed? The Bahrain Ombudsman's report is clear. These inhumane practices continue undisturbed. Meanwhile, prominent human rights activist Nabeel Rajab was arrested again. His crime? A few critical tweets. What does the government in Bahrain have to hide, I wonder. Does she fear that he would attend a meeting of the UN Human Rights Council in Génève and embarrass her there? Recently, another human rights activist, Zainab al-Khawaja, fled abroad, fearing that the same thing would happen to her. We can no longer be under the illusion that Bahrain is moving towards reform when opposition voices are ruthlessly silenced. The kingdom may be an important partner of the EU for energy and security, but we do not compromise on human rights? Not in my name! I therefore ask the High Representative and the Member States to continue to express their concerns about human rights violations, such as freedom of expression and freedom of association, both bilaterally and multilaterally. The ministerial meeting between the Union and the Gulf Arab Cooperation Council on 20 July provides an excellent opportunity to do so. And let us finally work on the creation of an EU-Bahrain working group on human rights.

name: Michel Reimon
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Twenty-one human rights organisations from Bahrain have asked the international community, the United Nations, the European Parliament, other organisations to shout out loud against human rights violations in their home country, and in this sense we should accept this closure. On 13 June, activists were arrested for wanting to travel to Geneva for the Meeting of the Human Rights Council. This does not only weaken human rights in Bahrain when something like this happens. If we overlook such a thing, it also weakens the United Nations and the human rights situation around the world, and we must not remain silent. Nabeel Rajab was arrested again after serving two years in prison and is now serving 13 years in prison. What? He called for human rights on Twitter. Sheikh Ali Salman is in prison for simply calling on his country's citizens to gather. Two years in prison, a few days ago extended to a total of nine years imprisonment without a fair trial. We cannot look the other way, we must not look away from it, and that is why we must accept this good closure. But Bahrain is also an important partner for the European Union – an economically important partner and military in the fight against Da'esh. Foreign policy is at odds with this, and we must be clear here: the role of the European Union has been clearly discussed in recent days and weeks. We must also make it clear that a sharp hard line on Bahrain must be taken by the Member States of the European Union, because they have these competences. Not only must we accept this good, but we must also go home and call on our governments to take tough and consistent action against the Bahraini Government if it violates human rights. Elie Wiesel, the Nobel laureate in human rights, died a few days ago. He said: "We always have to choose one side. Silence only helps the perpetrator, never the victim." In this sense, we should accept this good closure and not remain silent.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Bahrain, needless to turn around, has a significant geopolitical role: it is home to the US Fifth Naval Fleet but also to naval bases that are important to some European states, including the United Kingdom, which has privileged relations with the Monarchy of Al Khalifa, to which it sells arms.  We are here, for the third time in two years, to make resolutions on Bahrain, urgent resolutions which are unfortunately not followed up, probably because trade relations, the geopolitical role and bahrain's strategic role are more important than the continuing violations. Nabeel Rajab is back in prison and it is forbidden to disagree with the policy of the Al Khalifa monarchy. We must try to use this trade force to demand that at least fundamental human rights be respected. It is totally unacceptable that our resolutions should not be followed up.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: Author. – Madam President, Commissioner, I agree with what the speaker has said here, but I must add one thing. Bahrain committed to reforming the legal system in 2011. And we have little regard for his efforts to reform criminal laws or legal procedures in this area, which are moving in the right direction from my point of view and from the point of view of the PPE.  This state must be seen as an isolated case of a stable country, given the area where it is located and the composition of the population on its territory. I personally appreciate Bahrain's participation in the international coalition against the Islamic State or its cooperation in the fight against terrorism.  I believe that the current situation in Bahrain is not ideal, and I am in a position for the European Union to appeal as actively as possible to respect for human rights in that country. However, I appreciate all the positive changes that this country has made over the last few years. And let us try to bring it from Europe to the so-called imaginary hand for Bahrain to proceed with its reforms.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, exactly one year has passed since the last European Parliament resolution on the case of Nabeel Rajab, and we are still in agreement. This case, like the others, is part of a more general repression of civil society and political and religious opposition, and testifies to the sensitive political situation, especially in the wider context of relations between Iran and Saudi Arabia.  The Shiite opposition group al-Wefaq has been banned and its political leader, Shiite Sheikh Ali Salman, sentenced to nine years and Ayatollah Sheikh Issa Qassim has been stripped of his citizenship on charges of serving foreign interests and promoting sectarianism and violence.  As we know, there are deep divisions in Bahrain between the Shiite-majority population and the Sunni elite, and Saudi Arabia's financial and military dependence severely limits the country's action. So let us try with this resolution to call on the government to reverse course, and I also think that we need to engage in a tough confrontation with some Gulf countries.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: author. –  Madam President, I wish to thank the High Representative for participating in the human rights debate. Unfortunately, we today again have to raise the human rights violations in Bahrain that are ongoing. It is our fourth resolution in the last couple of years, and even though concrete proposals have been made to stop the tensions and the violence and the repression in the country, very little result has been booked. I think it is now time to really take new initiatives, as the EU. We’ve seen the US Vice—President come out strongly and we’ve seen major newspapers write op eds, so the whole idea that the EU is oversensitive and is alone in this is not true.  I think it is important – and on this I would be very interested to hear your thoughts – to see what we can do at this point before it further escalates. Quite frankly, the ongoing repression and stripping of citizenship, with high prison sentences for simply having an expression online are unacceptable. They happen in a region that cannot afford more tension and destabilisation.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Madam President, since our last resolution, the repression in Bahrain seems to be intensifying. Death sentences have resumed. Arrests, torture and simulacrums of justice are the daily lot of opponents and human rights activists. Others are prevented from travelling to testify in Geneva. In 2015, more than 230 people were denied their nationality. So, yes, we must call for the immediate release of all political prisoners and the abandonment of the charges against them - Nabeel Rajad is a symbol in this regard. The Bahraini authorities considered that our last resolution did not correspond to the position of the political forces with real influence, nor to that of the European Union. Such a statement is unacceptable. As a result, our resolve seems weak. It is based on the importance of economic and political partnership, including arms sales. And I pass on the effectiveness of the fight against terrorism, especially against the group "Islamic State". Bahrain is on a bad slope. I do not believe that we can help those who are fighting for their freedom of expression by turning a blind eye to reality. We must reaffirm our support for Mohamed Ramadan and Ali Moosa, who are still at risk of imminent execution.

name: Jiří Pospíšil
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, On my group's part, I support the motion for this resolution. Unfortunately, we are dealing with Bahrain here repeatedly, as the authors of the motion for a resolution have said, the human rights situation is not improving.  We are dealing with the news at the moment, when Nabil Rajab was again charged, imprisoned in June, his health is deteriorating, and we all know that he was imprisoned only because he realized his fundamental right, the right to free speech. He expressed his thoughts and opinions on Twitter. For this reason, he is imprisoned.  I do not dispute the words of some colleagues that things are evolving in Bahrain and the situation may be improving, but the human rights situation in this country is certainly not improving. It is still the same, the opposition is closed, people who express their views are bullied, at best their citizenship is taken away. For your information, 300 Bahraini citizens have lost their citizenship in this country and have more or less become people without political affiliation. This resolution is needed and the High Commissioner needs to be active in this matter.

name: Richard Howitt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. –  Madam President, in 2012, together with fellow members of the Human Rights Subcommittee I visited Nabeel Rajab in Juw Prison, Bahrain, and today, four years later, he is rearrested and the Fédération Internationale des Droits de l’Homme tell us that he is in solitary confinement and his life is at risk.  This is just one case, but should be put together with the travel bans against those human rights defenders, preventing them going to the UN Human Rights Council in Geneva on the restoration of the death sentence and on the arrest of opposition politicians, all cited in our resolution. The truth is that four years later, human rights in Bahrain have deteriorated. We recognise there have been improvements on labour laws and on the freedom of religion, but there has been no improvement on human rights. We see that freedom of expression is violated, contrary to the country’s own constitution, and more than 300 people have been stripped of citizenship, contrary to the Universal Declaration on Human Rights. We want cooperation with Bahrain, but our resolution says that that cooporation cannot continue as normal unless we see the improvement of human rights. Human rights in this country must change. They have to listen, and we will never ever forget a human rights defender who is at risk, anywhere in the world.

name: Ivo Vajgl
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I am not sure that the Kingdom of Bahrain deserves to be after short time again a subject of an urgency resolution of the European Parliament. Recently, we were hosting in Brussels a conference on religious pluralism and tolerance in Bahrain, with the participation of the supreme religious leaders of the Shia, Protestant, Baha’i and Hindu communities. High representatives of the government also participated in the event. It sent a message to the region that Bahrain wants to be a leader on tolerance and coexistence – something that other neighbouring countries could not present. If Bahraini authorities violate the human rights of individuals, and they do it, it is their right to be protected and we should do it, but bearing in mind that this small Gulf country, situated in the sensitive region and subject to confrontations and pressures from abroad as well as of the sectarian battles for political prestige. We must be interested for a stable Bahrain as well as for a country with the respect of human rights and democratic values and proven readiness to cooperate with the European Parliament.

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the sectarian conflict in Bahrain stems from the confiscation of almost all levers of power by the Sunni Al Khalifa dynasty. Yet the majority in the archipelago, The Shiites are kept away from the decision-making centers by a clientelistic system built by the ruling family for more than two centuries. Saudi Arabia, which considers Bahrain to be its square meadow, ensures that the status quo is maintained. Riyadh fears that possible concessions from the caliphate will open a gap that would benefit Iran. Once again, the European Parliament will forget to put forward a number of principles which it keeps gargling. It is the government of Bahrain that must be sanctioned, of course, but above all Saudi Arabia, the country that applies, no more and no less, the program of the Islamic State.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: –  It has been said that Bahrain is a key partner for the European Union economically, and especially in the area of energy and in fighting ISIS, and that is to be welcomed. But having said that, in the area of human rights it is ranked actually 163rd out of 180 countries in the Reporters without Barriers index. That tells the story. Where we are concerned, the phrase in English ‘banging your head off a stone wall’ comes into being. We have mentioned this on numerous occasions but it has basically been ignored. So what do we do about it? I think the first author made a suggestion that we should have work group between the European Union and Bahrain, which would look at human rights and be able to discuss the cases of Nabeel Rajab,  Mohammed Ramadan and Sheikh Ali Salman, and the whole question of human rights, and especially freedom of speech and expression. That may be one way to make some progress.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: –  Madam President, this is not the first time I have stood in this Parliament to speak about the human rights abuses in Bahrain, and I am not happy with my own country’s record on the deals that it does with Kingdom of Bahrain. On 24 June, together with 49 fellow MEPs, I sent an open letter to Federica Mogherini on Nabeel Rajab’s re-arrest. I look forward to her reply and I thank my colleague Panzeri for his work on this. In the meantime, I am glad will be voting on this resolution and that we will come together to say clearly that Nabeel must be released immediately and unconditionally, with all other human rights defenders and political prisoners in Bahrain. The Bahraini Government must understand that allowing free, open and diverse democratic debate and a vibrant civil society will not make it weaker. Democracy and human rights will only make Bahrain stronger, with a brighter future for all Bahrainis. It is time for the Bahraini Government to hold up its own constitution and release Nabeel now.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: –  Madam President, I would say to the High Representative that Bahrain is a key partner of the European Union in the Persian Gulf, and we want to deepen our partnership in order to better respond to future challenges, but regrettably today, with the aggravating cases of breaches of human rights and the rule of law in Bahrain not much has changed in that country since my last visit. If, after two years of absence, being back to the European Parliament. In our resolution see familiar names of the persecuted human rights defenders – namely Nabeel Rajab, Zainab Al-Khawaja, who has been forced into exile. I still recall our visit as Members of the European Parliament to Juw Prison.  A big number of new cases of violations of human rights and of the Bahraini Constitution have taken place. I call on the Bahraini authorities to immediately release all prisoners of conscious and lift the travel ban against human rights defenders. I insist that the authorities guarantee that all human rights defenders in Bahrain are able to carry out their legitimate human rights activities without intimidation and harassment.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: –  With Richard Howitt and Laima Andrikienė I visited Nabeel Rajab, Mr Al-Khawaja and Ibrahim Sharif in prison in Bahrain some years ago. Ibrahim Sharif, I recall, is not even a Shia. He is a Sunni who dared to expose corruption in the regime and, since then, the situation has deteriorated and gravely in the last months, as our resolution documents. The regime in Bahrain is behaving in a totally pyrominous and suicidal way in a region that cannot afford more conflict. One should say that actually our policy regarding Bahrain has been set in the last year since the uprising into 2011 in London – and for reasons that have nothing to do with human rights, nor with Europe’s strategic interests. They have to do with the strategic interests of London in the trade of arms with the Saudi regime. We cannot afford this anymore. Miss Mogherini, stop appeasing the regime. Please use the next ministerial meeting of the EU GCC to actually send a very stern message to the Bahrainis and to their partners in the region.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, I support the joint resolution which I have co-signed. The human rights situation in Bahrain has not only not improved as promised by the Bahraini authorities since 2011, but in 2015 the country's courts issued seven death sentences, while the use of repressive measures by the authorities against activists and peaceful demonstrations has increased. In particular, the secretary general of the opposition party was sentenced to four years in prison for his participation in demonstrations in the context of the Arab Spring uprisings.  In the face of the violation of human rights in Bahrain, the European Union should take immediate measures to stop all illegal arrests of activists and demonstrators and any inhuman and degrading treatment of prisoners. Bahrain will finally have to comply with its obligations under the UN Convention against Torture and stop re-attacking the Daesh jihadists.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the third time that we have discussed the situation in Bahrain. The situation has not changed, the government's persecution of the Shiite community continues and at least 97 people have died as a result of torture and ill-treatment in prison since 2011. The decision of the Minister of Justice to suspend all activities of the Islamic company Al-Wefaq, the country's main opposition group, is also a cause for concern. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon has also recently expressed concern about the intimidation of activists, who peacefully defend and promote human rights, and those who legitimately want to exercise their rights of freedom of expression and association. If decisive and decisive action is not taken, there is a risk that a very dangerous fire could start from this small region of Bahrain, fuelled precisely by the repression of the Shiites.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Madam High Representative, my fellow Members have said that it would be good to see improvements; from a labour law point of view, not from a human rights point of view. What can we do? We're waiting for your answer.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, first of all let me say that this is not only an issue related to human rights. It is, and it is a fundamental one, but it is also, as many of you mentioned, an issue that risks fuelling tensions in a region that definitely does not need further tensions. So, it is a human rights issue, but it is also an extremely serious geopolitical concern.  What can we do? First of all, what we have done already, because I’ve heard in this Chamber today suggestions or proposals. Let me remind you all –maybe you know already, but still a reminder may be needed today – that our EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, visited Bahrain for the second time last year and had a comprehensive visit that allowed frank discussions on all issues and, in the follow-up of that visit, we established an EU—Bahrain Human Rights working group, that met for the first time this year, in April. So that kind of working relation on these issues, including all difficult issues we have on the table, is ongoing. If I have to assess whether that has brought results today, I have to say, obviously, that we are facing extremely difficult situations, but the suggestion of establishing a working group on these issues with them and having our human rights representative working and visiting the country constantly is there, as well as when it comes to statements and declarations – the last one I think we released just yesterday – to highlight our preoccupation and concern at the deterioration of the human rights situation in the country. So we are constantly working on this.  Many worrying pieces of news have come out of Bahrain recently, and you mentioned them all. Let me stress that this includes the ongoing judicial proceedings on the suspension of Al-Wefaq, the sentence against the Secretary—General, Ali Salman, as well as the re-arrest of Nabeel Rajab and measures preventing activists from travelling abroad. As I said, all this is worrying in itself, but it will also hamper national reconciliation in the Kingdom and will have a spillover effect in the whole region that is extremely relevant. So we expect these decisions to be reconsidered in a fair and transparent manner in full respect of Bahrain’s international obligations and its own internal constitution. We will continue to liaise closely with all EU Member States that are present in Manama to attend trials of prominent activists and advocate transparent judicial proceedings. On a number of occasions, such as during the visit of Stavros Lambrinidis, we have called for the release of those arrested in the context of peaceful political activities and we are constantly doing that. We know very well that speaking up on this is important from the EU side as such.  This is crucial, not only on the issue of human rights in itself, but it is also crucial – as was mentioned in one of the last interventions – to overcome the deep polarisation of the country itself. So, it would be beneficial for Bahrain itself, for its stability and its internal healthy societal development, to go in that direction. The EU, both in Brussels and through our delegation, will keep working to protect and promote human rights and fundamental freedoms. This is consistent with Bahrain’s international commitment, but also with the recommendation set out by the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry and the recommendations made during Bahrain’s Universal Periodic Review process. It is first and foremost, as I said, in Bahrain’s national interest to facilitate and support national reconciliation through a peaceful, inclusive reform process, as was mentioned, and as there were commitments during 2011. It is – and I would like to stress this – in regional and global, including European, interests to avoid new tensions arising in a region of the world that cannot afford further tensions. On the contrary, the region needs reconciliation and de-escalation of political confrontation and this is exactly the work that we doing on a daily basis, both speaking up and engaging quietly not only to promote human rights in the country, but also to avoid further tension in the region.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. – The human rights situation in Bahrain is getting worse by the day. Last month, activist Nabeel Rajab was arrested again. He was accused of "spreading rumors in wartime" and "insulting the authorities" only for some Twitter postings and both charges bring 13 years in prison. The recent arrest is part of a string of abuses against political dissidents, human rights activists and the opposition in general. Also in June, the Bahraini government prevented a delegation of activists from traveling to the Geneva Human Rights Council for session No. 32. Only 2 days after this event, the authorities suspended the activity of the largest opposition party, Al-Wefaq. Sheikh Ali Salman, the group's president, was arrested (July 2015). Together with other MEPs I signed a letter on 21 June to Mrs Mogherini for the release of Nabeel Rajab. A joint action is important. I demand that the Bahraini authorities release from prison activists, human rights defenders, lift travel bans and stop using the withdrawal of citizenship as a form of intimidation of the opposition or punishment!

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. – It is a remarkable situation: Nobel Laureate and one of the heroes of our era, Aung San Suu Kyi, wins back democracy for her country Myanmar in 2011, but also inherits the concentration camps of her predecessors and a ethnically cleansing population that the world probably hears little or nothing about: the Rohingya. This Muslim minority has been stateless since 1982, the beginning of myanmar's military dictatorship. Many have fled to neighbouring countries, but they are not welcome there either. It is about people being mistreated, not having access to health care and food. All this is done intentionally and continuously. It is a violation of human rights and so it is our business. We must urge the government in Myanmar to stop sticking to its own version of apartheid. The EEAS must continue to raise the situation of the Rohingya at the highest possible political level with Myanmar and other ASEAN countries. In addition, the EU should provide continued support to the UN Refugee Agency to support the situation of refugees in the region.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: Author. – Mr President, one of the best news in international politics in recent years has been that Myanmar has gone from military power to civilian power. However, even if the reforms take time, the European Parliament would require the Government of Myanmar to take seriously the recent UN Special Rapporteur's report on the plight of Rohingya Muslims and other minorities in Myanmar. All kinds of discriminatory laws should be abolished. It has also been good to see that even Aung San Suu Kyi herself is now finally interested in the status of the Rohingya population. I'm sure there's a chance to move forward. This question, if anything, hinders the development of Myanmar.  Finally, I would like to remind you that all western countries, including China, are very interested in doing business with Myanmar. Care must be taken to ensure that the Government of Myanmar also promotes the transparent and responsible use of natural resources and administrative transparency in general.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, here too we find ourselves debating again from the Rohingya minority a year later: we adopted a resolution on this subject on 21 May last year. Unfortunately, the conditions of the Rohingya people have not changed.  The Role of the European Union could certainly be more incisive in the dialogue with Myanmar but also with neighbouring countries, which reject refugees when there are arrests on the other side. The Rohingya are people exposed to human trafficking. DG ECHO has done a good job providing humanitarian aid worth EUR 70 million since 2010. We should put pressure on the new government to try to change the pace with this minority and finally protect this landless and peaceless people.

name: Tunne Kelam
text: author. – Madam President, may I just say how much your presence in human rights debates is welcome, Madam High Representative, because this is confirmation that we take human rights issues seriously. The Rohingya minority is a special case for me, whose fate has not been fully understood or recognised. They have for long years not just been discriminated against, but have faced an existential danger. It is ominous and unacceptable that the whole ethnic group is not officially recognised in the country where a majority of them is living. They are not recognised as citizens of Myanmar and are treated as not wanted. The new government in Myanmar has decided to make national reconciliation their priority and therefore we call on them to provide the Rohingya people with safety against any form of discrimination, to end impunity and to grant the Rohingyas citizenship.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Author. Mr President, the situation seems to me to be quite clear and obvious. There's no point going back on it. This situation must be put in place here, but there is not only the problem of the Rohingya, who live in very poor conditions and many flee to the borders of Bangladesh, there are other problems that we also have to face. I had the opportunity to visit some camps on the border between Thailand and Myanmar and we also have them open problems.  I think we need to do a couple of things. First of all, to urge the current Government of Myanmar, which is in a phase of democratic transition, to say that the current situation of the Rohingya in the apartheid situation is unacceptable and the second thing, I wonder and wonder whether it is possible for the European Union to take action to implement a new memorandum between Myanmar and Thailand in order to resolve also the problem of so many camps in Thailand of Burmese population that must return to the country.

name: Urmas Paet
text: author. – Madam President, the Rohingyas have for decades suffered brutal oppression and discrimination. People have been fleeing Myanmar, often perishing on the way, children and mothers dying because of lack of access to hospitals; children not registered upon birth have not been able to go to school and people have not been allowed to move freely. This needs to stop. For the first time in 50 years, Myanmar has experienced a peaceful transfer of power to their first non-military president since 1962. It is a new possibility. Myanmar must seize it. The government must make an effort. Fighting has to cease and disputes need to be resolved through negotiation. The Rohingya minority must be given citizenship and the discriminatory local orders in Rakhine State must be abolished. And the European Union must help and persuade the Myanmar Government to work on this matter, be it bilaterally through projects and agreements or through ASEAN.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Madam President, once again we are talking about the Rohingya, one of the most persecuted minorities in the world: one million people deprived of nationality, driven out of all over the region, including Australia. "Rohingyas," a word that should not be uttered in Burma - even Aung San Suu Kyi recently reminded ambassadors and UN officials not to use it. We can welcome the victory of the National League for Democracy, but we know that everything is fragile. Eight months after the elections, the repression is still there. That's right, the challenge is immense. The entire discriminatory legal architecture, based on religion and ethnicity, needs to be revised, including the 1982 Citizenship Act and the four so-called race and religion protection laws of September 2015. The news is marked by a new outbreak of violence disturbing, Islamophobic and fuelled by a radical Buddhism that throws oil on the fire. Two mosques have just been destroyed in one week, in the north and centre of the country. Let us hope that the symbolic Panglong conference, if it is truly inclusive, will help to pacify the country beyond the urgent issue of the Rohingya.

name: Pavel Svoboda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, High Representative, since there is a government in Myanmar, headed by sakharov prize winner, it is as if we have a check mark in our heads that we have worked.  Unfortunately, the situation of the Rohingya has not changed much. On the contrary, rather it is getting worse, we know that they are denied citizenship, their genocide by Buddhists is tolerated, so they are at risk of death. Survivors are prohibited from having more than two children so that this ethnicity cannot grow. Hundreds of thousands had to flee Myanmar.  European policy must make it clear that such treatment of ethnicity is unacceptable. We must not promote and tolerate genocide, we must not tolerate human trafficking.

name: Ana Gomes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, I too greet Mrs Mogherini for being here today in this urgent debate on human rights. The new civilian government in Myanmar, which is the result of democratic elections to which I have had the privilege of observing as a member of the delegation of this Parliament, if it really wants to give credibility to the construction of democracy in the country has to give priority to an action plan to combat discrimination against the Rohingya and other ethnic and religious minorities. This is essential for there to be a genuine process of national reconciliation and this plan has to include the criminal accountability of all leaders of nationalist Buddhist forces spreading hatred and xenophobia. The Sakharov Prize, Aung San Suu Kyi, has special responsibilities as a member of this government and as a figure of democracy and respect for human rights, not only in the country but also in the world. It must therefore speak clearly publicly for the protection of the Rohingya and must facilitate access for international organisations to Rakhine State and must propose the legislative reforms that are necessary. And we, the European Union, must not only put pressure on the Government of Burma, but to put pressure on the governments of other countries that have problems with the Rohingya, who cannot continue to respect the principle of non-refoulement.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, I support the joint resolution which I have co-signed with my other colleagues. Human rights violations in Myanmar are common, with persecution and violence against the Rohingya minority constantly intensifying. The destruction of The Rohingya's property and places of worship, mass arrests, arbitrary imprisonment and restrictions on free movement characterise the behaviour of the Myanmar authorities towards this minority.  More than 130,000 displaced Rohingya remain in camps in other areas, while Myanmar authorities have made humanitarian aid access to the areas inadequate. At the same time, an estimated 10,000 Rohingya have fled by sea to escape persecution and 1,700 are being held in appalling conditions in refugee detention centres.  It is therefore necessary for the Myanmar authorities to allow humanitarian aid to enter all parts of the country and for the European Union to act immediately to support the rights of the Rohingya.

name: António Marinho e Pinto
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Madam High Representative, the tragedy of Rohingya refugees in Myanmar reaches such dimensions that it appeals to us all, in the depths of our ethical and political conscience. This Muslim minority is discriminated against and persecuted by the Burmese authorities who do not recognise them as nationalcitizens, forcing many of its members to leave the country in conditions of great precariousness. Men, women and children often end up falling into the meshes of dark human trafficking networks that beat them and abandon them on the high seas without food and water, or else, simply the murderers. At a time when the winds of Islamophobia are blowing more and more intensely in Europe, it was good for the European Union authorities to take concrete steps to convince the Myanmar government that there are more advantages to respecting the rights of the Rohingya minority than in violating those rights.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, just over a year ago you were already being addressed in this Chamber about the plight of the Rohingya in South-East Asia, and in particular in Burma. It is our duty to continue to denounce this ordeal endured by some one million Rohingya, of whom nearly 100,000 are parked in IDP camps. A UN representative was in Burma recently, and she did not see any progress under the new pro-democracy government that now runs Burma. The United Nations has also published a report highly critical of Burma, which recounts various persecutions against the Rohingya. It is high time that the countries of Southeast Asia unite in order to improve the living conditions of this ethnic group and finally to recognize it a true status. Burma still does not recognize their nationality, so they do not have citizenship. Finally, it is our duty to put pressure on the Burmese government to ensure that their rights are respected. I also support Mr Panzeri's initiative to draft a memorandum on the issue of IDPs between Thailand and Burma.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I signed up to catch the eye because I spoke on this subject here last time, when we criticised the situation with this minority of Rohingya a few months ago. And unfortunately, the situation has not improved at all. I am therefore continuing with colleagues who have detailed how the Rohingya do not have citizenship, are interned in camps, do not receive medical care.  Sadly, what has also been said here is that there has been a transition to democratic rule in Burma, that the Sakharov Prize winner is effectively responsible for this current government, but the situation of this Muslim minority is not improving. This is all the su sturgeon and I therefore think it is appropriate to adopt a resolution again and again to call on the democratic government in Burma, together with Mrs Suu Kyi, to really address the situation. There is no other way to talk about democracy in this country.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: –  Madam President, we have welcomed several times the transformation that has been taking place in Myanmar. I hope this change will improve the situation of all citizens of this country. In this way we have to look also on the situation of minorities. The persecution of the Rohingya people has a long history in Myanmar. Over past years, we have seen waves of refugees and internally displaced people from the Rohingya community as well as numerous persecutions, violations of their rights and discrimination. This minority is seen as one of the most persecuted minorities of the whole world. The Myanmar Government needs to respect the rights of the people belonging to this minority. This also applies to other countries of the region. The neighbouring countries in the region with large numbers of Rohingya refugees need to guarantee their protection.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I notice that all of you who took the floor in this debate know very well that the European Union plays a special role when it comes to Myanmar. First of all, because we are international observers of national ceasefire agreements. This gives us a special responsibility and a special role to play that includes many different issues. As you mentioned, we have an historic opportunity with the new government and we do work with them in many different fields, from poverty reduction to migration to, obviously, the situation of the Rohingya minority. I will meet the President of Myanmar as well as other leaders of the region next week at the ASEM Summit, so this will again be part of our commitment and engagement with them.  The situation in the Rakhine State where the Rohingya reside has dominated our political dialogue with Myanmar, including my meeting with the former Foreign Minister last year. On the occasion of the EU-Myanmar Human Rights Dialogue, our EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, who is here with us today, visited Rakhine State to assess the situation and to advocate measures to improve human rights. As you know, we have also tabled a number of resolutions on the human rights situation in Myanmar in the UN General Assembly and in the UN Human Rights Council, with a strong focus on that.  I would like to thank colleagues who mentioned the fact that the European Union has been not only a key political interlocutor on this issue, but also a key donor of humanitarian assistance for the Rohingya. In 2016 more than EUR 7 million, which means 68% of our Myanmar humanitarian envelope, is dedicated to the Rakhine State. We are working on development cooperation activities benefiting Rohingya communities, providing support especially to education assistance for children, but also poverty eradication in that part of the country.  The Government of Myanmar is well aware of the gravity of the situation and we will make sure that they stay committed to their intention to improve the situation there. Aung San Suu Kyi is taking steps to find durable solutions for both communities. She is leading a committee which aims to bring peace, stability and development to the area. A citizenship verification process started in early June to address the statelessness of Rohingya and other minorities, but obviously this work needs time, and especially this work needs our continuous support. We are intensifying our engagement with Myanmar to solve this situation in accordance with the strategy and the joint communication that we adopted at the beginning of June, and the Council conclusions that the Foreign Ministers adopted just a few weeks ago. We are encouraging the Government to launch a credible action plan to abolish all discrimination and displacement and to move towards truly inclusive development. There will be no real and stable peace in Myanmar without true reconciliation in the country.  I shall finish by saying that this process of reconciliation and peace is an historic one in Myanmar and has to include all ethnic and religious groups, and the European Union is working for that.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, July 7, 2016. (Debate suspended)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen! (Members of the GUE/NGL Group hold up signs in various languages.) You can sit down again. We have seen your signs, the photos are also taken. Ladies and gentlemen! After hearing Mr Korwin-Mikke and under Rule 166 of the Rules of Procedure, I decided to impose a sanction on this Member for his unacceptable remarks on African migrants during the sitting of 7 June. (Applause) As a result of this sanction, Mr Korwin-Mikke loses his entitlement to daily allowances for a period of ten days and is suspended from all activities of Parliament and its institutions for a period of five days. The penalty will apply from 12 September. My decision was taken yesterday by Mr Korwin-Mikke. At the same time, I have been told again today from the plenary session that Mr Korwin-Mikke has again made statements this morning in the speech he has given here, which I will review and which, if they are again racist to me, will lead to similar sanctions. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.)

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, thank you for your fairness, thank you for giving me the floor for a minute on the basis of Article 166 of our regulation, which you invoked earlier against one of our colleagues, whose words I do not necessarily share and who is not at all the same political party as me.  I would just like to point out to you, Mr President, that Article 166 gives you the right to sanction a Member who seriously disrupts the sitting, that is, for example, who prevents his colleagues from speaking, who gesticulates and who, despite reminders to order, persists in disruptive behaviour - this happened to me, for example, once in this Parliament - but in this case, in this case, , this article does not give you any right to censor the words of an MP, would they be outrageous, would they be indecent. If you put yourself on that, there will be a lot of work. And when I am President of Parliament, perhaps I will find the words of this or that of my colleagues indecent. I do not think it is a respect for the freedom that parliamentarians should retain to punish, as you now do on a regular basis, Members of Parliament simply for what they say.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Now take a look, Mr Gollnisch! Mr Korwin-Mikke said in the last sitting here in this House that the refugees who came here were the scounduation that Africa is pouring over Europe. That is the reason for the sanction, and I maintain that it is justified. (Loud applause)

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: –Madam President, I welcome Parliament's demand for a political solution to the conflict in Western Sahara and to ask the international community for humanitarian, financial and political assistance for crises of this magnitude. It lacked, and that is why I abstained, to realize the responsibilities of the European Union. Mrs Mogherini must be involved in maintaining humanitarian aid to refugee camps and for the mandate of the Security Council to be fulfilled.  Morocco must be obliged to fully restore MINURSO to return civilian observers and to hold the referendum at once.  I greet the Saharawi people, their courage and tenacity during the exile and colonial domination of Spain and Morocco. From this Parliament, which has condemned the brutal Moroccan occupation on numerous occasions, I would like to send you a fraternal greeting, an affectionate greeting which I would like to extend to the Delegates of the Polisario in the work of their congress. A united people can face any adversity.  All our solidarity with the Saharawi people's struggle for their rights and freedom.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Madam President, please stop the clock, and it would be a procedural request to kindly call on our fellow Members to come out here, because speeches cannot be made in such confusion and cacophony. We're insulting our constituents. So I ask you nicely to call on them to go outside, and when there are normal, parliamentary-like conditions, let us speak up if possible.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo agus le mo ghrúpa, agus glacadh leis le móramh mór – ní nach ionadh. The recommendations made throughout this report are welcome. I support the calls on the Council in the areas of peace and security, the fight against terrorism, migration and the various other areas covered throughout the report. The continued cooperation between the EU – including the Parliament – and the UN is a great example of the EU’s commitment to multilateralism. I hope our institutions will continue to work together in such a positive way. I support the work of the UN, especially in the areas of peace and security and human rights, and I hope they will welcome the recommendations of this report. I hope to see the work that the UN does – especially in finding lasting and peaceful solutions to ongoing conflicts, as well as strengthening peacekeeping operations – continue and improve following the discussions and the debate at the 71st Annual General Assembly.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Dear Madam President, honourable Members, my colleague Kovachev's report contains quite positive elements, but I nevertheless voted against it because it contains paragraphs that are unacceptable to me and my political group and cannot be supported. In particular, I believe that calls such as this to repeal the legislation of UN Member States, which violates the rights of so-called LGBT people and societies, violates the sovereignty of states.  I oppose the long-term objective set out in the report for the European Union's membership of the UN Security Council. The European Union is not a state and is not a federal state. I do not believe that we should go in this direction and there should be no more European Union at the expense of national sovereignty.  We are witnessing a divided Europe which, if it remains in its current form, could not represent itself and equally protect the interests of all Member States. I believe that such a step would lead to a greater division of the Union and create potential tensions between Member States.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have supported this report for many reasons, although, of course, I agree with my previous speaker that in some parts this report was a bit activist.  However, the UN is an organisation that needs our support, its place in world affairs is completely irreplaceable. This shows the whole, in fact, more than seventy years of post-World War II developments, although there are, of course, national or local conflicts, the world's risk of disaster has been significantly eliminated thanks to UN action. I think that we need to support its efforts, which, as has been said many times here, should be directed towards the prevention of disputes, their active amicable resolution.  And the second area where the UN should certainly be involved and where it should have our support is the protection of human rights, the Charter of Human Rights, which contains a certain necessary minimum. I, too, reject the pro-activist expansion to other rights. But this necessary minimum should indeed be respected. And it will be a challenge for the new decade as this adjustment can be enforced and coerced.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, yes, it is a good thing that we are approving the work that is being done under the presidency of Ambassador Espinosa, representative of the Ecuadorian State, in favour of a treaty that requires multinationals to respect social and environmental standards. This is an excellent thing, but we still need to work on this treaty until it is binding, not just indicative. And we would have to point the finger at the United States of America, which left the negotiating table and called into question the chairmanship of this working group. This is unacceptable, as is the fact that many of the European nations have withdrawn from this discussion. I call for us to go back and get it going. I would like to use this time to draw your attention to a point that generally does not mark anyone. And yet, take a good look. I believe that we are the world power most able to intervene to move towards an orderly world under the aegis of the United Nations in the areas essential for humanity in terms of the race that we see everywhere towards wealth and raw materials. I conclude: it is time for the European Union to vote for the great deep sea spaces to be placed under the international competence of the United Nations and for the same to happen with satellites and extraplanetary exploitation, since, as you know, the United States of America now recognises the right to take over the Moon's spaces privately.
