I would like to think about it and that the European Union is committed to the universal rights of humanity in the future.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: Madam President, perhaps there was a misunderstanding. I made an earlier point of order asking you to please call on the noisy Members who had nothing to do in this Chamber to leave the room so that we can speak decently. Then you took the floor away from me and didn't give it back so that I could make my explanation of vote. So please allow me to make my explanation of vote, as I was assigned to do.  Madam President, the biggest positive of this report was the very promising fact that at the 71st session of the United Nations in September it looks like there will be a paradigm shift on migration. At least that's what the migration section on page 11 (ab) foresees. It says that it calls on the Bodies of the European Union to support "the high-level plenary session of the UN General Assembly scheduled for 19 September 2016 on the issue of significant migration of refugees and migrants", "and calls for the meeting to address the root causes of migration, with a particular focus on poverty eradication, human rights enforcement and stability". So they finally seem to be starting to deal with the roots, not just the consequences and the wide opening of European doors to migrants.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In a 2011 resolution, the UN General Assembly gave the EU the power to speak on behalf of its states, although it could not be a member of the Organisation. The report, containing the recommendations that Parliament wishes to present to the next General Assembly, addresses many important issues: from general disarmament, to the need to counter terrorist propaganda, to the issue of human rights and the possibility of preparing humanitarian action in Yemen. Preparing shared strategies and policies, but above all supported by the entire international community, is of fundamental importance for the achievement of the main European objectives. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The United Nations is an organisation for independent and sovereign states, with very few exceptions. We do not believe that the EU should have a place in the General Assembly. Various parts of the resolution were of concern, in particular calls for the two EU Member States with permanent seats on the UN Security Council to represent the EU in this capacity.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While Member States are urged to support the UN resolution "Effects of the Use of Weapons and Ammunition Containing Depleted Uranium" and advocates greater efforts to protect the rights of religious and other minorities, it has interventionist and interferenceting approaches to the Crimean conflict, nor is it emphasized the need to rethink the current functioning of the UN Security Council , so I abstained.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which sets out the EU's objectives for the next session of the UN General Assembly. This text hints at the EU's aim to satellite the French seat on the Security Council. So I strongly opposed it.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with Parliament’s recommendation on the agenda for the upcoming 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. The report has a number of positive aspects on matters of human rights, democracy, rule of law and the proliferation of weapons.  However there are a number of negative aspects as well, related to the common foreign and security policy (CFSP) of the European Union, to EU battlegroups, and to the proposal for the EU to have its own seat on the UN Security Council. I therefore abstained on the overall vote.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which echoes our concerns about the role of women in the peace process, the representation of women at all levels of decision-making processes, children's rights, the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons and global disarmament, zero tolerance for the death penalty, LGBTI rights. , respect for human rights at sporting events, an EU seat on the Security Council or support for the candidacy of a woman as the new Secretary-General.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report with a proposal for a European Parliament recommendation on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. I fully support EP recommendations that the Council will continue supporting multilateral attempts to find lasting political and peaceful solutions to ongoing conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa. We recommend the Council to reiterate its unequivocal condemnation of terrorism and its full support for actions aimed at the defeat and eradication of terrorist organisations, in particular, the so-called ‘ISIS/Daesh’, as well as to promote respect for human rights, to protect the rights of religious and other minorities and to advocate freedom of religion or belief. We have to ensure that the EU remains at the forefront of the fight against climate change. We should support a comprehensive reform of the United Nations Security Council and promote a revitalisation of the work of the UN General Assembly.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. On the occasion of the 71st session of the UN General Assembly this year, Parliament adopted recommendations for them, which I also approved. The content is about peace and security, the fight against terrorism, non-proliferation and disarmament, migration, development, climate change and human rights, democracy and the rule of law. The reform of the United Nations system will also be discussed. The work of the EU institutions and those of the UN will be further strengthened.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because, here, the AIM of the EU is to delight or satelliteise the French seat on the UN Security Council.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU's commitment to effective multilateralism and good global governance, at the core of which would be the UN, is an integral part of the EU's external policy. I agree with the recommendations made to the Council to actively to ensure that all parties involved in directly or indirectly armed conflicts and their organisations fully comply with international obligations and international law and seek to find peaceful and diplomatic solutions to a wide range of conflicts, recall that they unequivocally condemn terrorism and fully support actions to defeat and eliminate terrorist organisations, in particular so-called ISIS(Daesh), to step up efforts to curb recruitment and combat terrorist propaganda on social media platforms , to support the UN's efforts to prevent, acquire or transmit weapons of mass destruction by non-state actors and terrorist groups, to promote greater support for unHCR's work in the implementation of its international mandate to protect refugees, with a particular focus on vulnerable groups such as women and children, as well as to take action to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals of 2030, etc.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which aims to prepare for the next session of the UN General Assembly. In addition to a lot of recommendations inspired more by the technocratic logic implemented in Brussels than by the demands of the international situation, this report seeks to subfer the French seat on the Security Council to the Brussels directives. In this respect, it is in perfect coherence with the attitude of the Commission, which seeks only to put under its control the prerogatives that still remain within the purview of the Member States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this report, which contains a recommendation to the Council at the 71st session of the UN General. This recommendation addresses Parliament's priorities in the areas of peace and security, counter-terrorism, non-proliferation and disarmament, migration, human rights, democracy and the rule of law and development.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In September, the Glass Palace will host the 70th session of the UN General Assembly. In a particularly difficult year at international level, the EU will be able to use this opportunity to bring its priorities to the centre of the world debate. The Kovatchev report, which I supported today, sets out the main guidelines for action that it should pursue on this occasion, touching on a number of key issues: peace and security, the fight against terrorism, non-proliferation and disarmament, migration, development, human rights and the rule of law. These are complex issues that require coherent action on a global scale; The EU therefore has the greatest interest in finding solutions to these problems in a context of multilateralism. Firstly, we need to relaunch the work of the UN, by improving the coordination and coherence of the work of all the UN institutions and, at the same time, by developing greater transparency in the selection process for the next Secretary-General, who will have to see the candidates submit their candidacy to the General Assembly. Europe must take responsibility for this process and be at the forefront of promoting a reform of the organisation with a seat on the Security Council.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from this vote as I advocate a multilateral approach to international relations, which favours dialogue and horizontal cooperation between States and actors in international relations, to the detriment of strategic-military solutions. I am in favour of a restructuring of the United Nations and its Security Council, but not in the sense of consolidating its character as an exclusive and exclusionary club dominated by economic and military powers, but instead promoting and effectively promoting and enabling an equitable system of representation and decision-making to move towards a new world order based on justice , democracy, respect for human rights, joint approach to great global ills, preservation of global public goods and peace.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. I will not use the word "thing" that General De Gaulle used to describe the United Nations and which so many Members of our Assembly claim.  This report calls for good measures in the field of international policy, although I fear that many of them, including the two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, will remain a dead letter. I also do not see how the conflict in Yemen can be resolved by advocating a rapprochement of all parties with Iran and Saudi Arabia. It's a bit naïve and falls under the squaring of the circle. But we can always hope. And I also welcome the call to abolish the offence of blasphemy in some Islamic countries, even if the rapporteur avoids clearly identifying which countries it is. Could it be to not offend some of our "allies" like Turkey?

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work in achieving this report on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. It discusses certain recommendations to the Council on peace and security, the fight against terrorism, the non-proliferation of arms and disarmament, migration, human rights, democracy and the rule of law, development, climate change, the Union and the reform of the United Nations system. I hope that the Council will be able to take into account Parliament's mostly voted claims.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the 71st session of the UN General Assembly looks at the EU's objectives for the next session of the Assembly. The AIM of the EU is to win over or satelliteise the French seat on the Security Council for its benefit. For that simple reason, I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite some interesting suggestions, the Kovatchev report contains several critical points for which I preferred to abstain.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've dropped my voice. In the run-up to the UN General Assembly sessions, the European Parliament makes its recommendations. There are many good wordings about acting for peaceful solutions in conflict countries, working preventively, emphasising the ROLE of the UN in global peace making, and more. But the resolution also calls for the EU to have a seat on the Security Council, mentions only Islamist terrorism, supports the EU's repressive refugee and migration policies by linking aid and external relations to closing borders, includes support for the EU's common foreign and security policy, and unclear sentences about "EU battle groups". Because of these positions, I am abstaining.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This report on Session 71 of the United Nations General Assembly constitutes the annual recommendation to the Council of the European Parliament prior to the meeting of this body. Multilateral attempts to find lasting and peaceful political solutions to conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa must continue to be supported; especially in Syria, Libya, Yemen, the Middle East Peace Process and Western Sahara, and to seek continued humanitarian, financial and political assistance from the international community to address the humanitarian situation and work for the immediate cessation of violence. It also promotes greater support for UNHCR's work to bridge the huge gap between its budgetary needs and the funding received, and greater global solidarity is needed. Further strengthening respect for human rights, democracy and the rule of law in the world, the fight against terrorism, non-proliferation and disarmament, and rapid implementation of the decisions taken at the 2015 Paris Climate Change Conference are other priority issues in this report that I supported with my vote.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the proposal for a European Parliament recommendation to the Council on the 71th session of the United Nations General Assembly. Parliament makes recommendations to the Council on peace and security, the fight against terrorism, non-proliferation and disarmament, migration, human rights, democracy and the rule of law, development, climate change and the reform of the EU-UN system. Parliament proposes to actively seek full compliance with international obligations and international law and to seek peaceful and diplomatic solutions to a wide range of conflicts, whether directly or indirectly, in armed conflicts. It also unequivocally condemns terrorism and fully supports actions to defeat and eliminate terrorist organisations, to step up efforts to curb recruitment and combat terrorist propaganda on social media platforms. Parliament recommends supporting the UN in its efforts to prevent non-state actors and terrorist groups from developing, producing, acquiring or transferring weapons of mass destruction and using them for their supply systems. Encourages greater support for unHCR's work in implementing its international mandate to protect refugees, paying particular attention to vulnerable groups such as women and children.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the European Parliament's recommendation to the Council on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly, which sets out the guidelines to be defended by the EU at the upcoming session. I particularly consider the issue of security in the world, and especially in the Middle East and Africa. The General Assembly should take binding measures to immediately end the violence and establish a transitional government in Syria, as agreed at the Vienna peace talks. With regard to the fight against climate change, I expect to strengthen the joint efforts of the EU and the UN to ensure the swift implementation of the conclusions of the Paris Climate Conference of late 2015.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, more than ever, it is important to ensure an active role for the Union on the international stage and, in particular, within the largest global cooperation forum, the United Nations. In line with this, just a few months after the opening of the 70th UN General Assembly, the European Parliament today approved its recommendations to the Council on the Union's priorities to be defined in view of the next session of this House. One of Parliament's priorities is, firstly, the commitment to maintaining and restoring peace and security at global level, in particular through multilateral action, diplomacy, especially preventive diplomacy, and the promotion of political and peaceful solutions to the conflicts still taking place. Closely linked to this is, of course, the need to respond decisively, effectively and in a coordinated manner to the global threat posed by terrorism, and to provide equally adequate and shared responses to migration problems. It is also essential to continue to invest in promoting the rule of law, democracy and the ability to respond to other challenges, such as those posed by climate change, with a view to an effective multilateral system, within which the Union can and must be at the forefront.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report outlines the EU's objectives vis-à-vis the UN in the forthcoming session of its General Assembly. I guess it is more or less clearly expressed the objective of winning the French seat in the Security Council or, failing that, to satellite it. For this reason, I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fundamental principles underlying the European Union's foreign action are based on the promotion of dialogue, inclusive multilateralism and respect for human rights as universal, indivisible, independent and inseparable postulates. With this in mind, the United Nations Organisation is the natural framework for effectively promoting these principles on a global scale, promoting cooperation and exchange of views, facilitating efforts to find peaceful diplomatic solutions to the dramatic crises and conflicts that exist. Within this framework, the European Union must move with the knowledge that derives from its history and its geopolitical and cultural weight, playing a leading role without hesitation on all crucial issues, so as to increase the influence of its soft power at world level.  I am thinking, for example, of the resolution of the conflicts still under way in Africa, the Middle East or the need for a reform of the United Nations itself that is fairer, more balanced and more representative of the current international balances. I am thinking of the promotion of closer and more transparent international tax cooperation, capable of limiting the emergence of trade distortions and situations of social dumping which give rise to great injustices and inequalities.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of this report, which I find well articulated and full of valuable ideas, above all the long-term objective of the European Union to have a seat on an enlarged Security Council. The European Union shows a great commitment to multilateralism and the intensification of cooperation with the United Nations. The European commitment stems precisely from the values and convictions that are rightly confirmed in the priorities identified in the report, such as: peace and security, the fight against terrorism, disarmament, migratory flows, human rights, democracy and the rule of law, development and climate change. A multilateral system based on universally shared norms and values, I believe, is the most appropriate instrument for effectively addressing crises and countless global challenges. The EU's security environment is denoted by increasing instability, and the so-called secular and peace-keeping armed arm provided for in Articles 43, 46 and 47 of the UN Charter has never been applied. The 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly could provide a good opportunity to lay the foundations for a concrete modernisation of what my illustrious countryman Antonio Cassese called 'realistic legal mechanisms'.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report because I strongly protest the enhancement of access to sexual and reproductive health services, namely abortion, which defies all moral principles, especially the right to live. I do support the recommendations on promoting the collaboration between the EU and UN General Assembly for the purpose of providing better regional and global protection but my conscience does not allow me to vote in favour of anything which allows people to kill innocent children.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Delegation of the Five Star Movement Europe voted in favour of the own-initiative report drawing up recommendations to the Council in relation to the next session of the United Nations General Assembly. The recommendations are, in fact, entirely acceptable in that they relate to engagement on issues relating to peace and security, the fight against terrorism, migration, human rights, the rule of law, development, climate change and the reform of the United Nations System. Finally, I fully support the call for the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals set out in the 2030 Agenda.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's commitment to effective multilateralism and good global governance, centred on the UNITED Nations, is an integral part of the EU's external policy, and Member States should make every effort to coordinate their actions in all international for a. On the subject of security, the proposal reiterates the condemnation of terrorism and the need to combat online terrorist recruitment and propaganda, while recalling that the actions to be taken must always respect international human rights principles. And, again out of respect for the lives and security of all, it calls for non-proliferation and nuclear disarmament, as well as the global abolition of the death penalty. It is also to be welcomed to highlight the importance of women in peace processes and to encourage their representation at all levels of decision-making, including at the head of the United Nations. Finally, there is a call to develop a human rights-centred approach with a particular focus on the situation of children and migrants. For all these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. – We support the report, we underline the important role played by the UN as a guarantor of global security and stability.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a European Parliament recommendation to the Council on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly contains some positive elements that contribute to the wider cooperation of States. However, as I do not embrace references to military intervention, I have decided to abstain.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 'report on the proposal for a European Parliament recommendation to the Council on the 71st session of the UN General Assembly' as I believe it is essential to promote cooperation between the European Union and the United Nations in the definition of new security strategies, peacekeeping and crisis management. I also believe that the Member States of the European Union must make every effort to coordinate their actions within the bodies and bodies of the United Nations system.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with this proposal, which is simply intended to make a number of recommendations to the European Council. These are very difficult times with regard to the security of citizens and their fundamental rights. We are going through a difficult period in which the security of our citizens is no longer guaranteed, where terrorism is having countless victims. I am convinced that the European Union must make even greater efforts to limit these problems as much as possible and to try to maintain peace and security in the countries affected by these phenomena. For these reasons, I therefore voted in favour of this proposal for a recommendation to the European Council.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU contributes substantially to the development of policies adopted within the UN and should further strengthen its contribution to the continuous improvement of global governance through the United Nations, especially in a period of change in which global power is being disseminated and when global threats dominate the political agenda. Based on the 71st Session of the United Nations General Assembly, I support the Kovatchev Report, which addresses a number of recommendations to the Council to promote peace and security for the conflicts in the world and the importance of humanitarian action, the fight against terrorism including its financing, recruitment of its members, disarmament, support for migration flows and the fight against human smuggling and trafficking in human beings. I reiterate the importance of promoting the values of Human Rights, Democracy and the Rule of Law on which the EU is based and also embodied in the UN acquis and the need to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals and the definition of a coherence agenda for development policies.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the demands in the report. I am convinced that only through global cooperation can we achieve peace and security, an effective development policy, respect for human rights and a world order based on democratic and constitutional principles. We, the EU, must play an active role in this and play an active role in shaping it.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's commitment to effective multilateralism and good global governance is an integral part of the EU's external policy. The European strategy is based on universal standards and values to be honoured and respected, in order to address emerging global crises, challenges and threats, including at the level of IT and digital systems. The European Union must therefore play a proactive role in contributing effectively to the action of the United Nations with global proposals for peace and security, development, human rights, democracy and an international order based on respect for the rule of law. The EU Member States are called upon to make every effort to coordinate their actions within the bodies and bodies of the UN system. The EU security environment is increasingly unstable and precarious due to a large number of challenges, including violent conflicts, terrorism, organised crime, unprecedented migration flows and climate change, which are impossible to address at national level and require regional and global responses. I voted in favour of this report, which also recognises the importance of respect for internationally recognised borders and the need to take action against violations of international law.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While Member States are urged to support the UN resolution "Effects of the Use of Weapons and Ammunition Containing Depleted Uranium" and advocates greater efforts to protect the rights of religious and other minorities, it has interventionist and interferenceting approaches to the Crimean conflict, nor is it emphasized the need to rethink the current functioning of the UN Security Council , so I abstained.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The growing complexity of the global security environment implies a careful review of the UN multilateralism model. The EU, together with its Member States, is the largest financial contributor to the UN system and supports its policies and objectives. I therefore welcome the European Parliament's recommendation to the Council that the UN should be able to respond effectively to emerging challenges in the European and global context. In the area of the protection of peace and security, I hope that the UN will continue to support multilateral efforts to find lasting peaceful solutions to the conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa. In the context of the current hybrid threats dictated by terrorism and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, I believe that the EU and the UN must strengthen cooperation to combat terrorist propaganda and terrorist financing, in a manner consistent with the UN Global Strategy against Terrorism and in line with the UN General Assembly resolution on 'Effects of the use of weapons and ammunition containing depleted uranium'. Finally, I support closer cooperation between the UN and the EU to strengthen the coherence of development policies within the UN, in order to complement the commitment to the implementation of the 2030 Agenda Sustainable Development Goals.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union together with the Member States is the most important financial contributor to the UN, providing half of all contributions to its funds and programmes. The UN General Assembly is the most appropriate place for the development of multilateral agreements on new challenges such as information warfare and hybrid warfare, cyber threats, bioengineering, and the proliferation of dual-use technologies. Security at European Union level is increasingly unstable due to a large number of new or long-standing challenges, including violent conflicts, terrorism, organised crime, unprecedented migratory waves and climate change, which are impossible to solve at national level and require regional and global responses. I voted for a fundamental change in UN endowment with the capacity to organise and boost the implementation process of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. The 71st ordinary session of the United Nations General Assembly will take place in September at the UN headquarters in New York. The Assembly shall have the power to make recommendations to States in international matters within its jurisdiction. The Assembly has initiated a number of political, economic, humanitarian, social and legal actions that have affected the lives of millions of people around the world. The report proposes a number of recommendations to the UN General Assembly in areas such as peace and security, migration, the fight against terrorism on a global scale, women's rights and UN reform. In general, I support close cooperation with the United Nations and other international organisations to jointly address foreign policy, security and humanitarian challenges. I also support the reform of the United Nations to improve the transparency, speed and effectiveness of this organisation so that it can meet the many challenges that the world is currently facing. However, this does not mean that I believe that the European Union has won its own mandate in the UN Security Council. The UK and France should not be forced to renunciation of their mandates in the UN Security Council for the BENEFIT of the EU as part of any reforms. With this in mind, I voted against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Undoubtedly, recent happenings show that we need to address and ensure peace and security and continue to fight against terrorism. In the field of migration we need enhanced coherence and coordination between the external and internal dimensions of migration policy and the development and external affairs agendas while ensuring that human rights, democracy and the rule of law remain fundamental elements of the Union. This recommendation also takes into account Development and Climate change, which are crucially important in reaching the Union’s objectives. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report. However, I voted against all articles making reference to abortion.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the European Union must play a proactive role in building a United Nations that is able to contribute effectively to global solutions, peace and security, development, human rights, democracy and an international order based on the rule of law in the context of addressing global crises, problems and threats.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament approved a recommendation to the Council ahead of the 71st session of the UN General Assembly, reaffirming the EU's commitment to effective multilateralism and good global governance, centred on the United Nations. In an increasingly unstable and precarious security environment and, convinced that a multilateral system based on universal standards and values to be respected is the most appropriate instrument for dealing with global crises and challenges, I voted in favour of this recommendation. I believe, in this regard, that the EU must cooperate effectively with the entire UN system in those areas on which international stability and security depend, such as the fight against terrorism or the management of migration, preventing irregular migration and combating migrant trafficking. I hope that the EU will play an increasingly proactive role in strengthening a United Nations Organisation that can contribute to peace and security, development, the protection of human rights ( as universal, indivisible, interdependent and related), democracy and an international order based on the rule of law.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report makes recommendations to the Council on peace, security, counter-terrorism, non-proliferation, disarmament, migration, human rights, democracy, the rule of law, development, climate change and reform of the United Nations system.  Parliament recommends that the Council reiterate its categorical condemnation of terrorism and its full support for measures aimed at defeating and eradicating terrorist organisations, including the so-called "Daesh" group, to reaffirm clearly and categorically that all human rights recognised by UN conventions are universal, inseparable, interdependent and intimately linked.  Sharing the priorities, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The United Nations is an organisation for independent and sovereign states, with very few exceptions. We do not believe that the EU should have a place in the General Assembly. Various parts of the resolution were of concern, in particular calls for the two EU Member States with permanent seats on the UN Security Council to represent the EU in this capacity.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With the adoption of this resolution, Parliament sends its recommendations to the Council for the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly.  I supported this text, which highlights in particular the need to strengthen our strategy for preventing radicalisation and combating terrorism. We were then able to reiterate our call to end terrorist recruitment and propaganda via the internet and social networks.  Moreover, it was also necessary to recall our struggle for better protection of religious minorities from violence and persecution, especially Eastern Christians.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA is pleased that, after one year of interruption, the European Parliament has re-completed a report for the upcoming session of the United Nations General Assembly (UN). Global challenges such as terrorism and climate change require global solutions. As the main funder of the UN, it is the duty and right of the European Union to fill in the words 'international community'.  However, the N-VA considers that the report lacks focus in certain paragraphs. For example, it considers the request to the UN to take an active part in the debate on the term 'climate refugee', including its possible legal definition in international law, as unrealistic. In addition, the N-VA is sceptical about the creation of an international tax body within the UN system. Fiscal policy is, after all, one of the national competences. The N-VA delegation therefore abstained in voting on this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this 71st session because I believe it is important to ensure cooperation between the EU and the United Nations in defining new security strategies, peacekeeping and crisis management, in order to continue to work multilaterally to find solutions to conflicts and sustainable development.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's recommendation to the Council of 7 July 2016 on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. Among all the other missed recommendations, it is particularly striking that the resolution recommends that a comprehensive reform of the United Nations Security Council be supported on the basis of a broad consensus in order to better reflect the new world situation and to ensure that the Council is able to effectively address threats to international peace and security, and that it recommends that the EU's long-term objective be better reflected. to obtain a seat on a reformed UN Security Council. The EU has so far been unable to develop and defend viable or convincing foreign policy principles, in the face of many national interests that are as diverse as they are justified. A seat for the EU on the Security Council is not desirable, but dangerous.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text focuses on the EU's objectives for the next session of the UN General Assembly. To the extent that it leads to recurrent interference in the diplomacy of the Member States and where the EU wishes to satellite the French seat on the UN Security Council, I voted against it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU is cut off and wants to contribute to the solution of conflicts and crises in Syria, Libya, Yemen, Western Sahara, Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia, Somalia, Sudan, South Sudan, Mali, etc., but does not see the Cyprus issue as an issue to be raised at the 71st Session. It is worth noting that crises and conflicts in several of the above countries are the product of the policy of specific Member States.  At the same time, the EU shows the need to get involved in matters concerning Russia and third countries, without having any competence to do so. It also wants to strengthen the presence of Europeans in peacekeeping missions, ignoring the consequences for human lives that this can bring.  Indeed, in matters of security and terrorism there must be cooperation, but we believe that the interventionist way of operating the EU will intensify rather than solve the various crises.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU's commitment to effective multilateralism and good global governance, centred on the United Nations, represents an integral part of EU foreign policy and is based on the conviction that a multilateral system based on universal rules and values, which must be respected and observed, is best suited to addressing crises, challenges and threats on a global scale. The EU and its Member States collectively represent the largest individual financial contributor to the UN system, providing about one third of the regular UN budget, almost two-fifths of the UN peacekeeping budget and about half of all contributions to its funds and programmes. The EU should therefore urge the UN to actively promote measures to ensure that all parties directly or indirectly involved in armed conflicts and their organisations fully comply with international obligations and standards of public international law and make efforts to find peaceful and diplomatic solutions to conflicts of any kind.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report makes recommendations for the 71st United Nations General Assembly.  The report is based on a contextualization of the global and regional situation considered to be in serious deterioration. It sets out what it considers to be threats to EU security. It advocates strengthening European militarism under the European Security Strategy. The "challenges" set out are: violent conflicts, terrorism, organised crime, unprecedented migration, climate change, hybrid warfare and information, cyberthreats, bioengineering, lethal autonomous systems, nanotechnologies, miniaturisation of weapons systems and the proliferation of dual-use technologies. In other words, nato's "new" strategic concept and rationale are replicated. Nor is it worth listing the EU's enormous contradictions with regard to the supposed protection of the environment or democracy and human rights. What the report contains of negative - apart from the mystifications, contradictions and statements - is more than enough to justify our vote against. The defence of an EU representation in the UN remains, including in the Security Council, contrary to the spirit of the organisation and attacking the sovereignty of european states, which we reject.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 If the UN is to acquire the capacity to implement, shape and promote the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, substantial reforms need to be made to its functioning. There is an urgent need for better cooperation between the UN institutions, both at strategic and local level. In order to maintain the EU's credibility and leadership in world development, it is essential to present a common position on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development before holding a high-level political forum in 2016. The European Commission should therefore not hesitate to issue a communication on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development in a timely manner so that the European Parliament can contribute to the Council's conclusions before holding a high-level political forum. The European Union should continue to work to strengthen international tax cooperation in support of the creation of an international tax authority within the UN system.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report: it proposes nothing new and once again confines itself to submitting a number of suggestions on various issues to the Council.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU is cut off and wants to contribute to the solution of conflicts and crises in Syria, Libya, Yemen, Western Sahara, Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia, Somalia, Sudan, South Sudan, Mali, etc., but does not see it as an issue, which it should raise at the 71st Session, the Cyprus issue. It is worth noting that crises and conflicts in several of the above countries are the product of the policy of specific Member States.  At the same time, the EU shows the need to get involved in matters concerning Russia and third countries, without having any competence to do so. It also wants to strengthen the presence of Europeans in peacekeeping missions, ignoring the consequences for human lives that this can bring. Indeed, there must be cooperation on security and terrorism, but I believe that the interventionist way of operating the EU will intensify rather than solve the various crises, and that is why I am voting against the report containing a proposal for a European Parliament recommendation to the Council on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome the inclusions in the report of issues that take into account the three pillars of the United Nations which are peace and security, development and human rights.  Particularly, the focus on the role of women in the peace process, the support for representation of women at all levels of the decision-making process, the inclusion of children’s rights and the definition of responsibility to protect (R2P) and the human security concept to be closer to gender equality and human rights. I hope that this session will prioritise the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons and global disarmament, a human-rights based approach to migration, and special attention to women and children. We must show zero tolerance for the death penalty, continue to support the International Criminal Court and the ratification of the Kampala amendments and the accountability of perpetrators in case of genocides. Finally, we must give our strongest support for a woman as the new Secretary General.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I accepted Parliament's recommendations to the European Council on the 71st session of the United Nations. In my group's view, europe's exposure to hybrid warfare, cyberterrorism and unprecedented waves of migrants is increasing in the light of the violent conflicts in its immediate neighbourhood. The line between external and internal threats is blurring, and the European security environment is becoming increasingly complex, thus narrowing the autonomous margins of each country or region. We need to reinforce the idea that defence and intelligence cooperation at European level is no longer just a political option, but a strategic and economic necessity. Cooperation with the UN on issues such as peace and security, terrorism, organised crime, regional conflicts, state bankruptcy and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction are also important. Cooperation with the UN General Assembly is indispensable in order to eradicate trafficking in human beings, prevent recruitment by terrorist groups and break the funding of these groups. We must limit the recruitment, organisation, transport and equipment of terrorist fighters and the financing of terrorist travel and activities.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report which includes a proposal for a recommendation from the European Parliament to the Council on 71. or session of the United Nations General Assembly because, in the face of the various challenges we face, we must maintain a common position as a global player. The Union must face challenges of peace and security, but it must also be vigilant and a reference for the defence of human rights, both in migration flows and in the world. Therefore, we must not leave a minute of work and fight for a better and fairer world for the next generations.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the joint text adopted on the political priorities to be considered by the EU at the next UN General Assembly. Europe must continue to assert its voice as a global democratic actor, and i therefore consider the issues highlighted in our text to be very important, including: the role of women in peace processes and the need for adequate representation in decision-making processes, children's rights, with particular reference to the issue of migrant children, attention to the emerging issue of refugees for climatic reasons. , support for increasingly effective EU coordination within multilateral institutions.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report containing a proposal for a European Parliament recommendation to the Council on the 71st session of the UN General Assembly because I strongly believe in the need for a system based on multilateralism and global governance whose focus revolves around the UN.  I am also convinced that the EU has a duty to play an active role in implementing a sound structure within the United Nations so as to contribute effectively to the spread of peace, stability, the rule of law and respect for human rights and democracy. As an international player, the European Union also has the task of supporting the work of task forces engaged in the difficult search for peace solutions in Syria, Yemen, Libya or Western Sahara and of continuing to provide humanitarian, political and financial assistance to end conflicts in the hot spots of the planet, as well as working effectively to combat terrorism , the illegal trade in arms and ammunition and trafficking in human beings. Finally, I agree with the need for cooperation between the UN and the EU in order to take strong action to combat climate change by implementing the COP21 agreement.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support Parliament's recommendations on the occasion of the 71st session of the UN General Assembly. Among other things, it is important to support the current and comprehensive efforts aimed at strengthening United Nations peacekeeping missions and their capacity to manage conflicts. In addition, religious and other minorities must be better protected and terrorism must be combated.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from this vote as I advocate a multilateral approach to international relations, which favours dialogue and horizontal cooperation between States and actors in international relations, to the detriment of strategic-military solutions. I am in favour of a restructuring of the United Nations and its Security Council, but not in the sense of consolidating its character as an exclusive and exclusionary club dominated by economic and military powers, but instead promoting and effectively promoting and enabling an equitable system of representation and decision-making to move towards a new world order based on justice , democracy, respect for human rights, joint approach to great global ills, preservation of global public goods and peace.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which sets out Parliament’s recommendation to the Council on important points to raise ahead of the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. It covers a range of topics including peace and security, the fight against terrorism, human rights, development and reform of the UN system. It contains many helpful and timely recommendations, including calls for enhanced cooperation on migration, to work towards the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals and to promote the full implementation of the Arms Trade Treaty.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Parliament encourages the stepping up of efforts to clamp down on recruitment and fight terrorist propaganda, through social media platforms but also through networks of radicalised hate preachers. Also, it is crucial to continue to work with the UN in combating the financing of terrorism, including the use of existing mechanisms to designate terrorist individuals and organisations and strengthen asset-freezing mechanisms worldwide while upholding international standards on due process and the rule of law.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report concerns priorities for the 71st session of the UN General Assembly. We support the need for international cooperation within the UN, but we reject the use of military means to resolve disputes, as well as the call for Member States to appear with one voice. That is why we have held a position of abstention.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support Parliament’s recommendation on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. In particular, I support the recommendation to promote the work of UNHCR in implementing its international mandate to protect refugees, and the report’s unequivocal condemnation of terrorism and its full support for actions aimed at the defeat and eradication of terrorist organisations, in particular, the so-called ‘ISIS/Daesh’, which poses a clear threat to regional and international security.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I agree with the recommendations made within the report.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. – On behalf of the European Parliamentary Labour Party, we respectfully voted against the goal of the EU having a single seat in the UN Security Council, to reflect the consistent position our delegation has taken, on an otherwise excellent report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that proposes a recommendation to the Council on the 71st Session of the United Nations General Assembly. We must support a human-rights based approach to migration and the role of women in the peace process. Moreover, it is crucial to keep pushing for the abolishment of the death penalty across the world.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the report with a proposal for a Recommendation from the European Parliament to the Council on the 71st (2016/2020) as the proposal sublimates all of the EU's most important priorities on the international stage, taking into account the deteriorating global and regional security environment, the new challenges of a fragile security situation affecting the situation within the EU, and the need for the EU to play a proactive role in UN action towards peace, security of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. Priorities are reflected in recommendations on peace and security, counter-terrorism, non-proliferation and disarmament, migration, human rights, democracy and the rule of law, sustainable development, climate change and reform of the UN system.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The report looks at the EU's objectives for the next session of the UN General Assembly. It envisages a better integration of the European Union within the objectives of the United Nations and does not fail to interfere in a set of international situations, using the humanitarian pretext to mask the total interference of the European Union at the international level. This situation of fact does not seem to me to be acceptable in any way, and that is why I have opposed it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Andrey Kovatchev's report on the recommendations of the European Parliament for the 71st session of the UN General Assembly. This report proposes actions related to the many issues facing the United Nations: peace and security, terrorism, human rights, development, climate change and reform of the United Nations system.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which reiterates the European Union's commitment to effective multilateralism and good global governance centred on the United Nations. Recommendations include a call for lasting and peaceful political solutions to ongoing conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa, the eradication of terrorist organizations, and a call for greater protection of religious minorities.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted the report of Mr Kovatchev as he very keenly recognises the need to have a presence in the UN that will reflect the EU’s points of view on the major global challenges. Armed conflicts, the migration crisis, the financial crisis, the non-proliferation of nuclear and weapons of mass destruction and a number of ongoing challenges are directly addressed in the report.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining on this resolution. Although the United Nations is doing a great job in many areas and must be supported by the international community, the approach in this report is too idealistic and very vague on the question of what possible role the EU or the Member States should play in the General Assembly.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it sets out Parliament’s recommendation to the Council on important points to raise ahead of the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. It contains many helpful and timely recommendations, including calls for enhanced cooperation on migration, to work towards the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals and to promote the full implementation of the Arms Trade Treaty.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the report on a proposal for a European Parliament recommendation to the Council on the 71st session of the UN General Assembly. The report makes several recommendations for strengthening security, promoting development, combating terrorism and supporting the UN. In particular, the Council is recommended to: continue to support multilateral agreements with a view to establishing political and peaceful solutions to the conflicts in North Africa and the Middle East; reiterate its condemnation of terrorism and strengthen its support for actions aimed at the elimination of terrorist organisations; to give greater support to the UNHCR in the implementation of the International Mandate for the Protection of Refugees; reaffirm the global and universal nature of the human rights agreed by the UN, while continuing to promote the rights of minorities and children; and, finally, to improve coordination with the UN institutions.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because the European Union is interfering in the Middle East peace process. However, this issue should be exclusively a matter of Member States' diplomacy. The European Union is also interfering in the functioning of the United Nations, which I think is unacceptable. It is up to the Member States of the United Nations to deal with the United Nations, not the European Union, which would do better to seriously address its own problems.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. It is also the role of the European Parliament to participate in global governance by being part of our international system and ensuring good cooperation with international organisations. I voted in favour of the Kovatchev report on the 71st session of the Un General Assembly, which makes a series of recommendations from the European Union to the UN Council on peacekeeping, counter-terrorism, migration, human rights and climate change.  I particularly supported our call on the United Nations to fill the legal void around the concept of 'climate refugee', in particular by addressing the possibility of an international definition.  On the other hand, I wanted to defend our values of gender equality and the promotion of women by voting in favour of a proposal to prioritise the choice of a woman as the next Secretary-General of the United Nations, in the context of the candidates presenting an equivalent level of excellence.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the 71st session of the Un General Assembly. The European Union simply does not have to play a role in the United Nations. Its aim is to win over or satelliteize the French seat on the Security Council. I will, of course, oppose that.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. The text deals with the objectives of the European Union for the next session of the UN General Assembly. It is clear that its aim is to seize the French seat on the Security Council in order to advance the EU's positions. I strongly opposed it by voting against it.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report with recommendations to the Council concerning a number of human rights concerns such as peace in the Middle East and North Africa and strengthening the UN’s ability to address conflict.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the call for the creation of a new UN body to ensure 'a global automatic exchange of information on tax issues and to compil a common global blacklist of tax havens'. Tax havens are sovereign states, and if they lure companies and individuals to low taxes, they have every right to do so.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support Parliament’s recommendation to the Council on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly in such areas as: the fight against terrorism, non-proliferation and disarmament, migration, human rights, democracy and the rule of law, development and the EU and reform of the UN system.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The EU must strengthen its position within the UN. To do this, however, all Member States need to coordinate their policies and unite their views and positions on fundamental issues. The forthcoming 71st th Ofsted will be the first of its The UN General Assembly must address the most important issues of our time, in particular the fight against terrorism and the illegal proliferation of weapons, disarmament, the promotion and promotion of peace and security in the world, the humanitarian, migration and refugee crisis, human rights, the promotion of the rule of law, climate change. I support the proposal for recommendations to the Council, the main idea and task of which is to promote, peaceful and diplomatic channels, the settlement of global and local conflicts and problems, the promotion of countries' own responsibilities and support for the reform of the UN system.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained when voting on the report containing a proposal for a European Parliament recommendation to the Council on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 6/7/2016, and because this report is not sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. It is aimed at satelliteising the French seat on the Security Council, which we disapprove of.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on the report, which assesses the 71st session of the UN General Assembly. The report contains a number of important issues, such as the emphasis on the protection of human rights, the need for a peaceful solution in the Middle East, the fight against terrorism, the security of cyberspace, the fight against illegal migration or climate change. However, I abstained in the final vote because, on the contrary, I cannot agree with some of the ideas. An example is the call to put more pressure on Russia or to push the "European" path as the only possible one for the countries of the former Soviet Union.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The United Nations and the European Union have many shared goals and values. The EU should support the UN in its initiatives, including finding a diplomatic solution to armed conflicts, promoting human rights, and preventing terrorist attacks and the spread of violent propaganda. Cooperation will help to find a global response to these problems.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. There is a lack of ideas and measures for peacekeeping. However, support for the United Nations should be supported. That is why I abstained.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because, here, the AIM of the EU is to delight or satelliteise the French seat on the UN Security Council.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I could not support the final version of this text as despite a number of good points, the final version contained unacceptable references to abortion.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome Parliament's proposal to the Council on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly: in my view, it contains important recommendations on peace and security, the fight against terrorism, non-proliferation, migration, human rights, democracy and the rule of law.  Having said that, I believe that Parliament has lost an opportunity to go even further, particularly on the Union's place in the United Nations system. Therefore, since both the United Nations and the United Nations and the Union defend universal values, they must continue to fight against double standards.  It is regrettable that no reference has been made to the situation in Ukraine and to other frozen conflicts: Parliament should not be afraid to rule against the violation of international law by third countries.  In the end, I hope that the recommendations of this proposal regarding the election of the Secretary-General will be taken into account. In my view, geographical and gender criteria must guide the representatives of the General Assembly so that the appointment of the new Secretary is consistent with the principles that both the United Nations and the Union stand for.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Union should play an active role in building a United Nations that can effectively contribute to global solutions, peace and security, development, human rights, democracy and the rule of law-based international order. The Member States of the Union must make every effort to coordinate their activities in the bodies and offices of the UN system. They are also the largest financial contributor to the UN system, providing about a third of the UN's regular budget, almost two fifths of the UN peacekeeping budget and around half of all contributions to UN funds and programmes. New challenges, including hybrid and information warfare, cyber threats, bioengineering, lethal autonomous systems, nanotechnology, miniaturisation of weapons and the proliferation of dual-use technologies, require the development of multilateral agreements, for which, in my opinion, the UN framework is most appropriate. It also provides an appropriate framework to support efforts for a new generation of arms controls and disarmament measures. I agree with the proposal that has been tabled.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which highlights important issues such as children’s rights, LGBTI rights, human rights and sport events, a human-rights based approach to migration, special attention to women and children, and zero tolerance for the death penalty.  Nevertheless, I have never supported, and voted against, any references to sexual and reproductive health rights, which in my opinion fall strictly under a competence of the Member States.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its report, the Committee on Foreign Affairs proposes that Parliament make recommendations to the Council for the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly on the following topics: Peace and Security Combating Terrorism Non-proliferation and disarmament Migration Human rights, democracy and rule of law Development Climate change Reform of the EU and UN systems I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. We are voting against this text, which sets out the EU's objectives for the next session of the UN General Assembly, as the main objective is to take control of the French seat on the UN Security Council.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the framework of its external relations, the European Union plays an important role in the framework of global governance, due to its great capacity for influence.  In the face of current global threats and challenges, the Union should make use of its influence on the international stage and contribute positively to responding to these challenges, including through multilateral support for peaceful political solutions to conflicts in North Africa and the Middle East, supporting efforts to strengthen the responsiveness of UN peacekeepers , support for counter-terrorism campaigns, increased support for unhcr work on the protection of refugees, the reaffirmation of the universal and irrevocable nature of human rights enshrined in the various UN conventions, the strengthening of the affirmation of freedom of religion and belief, among others. To this end, I am voting in favour of this report, because I believe that the European Union must play a proactive role and effectively contribute to global solutions, peace and security, development, human rights, democracy and an international order based on the rule of law.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of the Union is to delight or satelliteise the French seat on the Security Council. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which sets out Parliament’s recommendation to the Council on important points to raise ahead of the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. It covers a range of topics including peace and security, the fight against terrorism, human rights, development and reform of the UN system. It contains many helpful and timely recommendations, including calls for enhanced cooperation on migration, to work towards the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals and to promote the full implementation of the Arms Trade Treaty.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report, which once again calls into question Russia and helps to maintain the sterile spiral of reciprocal sanctions that penalises our European producers but also our cooperation in the fight against terrorism and Islamism. As the founder of the working group "For a new dialogue with Russia" in the European Parliament, I am a consistent advocate for an immediate lifting of reciprocal sanctions.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because an effective multilateral relationship system and the EU's commitment to global governance are an integral part of EU foreign policy. Greater emphasis should be placed on thresion of conflicts in parts of the world as soon as possible, so that guarantees of the rule of law and respect for human rights are implemented as soon as possible in the areas concerned.  Together with the UN, we must continue to take action against terrorism. A coordinated and cooperative migration policy should be established in both the external and internal dimensions. We must ensure that all human rights guaranteed by the conventions concluded under the auspices of the United Nations are up to force.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The United Nations General Assembly is one of the six principal organs of the United Nations and the only one in which all member nations have equal representation. I voted for this report that will improve peace and security, the fight against terrorism, non-proliferation and disarmament, migration, human rights, democracy and the rule of law, development and climate change.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report and voted in favour of it because I believe that peace, security, economic development, the protection of human rights, democracy are the main foundations of the European Union, and the re-establishment of these values, in a sustained partnership with the United Nations, can generate more concrete actions to protect them at international level. In the context of an unstable security situation caused mainly by the terrorist threat, I support the report's recommendations to promote and intensify inter-state efforts to combat terrorist organisations. I also welcome the strengthening of actions to protect and respect human rights in third countries, universal rights and those agreed under UN conventions.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. A number of proposals will be made to take into account the UN session in different areas. The aim is to make the EU's common voice heard at the UN, given that the EU and its Member States are together the biggest donors to the UN system.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled. In view of the violent conflicts in the EU's neighbourhood, europe's increasingly widespread mixed war, cyber terrorism, so-called foreign fighters, unprecedented influxes of migrants and the dwindling dividing line between external and internal threats, the European security environment is becoming increasingly difficult for a individual country or region to navigate. In this context, cooperation with the UN in the areas of peace and security, terrorism, organised crime, regional conflicts, state infection and the fight against proliferation of weapons of mass destruction needs to be strengthened. The EU should play an active role in contributing effectively to global solutions, development, peace and security, human rights, democracy and the rule of law. There is an active need for all parties and organisations directly or indirectly involved in conflicts to fully respect international obligations and international law and to seek peaceful and diplomatic solutions to a wide range of conflicts.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The United Nations is an organisation for independent and sovereign states, with very few exceptions. We do not believe that the EU should have a place in the General Assembly. Various parts of the resolution were of concern, in particular calls for the two EU Member States with permanent seats on the UN Security Council to represent the EU in this capacity.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report addressing to the Council recommendations on topics of peace and security, the fight against terrorism, non-proliferation and disarmament, migration, human rights, democracy and the rule of law, development, climate change and reform of the UN system. I, too, take the view that the conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa must be brought to an immediate end and, at multilateral level, permanent political solutions must be found that, in the context of intensified peace operations in this troubled area, peace must be found. In order to achieve this, we must first eradicate terrorism and strengthen support for the UNHCR's work in helping refugees. Human rights are universal under the Convention, and we must do more to protect the rights of religious and other minorities against persecution and violence. To achieve this, however, it is first necessary to reform and strengthen the work of the General Assembly so that it can coordinate more effectively the work of the institutions within the United Nations.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the rapporteur's recommendation that it is necessary to modify the cooperation between the European Union and the United Nations to date and to amend the strategy for crisis management and peacekeeping operations under the auspices of the EU and the UN. In particular, I would like to stress the resolution of the crisis in Syria and once again urge a halt to the genocide and persecution of Christians by extremist groups such as ISIL.  Declarative convictions are not enough. The UN and the international community are obliged to launch much-needed concrete actions. The European Union should make available all resources in preventing a humanitarian catastrophe in Syria and neighbouring countries in the Middle East. Millions of people need our help and protection and we need to help them. Echoes of the Syrian crisis have also hit European soil, leading to the destabilisation of Southeast Europe. There has been a lack of incoordination and a lack of strategy on the EU-UN route in resolving the crisis situation both at the external borders of the European Union and the Middle East, and this problem needs to be urgently addressed.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The text sets out the objectives of the European Union for the next session of the UN General Assembly. But the European Union does not have to have any objective in this regard. It has no legitimacy and must absolutely leave the Member States in control of their diplomacy.  I therefore vote against this interference, which may one day become an attempt by the EU to take over The permanent seat of France in the Security Council.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ As the EU's security situation becomes increasingly unstable and variable due to the high number of long-standing and new security challenges involving violent conflicts, terrorism, organised crime, unprecedented waves of migrants and climate change that are impossible to address at national level and which call for regional and global solutions, I propose to make a clear recommendation to the Council. I ask the Council to continue to support multilateral efforts to find long-term political and peace solutions to the ongoing conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa; to continue to support the work of the UN Secretary-General's Special Envoy for Syria, the Special Representative and the Head of the United Nations Support Mission in Libya, the UN Secretary-General's Special Envoy for Yemen, the UN Special Coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process and the UN Secretary-General's Special Representative for Western Sahara; to seek sustained humanitarian, financial and political assistance from the international community to address the humanitarian situation and to work towards an immediate end to violence; to condemn unilaterally non-complied action in areas of crisis. I also call on the Council to continue to call for full respect for the internationally recognised borders and territorial integrity of eastern European and Southern Caucasus countries, including Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, in view of violations of international law in these areas, and their free and sovereign commitment to the European path.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report continues the european Parliament's overlooking narrative of recommendations to the United Nations General Assembly. Starting from a contextualization of the global and regional situation, it exposes those that are the threats to the security of the European Union, to justify the posture of securitarization and strengthening of European militarism with a view to pursuing a European Security Strategy. It is shameful to launder the European Union's role in the criminal response to the refugee tragedy. The EU, which claims to be a staunch human rights defender, violates them with impunity in responding to migration. The EU's assertion as a promoter of environmental sustainability when its environmental policies are at the service of the market and financial interests is sarcastic. The proposal for an alignment and combination of UN policy with that which is the EU's external and security agenda is unacceptable. The call on Member States to take action on disarmament is sarcastic when the EU strengthens its military budgets and militarisation. The un's praise for the adoption of a resolution on each country's right to restructure sovereign debt is sarcastic, when the EU and its impositions prevent states from sovereignly renegotiating debts. We voted against it.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The United Nations is an irreplaceable global democratic forum. I also believe that the UN needs to be reformed and that its specialised agencies need to work more transparently.
