Furthermore, I hope that the EU will be able, as soon as possible, to have a permanent seat on the Security Council and in this way to deploy all its potential, which has not yet been expressed, with regard to the common foreign and security policy. In its report, the European Parliament makes recommendations to the Council on peace and security, the fight against terrorism, proliferation and disarmament, migration, human rights, democracy and the rule of law at the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report because it contains my key demands on the content of the negotiations of this year's UN General Assembly. I personally welcome, for example, the mention of the unacceptable occupation of Crimea and Russia's interference in the conflict in eastern Ukraine.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which makes recommendations to the Council on security and peace, the fight against terrorism, others related to disarmament and non-proliferation, migration, human rights and climate change. These areas of action at the multilateral level must be supported by the European Union, especially at a time when there is a great deal of conflict in regions such as the Middle East or North Africa. Strengthening peacekeeping operations is fundamental in this context, as is the protection of the rights of religious minorities.  More broadly, we call for comprehensive reform of the UN Security Council, so that UN institutions can carry out their missions effectively and on the basis of consensus between states.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The United Nations is an organisation for independent and sovereign states, with very few exceptions. We do not believe that the EU should have a place in the General Assembly. Various parts of the resolution were of concern, in particular calls for the two EU Member States with permanent seats on the UN Security Council to represent the EU in this capacity.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I want to reinforce the attention that needs to be given: to the role of women in peace processes; representation of women at all levels of decision-making; children's rights; gender equality; non-proliferation of nuclear weapons and global disarmament; human rights in migration; zero tolerance for the death penalty; LGBTI rights; the definition of climate refugees and absolute intransigence for respect for human rights.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. This report on Session 71 of the United Nations General Assembly constitutes the annual recommendation to the Council of the European Parliament prior to the meeting of this body. Multilateral attempts to find lasting and peaceful political solutions to conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa must continue to be supported; especially in Syria, Libya, Yemen, the Middle East Peace Process and Western Sahara, and to seek continued humanitarian, financial and political assistance from the international community to address the humanitarian situation and work for the immediate cessation of violence. It also promotes greater support for UNHCR's work to bridge the huge gap between its budgetary needs and the funding received, and greater global solidarity is needed. Further strengthening respect for human rights, democracy and the rule of law in the world, the fight against terrorism, non-proliferation and disarmament, and rapid implementation of the decisions taken at the 2015 Paris Climate Change Conference are other priority issues in this report that I supported with my vote.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted on the European Parliament's recommendation to the Council on the 71st session of the UN General Assembly, in order to encourage the strengthening of security in the Union at a time when it seems particularly vulnerable.  Effective cooperation between the European Union and the United Nations is essential to develop new security, peacekeeping and crisis management strategies. As such, the fight against terrorism is a priority, and our eyes are obviously on Syria and the Middle East, where we must encourage multilateral talks and protect civilians as much as possible from the throes of conflict.  In addition, we will continue to ensure that elections are conducted around the world, with a view to transparency and to ensure democracy throughout the United Nations system.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution, which deals with the fundamental problems and challenges of today. First of all, the resolution stresses the need to combat climate change and must remain a priority in the European Union. It also stresses the need for rapid implementation of the paris climate change conference decisions. The resolution also focuses on the fight against terrorism. The European Parliament considers that cooperation between the EU and the United Nations in the fight against the financing of terrorism is necessary. The scope of cooperation in the resolution extends to draw attention to improvised explosive devices and the persons producing them. It is these cartridges used in many recent terrorist attacks. The text adopted calls for the use of the resources and expertise of the united nations system structures and Interpol in order to facilitate greater cooperation between law enforcement agencies.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union (EU) is committed to good global governance and multilateralism by playing a proactive role in the United Nations through contributions to the common search for global solutions, be it peace, security, development, human rights, democracy or the rule of law-based international order. In this context, the European Parliament (EP) produced the report voted on today, which contains some proposals for the next UN General Assembly, to be held in September. This report, which I supported, believes that the EU should continue to support multilateral attempts to find lasting (and peaceful) political solutions to regional conflicts, in particular in the Middle East and North Africa, and continue to strengthen UN peacekeeping operations, while reiterating the condemnation of terrorism and its support for actions aimed at combating terrorist organisations. Human Rights (agreed under UN conventions), being universal, indivisible, interdependent and interrelated, must also be scrupulously respected. I also stress the need to reform its Security Council in order to promote the revitalization of the work of the General Assembly and the consequent improvement of coordination and coherence of UN actions.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets out the position of the European Parliament for the 71st session of the Un General Assembly. The text thus recalls the European Union's commitment to effective multilateralism and good global governance, centred on the United Nations. This text underlines the magnitude of the challenges to be met in the years to come. Thus, this report calls for further peace efforts in the Middle East, but also to question the means by which international law in a war zone can be respected. The report also stresses the importance of the fight against terrorism and in particular the fight against Daesh. I supported this text because it reminds us how important cooperation between the EU and the UN is in order to respond effectively to the current challenges.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Through the report presented by Mrs Kovatchev, the European Parliament has addressed a proposal for a recommendation to the UN General Assembly. This proposal covers different areas, all of which are very sensitive at international level, such as the fight against terrorism, migration and climate change. These are current challenges that transcend national borders, to which we can only respond effectively by strengthening cooperation at international level. The European Parliament calls for the support and promotion of those fundamental and democratic rights which are at the basis of european construction itself, but which too many people in this world cannot enjoy. It is precisely in this direction that the United Nations must take action in order to guarantee a climate of peace and security. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the proposed text.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from this vote as I advocate a multilateral approach to international relations, which favours dialogue and horizontal cooperation between States and actors in international relations, to the detriment of strategic-military solutions. I am in favour of a restructuring of the United Nations and its Security Council, but not in the sense of consolidating its character as an exclusive and exclusionary club dominated by economic and military powers, but instead promoting and effectively promoting and enabling an equitable system of representation and decision-making to move towards a new world order based on justice , democracy, respect for human rights, joint approach to great global ills, preservation of global public goods and peace.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the recommendation to the Council on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. Cooperation between the EU and the UN will help address the increasingly unstable security environment and global challenges such as terrorism, unprecedented migration, and climate change. These problems require both regional and global responses. An approach based on human rights should be adopted for the migration crisis, with special attention paid to women and children to prevent trafficking and exploitation, and a focus on children’s rights including the right to water, healthcare, sanitation and education. These actions will support desperate people fleeing the appalling conditions of war and persecution.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report with a proposal for a recommendation from the European Parliament to the Council on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. In this recommendation, we set out all relevant issues such as development, climate change, human rights and the rule of law.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While Member States are urged to support the UN resolution "Effects of the Use of Weapons and Ammunition Containing Depleted Uranium" and advocates greater efforts to protect the rights of religious and other minorities, it has interventionist and interferenceting approaches to the Crimean conflict, nor is it emphasized the need to rethink the current functioning of the UN Security Council , so I abstained.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report, which contains a proposal for a recommendation from the European Parliament to the Council on the 71st Session of the United Nations General Assembly, is a comprehensive and important document in the definition of consensual positions in diverse and decisive areas.  In this area, I would like to stress that one of these recommendations is to ensure that the EU remains at the forefront of the fight against climate change and that it cooperates with the UN in this area.  I agree that the rapid implementation of the decisions taken at the 2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Paris must be ensured. This is a determining issue. If humanity is not the one to address the enormous problem of climate change that it itself has caused, humanity will be one of the victims. This was one of the reasons why I voted in favour of this extensive set of recommendations to the Council.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I do not recognise the EU's right to get involved in UN matters.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation to the Council regarding the 71st Session of the UNGA. I am particularly pleased to hear that many amendments which were the initiative of my socialist colleagues have been included in the text, particularly amendments concerning the role of women in the peace process, an aspect which is all too often overlooked; a zero tolerance for the death penalty; LGBTI rights; and a human rights-based approach to migration, with special attention given to women and children. Overall, I think this is a satisfactory text, which I can support.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EU's close cooperation with the United Nations and other international organisations to address foreign policy, security and humanitarian problems together. At the same time, I support the reform of the UN to make the organisation more transparent, agile and effective, so that it is able to meet a number of challenges facing today's world. But that does not mean that I would like to see the European Union win its own seat on the UN Security Council. It is very important that countries have the opportunity and the ability to speak when they want to, in their own national interest, which is a defining element of a country's foreign policy. I abstained.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Report with a proposal for a recommendation from the European Parliament to the Council on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. The UN can contribute effectively to global solutions, peace and security, development, human rights, democracy and an international order based on the rule of law. The global and regional security environment is becoming more complex, the borders between internal and external security are increasingly overlapping, so the UN continues to play a key role in ensuring global security and stability. The EU's security situation is also increasingly unstable and changing due to the high number of long-standing and new security challenges involving violent conflicts, terrorism, organised crime, unprecedented waves of migrants and climate change that cannot be addressed at national level and which demand regional and global solutions. Together, the EU and the Member States make the largest financial contribution to the UN system, which amounts to one third of the regular UN budget. Also, the EU is one of the greatest protectors and promoters of human rights, fundamental freedoms, cultural values and diversity, democracy and the rule of law, achieving environmental sustainability goals through improving environmental quality and sustainable management of natural resources.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly, because the EU must play an active role in the work of a UN that can contribute effectively to global solutions, peace and security, development, human rights, democracy and the rule of law-based international order. Now that the regional and global security environment is deteriorating significantly, the UN must play a key role in ensuring global security and stability. The conflicts in Syria, Libya, Nigeria, Afghanistan, Iraq must be alarming in the context of active action to ensure that all parties directly or indirectly involved in armed conflicts and their organisations fully comply with international obligations and standards laid down in international law and seek to ensure a peaceful and diplomatic solution to all kinds of conflicts. At the same time, there is an urgent need to demand that the necessary humanitarian aid and protection be provided to people in need.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The annual report, with recommendations to the Council for the autumn plenary session of the United Nations General Assembly, calls on the members of the Security Council to refrain from using their veto in cases of crimes against humanity. It also includes a recommendation that EU Member States actively participate in the Open Working Group, the Subsidiary Body of the General Assembly for the negotiation of multilateral nuclear disarmament. As is customary, this time, in connection with the reform of the Security Council, the only mention is that the long-term objective is for the European Union to have a seat on the Security Council. It also mentions international humanitarian and human rights law in relation to the use of drones, as well as the promotion to halt the development and use of fully autonomous weapons that allow attacks to be completely independent of human intervention. The report also recommends defining climate migrants, prosecuting sexual abuse by United Nations troops, taking action to protect whistleblowers and reforming the rules of special envoys to ensure neutrality. In view of all the above, I believe that the report contains many good recommendations, which is also the basis for my vote in favour of adopting the report.

name: Renato Soru (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation to the Council on the EU's priorities for the 71st session of the UN General Assembly to be held next September. On the basis of the strong relations between the United Nations and the Union, the text reaffirms Europe's continued commitment to multilateral cooperation based on universal norms and values as an integral part of our external policy. The Council should insist on multilateral diplomatic solutions with the parties involved in the ongoing conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa, in particular by supporting peace negotiations between the Syrian parties. Similarly, the Council is asked to support the EU's active role in collective actions to combat international terrorism and in the definition of measures to promote the disarmament of terrorist groups and against nuclear proliferation, in line with international treaties on the subject. With regard to the issue of the reform of the Security Council, the Council should work towards a structure of this body that better reflects the new world reality and therefore the UN's capacity to react to crises, with the aim of arriving at a reformed and enlarged Council in which the EU can obtain a permanent seat.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The General Assembly is one of the main UN bodies. The European Parliament's recommendations to the Council reflect the current needs of the dynamically changing social situation in Europe. The aim is to improve global governance through institutionalised dialogue between states on issues such as migration, human rights, the fight against terrorism, non-proliferation and disarmament and others.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ A systematic part of the Union's policy is a commitment to an effective system of multilateral relations, at the heart of which is the UN. Fierce clashes are taking place on the doorstep of the Union. Europe is exposed to hybrid warfare, cyber-terrorism and one country or region is finding it increasingly difficult to find its way around a European security environment. Therefore, the idea is promoted that European defence and intelligence cooperation would not be a mere political choice but a strategic and economic necessity and to enhance cooperation with the UN in the areas of peace and security, terrorism, organised crime, regional conflicts, the disintegration of states and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.  I support this proposal for a recommendation from the European Parliament to the Council, as I believe that an effective system of multilateral relations is based on generally accepted rules and values, and is best suited to address global crises, challenges and threats. The Union is one of the greatest protectors and promoters of human rights, fundamental freedoms, cultural values and diversity, democracy and the rule of law, and cooperation with like-minded partners such as the UN can only bring new positive developments in all these fields.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the report by proposing a European Parliament recommendation to the Council on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. The European Union must play a proactive role in the United Nations, and EU Member States must strive for coordinated action within UN bodies and bodies. I support the Council's recommendation to continue to support multilateral efforts to find lasting and peaceful political solutions to the conflicts that are taking place in the Middle East and North Africa and to support the talks in Syria following the UN Security Council resolution.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU is cut off and wants to contribute to the solution of conflicts and crises in Syria, Libya, Yemen, Western Sahara, Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia, Somalia, Sudan, South Sudan, Mali, etc., but does not see it as an issue, which it should raise at the 71st Session, the Cyprus issue. It is worth noting that crises and conflicts in several of the above countries are the product of the policy of specific Member States. At the same time, the EU shows the need to get involved in matters concerning Russia and third countries, without having any competence to do so. It also wants to strengthen the presence of Europeans in peacekeeping missions, ignoring the consequences for human lives that this can bring. Indeed, in matters of security and terrorism, there must be cooperation, but we believe that the interventionist way of operating the EU will intensify rather than solve the various crises.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of parliament's recommendations to the Council, along which the EU and its Member States can take a position on current international issues during this year's 71st session of the UN General Assembly. The positions and priorities faithfully reflect the recent EU positions and European interests under the EU's Common Foreign and Security Policy. Among the issues highlighted for the future of Europe, the issue of the refugee crisis and migration as an international challenge and the need to address them with a joint global effort are given due prominence. Among other international issues, due to my mandate in the EP delegation on Ukraine, I have taken particular account of the formulation of the EU position on the situation in Ukraine.  I agree that our common position on supporting democratisation in Ukraine, the illegal annexation of Crimea and condemning military violence is reflected with sufficient firmness, specifically pointing to the need for further international pressure on Russia, a permanent BT member. I also support the eu's need for permanent BT membership at this session, as part of the UN reform. Overall, I considered that the recommendations adopted could serve the benefit of coordinated EU Member States' action at the 71st session of the UN General Assembly.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Every year the European Parliament sends recommendations to the Council for the annual meeting of the United Nations General Assembly. These recommendations are sent based on the three pillars of the United Nations, which are peace and security, human rights and development. This year`s amendments to the draft recommendations concern issues closely connected to the realities of today’s world, such as LGBTI rights, women’s representation at all levels of the decision-making process, zero tolerance for death penalty, and children`s rights. I support these amendments, as they address issues that are of great concern for myself and the Alliance of Socialists & Democrats.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. We must actively work to ensure that all parties directly or indirectly involved in armed conflict and their organizations fully respect their international obligations and the norms of public international law and advocate for peaceful and diplomatic solutions to conflicts of any kind, and to ensure that this approach also includes the obligation to ensure access to humanitarian aid for those in need. It is also necessary to continue to support multilateral efforts to find lasting political and peaceful solutions to the ongoing conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa, and to continue to support the work of the UN Special Envoy for Syria, the Special Representative and the Head of the UN Support Mission in Libya, the UN Secretary-General's Special Envoy for Yemen. , the UN Special Coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process and the UN Secretary-General's Special Representative for Western Sahara. We must call on the international community to continue humanitarian, financial and political assistance to address the humanitarian crisis, work towards an immediate end to the violence and condemn unilateral and uncoordinated actions in crisis zones.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation for the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly, which defines a list of common EU priorities on human rights, climate change, development and the active promotion of the rule of law and international humanitarian law for the next assembly of the UN. In addition to agreeing with the recommendations overall, I consider this to be an important step to strengthen Parliament’s voice on the global stage. I am particularly supportive of the establishment of a clear human-rights-performance based criteria for membership of the United Nations Human Rights Council as well as a comprehensive reform of the UN Security Council to reflect today’s realities and power balance.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union, through its Member States and the action of the High Representative, should support a comprehensive reform of the UNITED Nations Security Council on the basis of a broad consensus, in order to better reflect the new world reality and ensure that it is able to effectively manage threats to international peace and security. I voted whole much in favour of this report, because I believe that the medium-term objective of seeking an EU seat in a reformed UN Security Council should be pursued. This is an ambitious objective that will only be achieved if the European institutions and the Member States all work together to meet the enormous challenges we face on a daily basis, both in the Union and outside. The European Union is a well-established reality which must also be able to express its unified voice in the international arena.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The Union's foreign policy is based on the belief that a multilateral system based on generally accepted rules and values is best suited to address global crises, challenges and threats. Therefore, Member States of the European Union should play a proactive role in creating a United Nations that can effectively contribute to global solutions, peace and security, development, human rights, democracy and an international order based on the rule of law. I consider it necessary for members to make every effort to coordinate their actions within the organs and bodies of the United Nations system. However, the European Union is not a federal community and cannot represent the interests of all members. Each Member State of the Union should represent primarily its national interests. Therefore, I voted against this proposal.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the 71st session of the UN General Assembly. The latter deals with the Council's recommendations on peace and security, the fight against terrorism, non-proliferation and disarmament, migration, human rights, democracy and the rule of law, development, climate change and reforms of the UN system. The Council must continue to support multilateral attempts to find a lasting political and peaceful solution to the ongoing conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa. It must reiterate its unequivocal condemnation of terrorism and its full support for measures aimed at defeating and eradicating terrorist organisations, in particular ISIS. The Council must make a clear and strong commitment to the protection of human rights and stress that human rights are agreed within the framework of UN conventions universal, indivisible, interdependent and interconnected. The Council must also support the comprehensive reform of the UN Security Council and promote the revival of the work of the General Assembly and better cooperation and coordination between all UN institutions.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from this vote as I advocate a multilateral approach to international relations, which favours dialogue and horizontal cooperation between States and actors in international relations, to the detriment of strategic-military solutions. I am in favour of a restructuring of the United Nations and its Security Council, but not in the sense of consolidating its character as an exclusive and exclusionary club dominated by economic and military powers, but instead promoting and effectively promoting and enabling an equitable system of representation and decision-making to move towards a new world order based on justice , democracy, respect for human rights, joint approach to great global ills, preservation of global public goods and peace.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution. In particular, I welcome UN action in order to combat terrorism, which is such an urgent and increasing problems affecting our countries. It will affect our children for sure. Therefore I hope for and welcome all actions aimed at the defeat and eradication of terrorist organisations, in particular, the so-called 'ISIS/Daesh', which poses a clear threat to regional and international security. I support the promotion of all aspects of Security Council Resolution 2178 (2014) on countering threats posed by foreign terrorist fighters and of the Madrid Guiding Principles on stemming the flow of foreign terrorist fighters. The UN should step up efforts to clamp down on recruitment and fight terrorist propaganda through social media platforms but also through networks of radicalised hate preachers; and to support counter-radicalisation and de-radicalisation policies in line with the UN Plan of Action to Prevent Violent Extremism. The EU should continue to work with the UN in combating the financing of terrorism, including the use of existing mechanisms to designate terrorist individuals and organisations and strengthen asset-freezing mechanisms worldwide.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This text outlines the EU's objectives for the next session of the UN General Assembly, and it is clear that its intention is to take over the French seat on the Security Council. So I voted against the text.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I believe that working with the United Nations and other international organisations to jointly address foreign policy, security and humanitarian challenges is an integral part of our efforts, and I also agree with the UN reform that will improve its functioning in the face of today's crises. European countries should have their own mandates at the UN, which is why I did not support this resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from this vote as I advocate a multilateral approach to international relations, which favours dialogue and horizontal cooperation between States and actors in international relations, to the detriment of strategic-military solutions. I am in favour of a restructuring of the United Nations and its Security Council, but not in the sense of consolidating its character as an exclusive and exclusionary club dominated by economic and military powers, but instead promoting and effectively promoting and enabling an equitable system of representation and decision-making to move towards a new world order based on justice , democracy, respect for human rights, joint approach to great global ills, preservation of global public goods and peace.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the increase in Member States' support for UN peacekeeping and peace-building operations, which include the human rights component. Further develop the eu common security and defence policy procedures in support of UN operations, including the deployment or capacity building of EU battlegroups and security sector reform initiatives, while paying sufficient attention to issues such as human rights, sustainable development and the causes of mass migration.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report with a proposal for a European Parliament recommendation to the Council on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. The report underlines the importance of undertaking active steps to ensure that all parties directly or indirectly involved in armed conflicts and their organisations comply in full with their international obligations and the standards laid down in international law in order to secure peaceful, diplomatic solutions to conflicts of all kinds. I voted in favour because I strongly believe that it is of crucial importance to promote a culture of prevention within the UN system in order to improve its capacity to respond more quickly to emerging crises and potential threats to peace and security.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In this report, Parliament addresses to the Council recommendations on peace, security, the fight against terrorism, non-proliferation and disarmament, migration, human rights, democracy, the rule of law, development, climate change and reform of the United Nations system. We are therefore talking about a full report which has enjoyed broad consensus in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, so I consider it necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While Member States are urged to support the UN resolution "Effects of the Use of Weapons and Ammunition Containing Depleted Uranium" and advocates greater efforts to protect the rights of religious and other minorities, it has interventionist and interferenceting approaches to the Crimean conflict, nor is it emphasized the need to rethink the current functioning of the UN Security Council , so I abstained.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report, in which Parliament sets its position before the commencement of the 71st United Nations General Assembly. The EU should play a more proactive role in the functioning of the United Nations on global solutions, peace, security, development, human rights, democracy and an international order based on the principles of the rule of law. One of the concerns is certainly to step up efforts to combat the recruitment of young jihadis and to combat terrorist propaganda on social media platforms, as well as through networks of radicalised hate preachers.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. As every year, the European Parliament adopted a resolution to the Council on the EU's priorities for the 71st session of the UN General Assembly. This resolution is, as is often the case, paved with good intentions. In particular, it promotes a "culture of prevention" of conflicts with the idea of more diplomacy and stresses the need to investigate cases of sexual abuse (including the French case). On migration, it plans to strengthen the budget of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and is addressing the legal vacuum surrounding the concept of "climate refugee". Nevertheless, some positions are not acceptable, starting with the desire to increase pressure on Russia following its "illegal annexation" of Crimea. This only exacerbates the situation and reinforces the logic of confrontation between the two blocs. Worse, the resolution proposes to develop European military interventions and prevent irregular migration, which is of course part of an ever more secure logic. In short, a mixed record for this resolution on which I have therefore decided to abstain.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is based on a contextualisation of the global and regional situation which, in the rapporteur's view, is in sharp deterioration, exposes those that are the threats to the security of the European Union and is addressing the strengthening of European militarism with a view to pursuing a European Security Strategy, calling them "challenges": violent conflicts, terrorism, organised crime , unprecedented migration, climate change, hybrid warfare and information, cyberthreats, bioengineering, lethal autonomous systems, nanotechnologies, miniaturisation of weapons systems and the proliferation of dual-use technologies.  It is ironic to have the EU say that it promotes environmental sustainability, when it is precisely the opposite. The intention of the European Union's policies is to put the supposed protection of the environment at the service of the market and business.  It is a shame that the European Union considers itself a staunch human rights defender when it whistles to the side of the Odessa Massacre and supports fascist and murderous regimes; or when it treats the refugee crisis as it treats. It's to see what's going on in Denmark, France or Hungary and Austria.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This proposal lacks concrete steps, ideas and measures. Member States were asked to support the United Nations, which failed at the level of peacekeeping and peace-building. I shall therefore abstain from voting.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it covers a range of topics including peace and security, the fight against terrorism, human rights, development and reform of the UN system. It contains many helpful and timely recommendations, including calls for enhanced cooperation on migration, to work towards the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals and to promote the full implementation of the Arms Trade Treaty.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report by Mr Kovacchev, chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, which mentions a comprehensive framework for peace and security, the fight against terrorism, human rights and the rule of law, democracy, migration, development and climate change. The text refers in particular to the conflict in the Middle East and the situation in Syria.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Kovatchev report because I agree with the proposals put forward for the programme of the 71st United Nations General Assembly, in particular on the issue of migration. I believe it is crucial to promote greater support for the activities of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in the implementation of its international mandate to protect refugees, paying particular attention to vulnerable groups such as women and children. This will require more funding to provide the UNHCR. I would also like to point out that the EU and its Member States collectively represent the largest individual financial contributor to the UN system, providing about one third of the regular UN budget, almost two-fifths of the UN peacekeeping budget and about half of all contributions to its funds and programmes. The EU's commitment to effective multilateralism and good global governance, centred on the United Nations, is an integral part of THE EU's foreign policy and is based on the conviction that a multilateral system based on universal rules and values, which must be respected and observed, is best suited to addressing global crises, challenges and threats.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the report by proposing a European Parliament recommendation to the Council on the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly. Global and regional security is rapidly deteriorating and becoming more complex. The UN plays a key role in ensuring security and stability around the world, so EU Member States should make every effort to coordinate their actions in the bodies and bodies of the United Nations system. The European Parliament recommendation thus contains key points for the Council to ensure peace and security, in the areas of combating terrorism, disarmament and respect for human rights, the principles of democracy and the rule of law.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I fully supported the report on the UN Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities. That is because it is the first international convention ratified by the European Union. We have had an excellent debate in this Chamber today, and I do not want to repeat what has been said, but I would like to draw attention to one part, which is the need to make the 112 emergency number accessible. Unfortunately, today, today in the European Union, deaf and hard-of-hearing citizens are unable to access this, to seek help from themselves, to their family members, or to any other person. It is important that today's vote puts pressure on the European Commission to initiate this change as soon as possible in this area.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of the report on the rights of persons with disabilities, but I did have a sense of absence. Mainly because, although we are talking about the rights of people with disabilities, there is very little call for real enforcement in the report. In particular, point 42 of the report deals with petitions submitted to the Committee on Petitions of the European Parliament here by people with disabilities who have had manifest infringements in the so-called 'invalidity procedure'. That's what happened in my country, where people with long-standing disabilities, incapacitated persons, some percentage of whom are incapacitated, have reportedly been subjected to extremely degrading procedures which have been expressly unlawful in many cases, and here the report only gives them some kind of buksi caressing, rather than saying that they should exercise their rights, be qualified lawyers who specialise in such matters, cases with disabilities, and take these outrageous cases to the court and the relevant legal bodies.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with today's vote, this House confirms its commitment to combating all forms of discrimination. There is no hierarchy of human rights and discrimination based on disability must deserve the same attention and benefit from the same prevention and safeguards.  We have recalled that the inclusion of people with disabilities is not only a right and a well-deserved benefit for those concerned but also a resource for society as a whole. But not enough is being done either in terms of preventing discrimination based on disability, let alone in terms of adequate support for their families.  It is essential that all EU policies and programmes, both externally and internally, comply with the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and establish specific measures to ensure that these rights are integrated into all areas, including humanitarian and development policies and programmes.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís vótáil mé i bhfabhar an tuarascáil seo mar a rinne an chuid is mó de na Feisirí. Ní nach ionadh. Agus ghlac mé páirt sa díospóireacht anseo ar maidin. Bhí an-díospóireacht againn. Agus mé ag caint luaigh mé agus feisire Becker an tábhacht a bhaineann le spórt chun cabhrú le daoine a bhfuil máchail orthu agus bhí áthas orm nuair a bhí an Coimisinéir Mogherini ag freagairt gur luaigh sí an pointe sin agus go ndúirt sí go ndéanfaidh sí gach rud chun cabhrú go háirithe na Cluichí Parailimpeacha an bhliain seo chugainn maidir le hairgead a thabhairt dóibh agus cabhair a thabhairt dóibh agus i mo thír féin feicim go bhfuil mórán á dhéanamh ag a lán daoine go deonach chun áiseanna agus comórtais a chur ar fáil do dhaoine a bhfuil máchail orthu. Dá bhrí sin is ceart é sin a aithint agus a mholadh. Agus freisin is dóigh liom nár luamar an pháirt atá á déanamh agus á glacadh ag múinteoirí sna scoileanna mar a bhfuil daoine speisialta mar sin ann agus is fiú é sin a aithint agus a mholadh chomh maith.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Madam Presidencies, I supported colleague Stevens' report because many different opinions were made by different committees in the European Parliament. I personally worked as a shadow rapporteur on the Committee on Culture and Education. In this direction, I would like to stress that there is still much work to be done to achieve the full integration and entry of persons with disabilities into social life. But it definitely starts at school with the right to education, access to free movement, non-discrimination and access to justice. I very much hope that the Commission and the Member States will work together to swiftly ratify the Marrakesh Treaty. I highly appreciate the rapporteur's work and his approach to respecting the principle of subsidiarity, and I believe that a good balance has been struck between the competences of the Member States, those of the European Union and the calls made in the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: –  Madam President, people in Ireland have been waiting over nine years for Ireland to ratify the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. On Monday, 30 March 2007 Ireland signed this Convention but, nine years later, people with disabilities are still awaiting the ratification of this Convention. The Convention itself has a right—based approach, and people with disabilities in Ireland have to be able to vindicate those rights. All other EU countries have now ratified this Convention; we are the very last. I know that the Independent Alliance have included the Convention in the programme for government, and I applaud this, but I am saying that we need action now.  Also, we have a situation in Ireland where young persons with disabilities cannot access a European programme called the Youth Guarantee. I have lodged a complaint with the European Commission, but right now we could change this in Ireland and ensure that young people with disabilities who are on disability benefit or on disability allowance can access the Youth Guarantee the same as all other young people.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am glad that this Convention was the first to be ratified by the European Union, and we were therefore also able to join it as a Union, as a body, because it is a consequence of the Treaty of Lisbon, which allows the Union to enter into legal relations as a legal entity. That's just the edge.  I would like to say that, of course, we all support the inclusion of people with disabilities in society. However, these people do not only want to hear these words of support, but also want to see a proactive approach as well as assurances that they are valid members of society.  And I think we can make it easier for them to move around in everyday life. For example, when municipalities build sidewalks, you wouldn't even believe how many problems there are associated with crossing the barrier and building sidewalks with reduced rampage. That's just one of the things that's perfectly practical. I think that we should bring those words to life, into everyday reality, and make them really practice, not just theory.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2010, the European Union acceded to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. However, there are still particular problems connected with the practical implementation of the Convention, particularly as regards the limits of European competence. The key points on which the report focuses are: free access for people with disabilities to the world of work; the removal of architectural barriers and, finally, the definition of a system of social protection that allows an adequate standard of living. Since I believe it is right that the European institutions should work to improve the daily lives of all citizens, without distinction, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the first human rights treaty of the 21st century and the first to sign the Union as a whole.  Today we voted on Parliament's response to the Committee's Conclusions on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, as well as the steps we believe should be taken to implement it. And in this report both content and forms are important, because organizations of people with disabilities have been involved throughout the process.  The labour market share of persons with disabilities is 58.5%, compared to 80.5%, of people without disabilities. And these figures are even worse for women, at 44%. Therefore, among all the proposals in the report, I would like to highlight one which calls for support for people's independent lives, equal opportunities and equal access to digital society. It is necessary for the Council to end once and for all the blocking of the Anti-Discrimination Directive and the Marrakesh Treaty.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-binding and non-legislative report. The report was regarding the implementation of a UN convention on the rights of persons with disabilities. However the report also called for setting standards of social protection measures at EU level. While of course UKIP supports the rights of disabled people, it should only be for elected national governments, in compliance with international law, to decide social protection policy.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is one of the most important human rights conventions and the first signed by the European Union as a whole. For its implementation, this report requires that accessibility legislation be implemented, that EU-funded programmes and projects comply with this Convention, and that a structured dialogue be established with organisations representing persons with disabilities. For us these rights are fundamental to achieving a just society with equality for people with disabilities, so we voted in favour of the text.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This is an initiative report to enable the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.  Blocked in the Council for 8 years, the anti-discrimination directive would thus find an indirect outcome. The Council would then be obliged to implement decisions on the EU's accession to the Convention in 2010 as a whole.  The idea is generous and seems positive at first. However, on closer inspection, the initiative here is to accentuate the role of the Commission by forcing the Council, on a (social) subject outside its direct competence, to have the Union regarded as a State in its own right. Many stumbling blocks lie, moreover, in the divergent definitions between states of the concepts of disability, reasonable development of public and private places, etc. Finally, this report extends the concepts of disability to gender equality or to the reception of migrants.  We are opposed to the EU's approach to disability policy and its systematic pretexts for extending it to other concepts.  I therefore objected to this report.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which incorporated a number of proposals that I put forward as author of the associated opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE).  The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) was ratified by the EU in 2010, covering a large range of rights for people with disabilities, ranging from the workplace to transport. Accession means the EU is now scrutinised by the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.  The CPRD Committee published its concluding observations on the initial report of the EU in August 2015, which require the Commission to respond with a report within a year. The purpose of this own-initiative report is to ensure that Parliament’s views are taken into account in the Commission’s response (due in September). Among other things, the report calls for the EU to ratify the Optional Protocol to the CRPD, welcomes the proposal for a European Accessibility Act and calls for its swift adoption. It calls on the Commission to review the European Disability Strategy and develop a new EU CPRD strategy; and calls for a review of all EU legislation and funding programmes to ensure full compliance and implementation with the CPRD.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. People with disabilities are often excluded from society as a whole and deprived of their human rights. Together with the Socialists and Democrats group, we are committed to promoting, defending and strengthening the human rights of all people with disabilities. All these people, regardless of their type of disability, are full citizens and must be able to enjoy the same human rights and fundamental freedoms as other citizens.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report concerning the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The EU acceded to the UN Convention in December 2010. With its ratification, the EU is now subject to scrutiny by the Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The CRPD covers a large range of rights, spanning all areas of life, some of which fall outside of the competence of the EU. Therefore, Member States are required to equally implement the Convention at all levels, including regional and national. There is no hierarchy of human rights, and disability-based discrimination must be tackled; this is especially important for women and children with disabilities, older persons and individuals who have complex support needs, including those with intellectual and psycho-social disabilities.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the UNITED NATIONS Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with particular emphasis on the concluding remarks of the UN CPRD Committee, because I believe that all persons with disabilities should enjoy all human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities entered into force in 2010 and is the first international human rights treaty to be ratified by the EU as a whole. The Convention covers a wide range of rights that extend to all areas of life, some of which are outside the EU's competence. Member States are therefore obliged to implement the UN Convention accordingly at all levels, including at regional and national level. The report is addressed to the EU institutions, which are to take the lead in the implementation of the Convention. The Convention is an important step against discrimination, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I am obviously in favour of the proper integration of people with disabilities into society and an improvement in their well-being; If we cannot oppose the implementation of a convention already signed, in accordance with international law, I strongly oppose the implementation strategy proposed by the Commission in this initiative report and the very approach to disability that is made of it. That is why I voted against this report, its dogmatic vision and its subjective conception of disability.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 THE EU joined the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in 2010. Following the accession to the Convention, the EU, like the other Parties to the Convention, was required to submit an initial report on the implementation of the Convention. The purpose of this report is to examine, in particular, the issues raised in the final observations of the report. The focus is on the EU institutions themselves, as they must serve as an example of how the Convention needs to be implemented. Recalls that the full inclusion of persons with disabilities is not only the right of the persons concerned and what belongs to them, but also benefits for society as a whole, as it can bring the values and different skills provided by these individuals. The inclusion of persons with disabilities in society, regardless of the country's social, economic, political or cultural status, is not only a matter of development, but also of human rights. I support the calls on Parliament, the Council and the Commission to fully implement the recommendations of the UN CRPD Committee and to ensure that this convention is respected in all future legislation.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the implementation of the Un Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNDP), which aims to reduce inequalities between people with disabilities and other citizens by integrating them into all areas of society.  However, this report is disconnected from reality, defending a logic of systematic integration while parents of disabled people themselves demand more specialized structures for the care of their children.  Moreover, the bias of the text, which in the name of a member's incapacity gives the Commission full power, does not give the best ways to help people with disabilities. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This report, which I approved, is an opportunity to remind people with disabilities that they have the right to live in a society where they have the same opportunities as other citizens to ensure their full integration and participation. The EU and Member States must take measures to ensure the implementation of the rights of people with disabilities, the promotion of their autonomy, accessibility, employment and social integration. This includes the end of austerity policies, which we know are the most vulnerable. It is time to revive social investment. It is also time for respect for the rights of people with disabilities to be addressed in the work of the European Semester. Improving the consideration of their rights also requires a permanent and structured dialogue with organizations representing people with disabilities. Finally, I would like to stress the importance of informing not only about the rights but also about the talents of people with disabilities, which are a real asset for our society.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. This report aims at the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. I voted in favour because I believe it reflects the ambition with which this issue must be addressed in order to end the discrimination that millions of disabled Europeans still suffer today. Disability should be treated in the same way as discrimination on other grounds. At the same time, specific measures are needed for citizens who may be double-discriminated against, such as women and children. In this sense, I like the attention this document devotes to disabled women who are in a situation of double discrimination, due to the specificities of diseases they suffer such as fibromyalgia or endometriosis. The report also denounces the damage caused by social spending cuts, as there are negative consequences for the lives of the disabled, and to prevent their inclusion and equal opportunities. The European institutions and the Member States have in their power to build a Europe accessible to all citizens. The Commission must provide concrete solutions, as a matter of urgency, such as the signing of the Marrakesh Treaty.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are 80 million people with disabilities in the European Union, about 15% of the entire population. According to Articles 21 and 26 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, they are protected from discrimination and guaranteed equal participation in community life. The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the first international human rights treaty ratified by the EU and represents a key step forward in protecting their privacy. The text voted on today by Parliament and which I strongly supported is the result of the work of eleven parliamentary committees and extensive consultations with civil society and organisations representing people with disabilities. We need a joint effort to remove all the obstacles that prevent people with disabilities from enjoying their rights to the full, but the path taken is the right one and also involves criticism of the austerity cuts that have affected precisely the most disadvantaged groups.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has a progressive and positive approach to persons with disabilities, including the gender and rights approach of girls with disabilities and a recognition of the role that the economic crisis has played in devaluing the provision of quality services for people with disabilities. The objective of this initiative report is to respond to the list of recommendations of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, ensuring that the views of the European Parliament are considered in the report of the European Commission (to be submitted in September). Among other things, the report invites the Union to ratify the Optional Protocol to the Convention, welcomes the proposal for a European Accessibility Law and calls for its rapid adoption, calls on the Commission to review the European Disability Strategy and develop a new Union strategy on the CDPD and a revision of legislation to ensure full compliance and implementation of the CDPD.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. The figures are sobering: 15% of the world's population, or approximately one billion people, live with a disability. 80% of these people live in low-income countries. 50% of disabilities can be prevented and are due to poverty. About 98% of children with disabilities living in developing countries do not attend school. In Europe, there are 80 million people with disabilities, representing one-sixth of the population. According to the ILO, the unemployment rate for people with disabilities can reach 80% in some countries.  People with disabilities are too often marginalized and discrimination against them takes many forms, from denial of educational opportunities to exclusion and isolation.  So yes, we must act to at least try to reverse the trend, if not to profoundly change mentalities and mores. Even if the proposed text does not win my support on all its points, I will always be in favour of texts which aim to eliminate discrimination against persons with disabilities in all areas of life.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. In a week full of reasons to regret that European construction is not progressing faster, this report resulting from the Accession of the European Union to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is a source of hope. In a matter of respect for fundamental rights, 26 Member States have joined, we have managed to get up to ten parliamentary committees to contribute their views to the report and there is a strong political will to continue improving legislation and policies on the road to equality for persons with disabilities. A topic in which sensitivity and will are perceived. An effort that improves us, is useful and builds Europe. Being different," one person once told me from a wheelchair, doesn't mean being unequal. That is why this collective commitment to this cause must be celebrated today. Let us hope that in the field of the language of terminology we will speak in the future of functional diversity, an expression that we include in our amendments, which also builds equality.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report should help reduce inequalities between people with disabilities and other citizens through the fight against discrimination and their integration into all areas of society.  The current problem is that the Anti-Discrimination Framework Directive has been blocked in the Council for 8 years, in particular on the definition of the term "disability" by states. The EU joined the UNCLOS in 2010, further enhancing the Commission's role at the expense of states.  The concerns in this report include misguided objectives (it talks about migrants, such as the type,200), confusion over the term 'disability' or the inability of States to deal with this issue and therefore the need for the Commission to take action.  Deeply committed to the fight against injustice and the inclusion of people with disabilities in society, whether it is in the school, professional, cultural, leisure or simply private life, I think it is important to support all initiatives in this direction and towards greater equality between citizens. On the other hand, the convention has already been signed, but I remain dubious about parts of the strategy proposed by the Commission. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is well thought out and I support it. Finally, the EU is moving towards a development in the concept of protecting the disabled, which until now has been limited to protection and care, while attention is now being paid to an approach to disability aimed at ensuring the active participation of disabled people in our society. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the first human rights treaty of the 21st century and the first to sign the Union as a whole.  Today we voted on Parliament's response to the Committee's Conclusions on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, as well as the steps we believe should be taken to implement it. And in this report both content and forms are important, because organizations of people with disabilities have been involved throughout the process.  The labour market share of persons with disabilities is 58.5%, compared to 80.5%, of people without disabilities. And these figures are even worse for women, at 44%. Therefore, among all the proposals in the report, I would like to highlight one which calls for support for people's independent lives, equal opportunities and equal access to digital society. It is necessary for the Council to end once and for all the blocking of the Anti-Discrimination Directive and the Marrakesh Treaty.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The European Union acceded to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in December 2010. and was the first signatory to the Convention of Regional Integration. Following accession to the Convention, the EU, like the other Parties to the Convention, was required to submit an initial report and further periodic reports had to be submitted every four years. The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities stands out from other human rights treaties because disabled people and their representative organisations have been involved in the process since the start of the convention. To this end, the Joint Working Party on the Protection of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, in cooperation with the European Disability Forum, organised a meeting of the Joint Working Party to hear the views of the European Disability Forum and its members' organisations. Their contribution in writing and orally is included in the working document and draft report. The Convention covers a wide range of rights, such as inclusion in society, economic, freedom of movement for EU citizens and other rights relating to all areas of life, and some do not fall within the EU's remit. It is therefore necessary for Member States to implement this crucial Convention at all levels, including at regional and national level.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities provides a comprehensive picture of the situation and the difficulties encountered. In this connection, I would like to recall that persons with disabilities are often outside or do not have effective access to education and training services where personalised education processes taking into account the level of their disability are needed. They should therefore be supported in unlocking their social, economic and educational potential. I underline the need to take the necessary measures to ensure that all students with disabilities benefit from the benefits of reasonable accommodation, which is necessary to exercise their right to inclusive, quality education. Member States and responsible regional and local authorities should be encouraged to strengthen their training programmes for all stakeholders involved in non-formal and informal learning. In doing so, they contribute to their role in overcoming prejudice in schools against people with disabilities, in particular those with intellectual and psychosocial disabilities. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the proposed report on the implementation of the UN Convention on Rights. In December 2010, the EU acceded to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities as the first organisation. It is the first and so far the only international human rights treaty that has been ratified by the EU as a whole. After accession, the EU, like other Contracting States, had to submit an initial report on the state of implementation of the Convention, and further regular reports should be drawn up every four years. In particular, this report aims to focus on the work of the EU institutions, which must lead by example in the implementation of the Convention. I agree with the rapporteur, my colleague Stevens, that there is no hierarchy in human rights and that discrimination on grounds of disability should be treated as all other forms of discrimination. This is particularly important for women and children with disabilities, the elderly and individuals with multifaceted support needs, including those with special needs in the intellectual and psychosocial fields.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 People with disabilities are often excluded from society and for this reason the European Union has committed itself to fully respecting their rights by having adhered to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) in 2010. The S&D Group and the European Parliament have always fought against discrimination and to defend and reinforce the human rights and fundamental freedoms of these people. The report stresses the need to better define the obstacles that individual Member States may encounter in applying the Convention and the need to take greater account of the specific rights and obligations of disabled people in the various sectors in order to guarantee them the easiest and most independent life possible. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this Report on the Implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.  People with disabilities are often excluded from society and denied their basic human rights. I believe that we must all work further to promote, harvest and strengthen the human rights of all people with disabilities. All persons with all kinds of disabilities must enjoy all human rights and fundamental human freedoms.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. While I am obviously in favour of the proper integration of people with disabilities into society, and an improvement in their well-being, and if I cannot oppose the implementation of a convention already signed, in accordance with international law, I am firmly opposed to the open-end implementation strategy as proposed to the Commission in this initiative report. , and the very approach to disability, because of its lack of objectivity in the very definition of disability.  I therefore vote against this report.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which incorporated proposals from my Sinn Féin colleague Martina Anderson who authored the associated opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE).  The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) was ratified by the EU in 2010, covering a large range of rights for people with disabilities, ranging from the workplace to transport. Accession means the EU is now scrutinised by the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The CPRD Committee published its concluding observations on the initial report of the EU in August 2015, which require the Commission to respond with a report within a year. The purpose of this own-initiative report is to ensure that Parliament’s views are taken into account in the Commission’s response (due in September). Among other things, the report calls for the EU to ratify the Optional Protocol to the CRPD, welcomes the proposal for a European Accessibility Act and calls for its swift adoption. It calls on the Commission to review the European Disability Strategy and develop a new EU CPRD strategy; and calls for a review of all EU legislation and funding programmes to ensure full compliance and implementation with the CPRD.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Around 80 million people in Europe have disabilities. It is a category of citizens that is all too often discriminated against and marginalised, but which has the full right to a worthy, independent, autonomous life, as well as to full participation in our societies.  These are people who are all too often not adequately supported and who are unfortunately too easily regarded as a burden, when, instead, in everyday reality, they contribute greatly to enriching, materially and culturally, our communities.  With a view to raising awareness and protecting the rights of persons with disabilities, as well as in accordance with Article 19 TFEI and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the European Union has acceded to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. In this respect, I hope that the Union and its Member States will be fully and increasingly involved in the application of the provisions of the Convention in question. If we are going in the right direction overall, however, much remains to be done: for this reason, I hope that the EU will ratify the optional protocol to the Convention, as well as the inclusion of the rights of persons with disabilities in the Europe 2020 strategy and in the European Semester.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to determine how the European Union will implement the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which aims to reduce inequalities between people with disabilities and other citizens.  I objected to this text for two reasons. On the one hand, this report makes recommendations to facilitate the social inclusion of illegal migrants while the Convention deals with the integration of persons with disabilities. On the other hand, this report appears to be very critical of the Member States, as to their ability or even their willingness to manage the problem of disability in their society, with the sole aim of making the European Union legitimate to deal with this issue.  In short, while we are obviously in favour of the proper integration of people with disabilities into society and an improvement in their well-being, we are opposed, on the other hand, to the European Commission's strategy for implementing this convention. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is different from other human rights treaties in that persons with disabilities and their representative organisations have been included in the process at the stages of development, so there is no hierarchy of human rights and discrimination on the basis of disability must be addressed as well as discrimination on other grounds including multiple discrimination. As regards equal treatment, it is understood to be discrimination not to provide adequate accommodation, since the Equal Treatment Directive does not refer to this and is therefore not in conformity with the Convention in these respects. We voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, considering the need for people with disabilities to be much more closely supervised and cared for, but not least we must fight for the disappearance of the discrimination to which they are subjected.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 One in six people in the European Union suffers from a disability whose degree varies between easy and severe. The EU has acceded to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and, following the conclusion of the ratification process, the EU is the first international organisation to become an official party to the Convention. The Convention obliges the parties to ensure that persons with disabilities can exercise their rights fully on an equal basis with all other citizens. For the EU, this means ensuring that all Community legislation, policies and programmes comply with the provisions of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, within the limits of EU competences. I support the EP report because I believe that, even now, as a result of all the Union's efforts, these people are prevented from participating fully in society and the economy because of physical or other obstacles, as well as discrimination. The EU must step up its efforts to promote a safe and conducive environment, also taking into account the concerns of the UNCRPD Committee about the lack of a clear Union strategy for the implementation of the Convention.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the first human rights treaty of the 21st century and the first to sign the Union as a whole.  Today we voted on Parliament's response to the Committee's Conclusions on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, as well as the steps we believe should be taken to implement it. And in this report both content and forms are important, because organizations of people with disabilities have been involved throughout the process.
