The labour market share of persons with disabilities is 58.5%, compared to 80.5%, of people without disabilities. And these figures are even worse for women, at 44%. Therefore, among all the proposals in the report, I would like to highlight one which calls for support for people's independent lives, equal opportunities and equal access to digital society. It is necessary for the Council to end once and for all the blocking of the Anti-Discrimination Directive and the Marrakesh Treaty.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. It is the first international human rights treaty that the European Union ratifies as an entity. The 26 Member States that have ratified the convention are also required to implement it. The convention covers a wide range of rights in all areas of life. All people with disabilities must be able to live in a society where they have the same opportunities as other citizens. This is the condition of their integration.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities because it is a document of the utmost importance for the promotion of a new culture regarding the situation of people with disabilities and their families. However, social, cultural, scientific and economic dynamics require that a regulatory system, however advanced, implement, in a timely manner, processes for updating and reviewing the instruments at its disposal, in order to increase, at all levels, the social inclusion of people with disabilities. Furthermore, standards alone are not enough; all too often they remain a dead letter. We need policies, cultural policies, because the culture of rights must be regained every day. Unfortunately, disabled people still face a wide range of obstacles preventing them from making progress towards equal opportunities, independence and full social and economic integration. Although the Union has responded to this challenge by taking a number of legal and political initiatives to remove these obstacles, there is still a long way to go. It is time for the European Union to make a firm commitment to the full implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which incorporated proposals from my Sinn Féin colleague Martina Anderson who authored the associated opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE).  The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) was ratified by the EU in 2010, covering a large range of rights for people with disabilities, ranging from the workplace to transport. Accession means the EU is now scrutinised by the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The CPRD Committee published its concluding observations on the initial report of the EU in August 2015, which require the Commission to respond with a report within a year. The purpose of this own-initiative report is to ensure that Parliament’s views are taken into account in the Commission’s response (due in September). Among other things, the report calls for the EU to ratify the Optional Protocol to the CRPD, welcomes the proposal for a European Accessibility Act and calls for its swift adoption. It calls on the Commission to review the European Disability Strategy and develop a new EU CPRD strategy; and calls for a review of all EU legislation and funding programmes to ensure full compliance and implementation with the CPRD.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report to welcome the EU’s efforts regarding the promotion and better implementation of human rights, especially, the rights of persons with disabilities. The ratification of the Convention marks an important step towards the full integration of people with disabilities into our societies and towards the full implementation of their rights. I encourage the initiatives to help people with disabilities to become more independent through employment, education and in all other areas of life.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU acceded to the UN Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities (CRPD) in December 2010; it makes the EU subject to the control of the Committee on the Rights of People with Disabilities (CRPD Committee). The report focuses on the issues highlighted in the conclusions of the CRPD Committee. The M5S Europe has contributed with its amendments: ensuring full accessibility in the labour market, education and training programmes, Erasmus+, establishing a social protection base in the EU, respecting the right to an adequate standard of living and social protection, etc. The M5S delegation therefore voted in favour.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The committee's concluding remarks on the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) highlight the various critical issues that still persist for full and equal participation in society, services, facilities and work of disabled people. It is estimated that around 80 million people in Europe have disabilities, of which only 48% have found employment. Although the Convention has proved to be a useful tool for promoting legislative reforms within the countries of the Union, we are still a long way from achieving an inclusive society for people with disabilities and we must therefore continue along the path we have embarked upon by providing support and protection to families as well. The report voted on in plenary, on which I voted in favour, clearly identifies the actions to be taken at both European and national level if the objective of a Europe in which all people can fully enjoy human rights and fundamental freedoms is to be achieved, and I trust that disabled boys and girls will soon be able to participate in European mobility and exchange programmes such as Erasmus+. That would be an important signal that the Union could give to all Member States.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. – We support the report and stress the role of the EU institutions, which must play an exemplary role in the implementation of the Convention. At the heart of this process are, inter alia, staff regulations, staff appointment and retention practices, and public events organised by the European Parliament and on the premises of the European Parliament.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with particular emphasis on the concluding remarks of the UN CPRD Committee, is an important process of accepting and supporting those already agreed at the highest transnational level. As Europe must take the lead in efforts to protect people with disabilities, I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted positively on the 'report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities' as I believe that the European Union must combat discrimination through the definition and implementation of its policies and activities. I also believe that the institutions of the European Union themselves must be an example in the implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am convinced that the accession of the European Union to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) has shown that the European Union strongly believes that discrimination of all kinds must be combated. I believe that the Eu ropean Union as such must be an example in terms of respect for and promotion of human rights, and i therefore believe that the European institutions must work to ensure that existing and future legislation respects human rights and complies fully with the CRPD. I therefore agree with this proposal, which aims to combat discrimination, particularly against people with disabilities and women, and I believe that it is important for the institutions to follow this line. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported this report, on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) is the first international human rights treaty ratified by the EU and has also been signed by 28 EU Member States. The Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union explicitly prohibits discrimination on grounds of disability and ensures equal participation in the society of persons with disabilities. I support the Helga Stevens report because It considers it necessary to pass the European Accessibility Act to address problems relating to accessibility for people with reduced mobility in transport, mobility and tourism. I highlight the need for cooperation between Member States and the Commission to draw up a clear and effective Directive on the accessibility of public sector bodies' websites, as well as to ensure that the European emergency number 112 is fully accessible and reliable, in particular for deaf and hearing impaired people. I regret that the Council has not yet adopted the proposal for a 2008 Directive applying the principle of equal treatment of persons, regardless of their religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation, and the Council should do so as soon as possible;

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I warmly welcome the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Unfortunately, people with disabilities are still discriminated against and excluded here and now. In our report on the state of implementation of the UN Convention, we highlight the need for further measures to be taken at EU level and also at Member State level: in the area of freedom of movement, healthcare and education, or access to information and communications in accessible formats and technologies, we are still a long way from being treated on an equal footing.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the implementation of the UN Convention on Persons with Disabilities, because as full citizens, all persons with disabilities have equal rights, including those inalienable to dignity, equal treatment, independent living, autonomy, support from publicly funded systems and full participation in society. It is necessary to promote, protect and monitor the implementation of the CRPD at national level in order to ensure full respect for human rights and the principle of equal treatment of disabled people, to whom reasonable solutions must also be ensured in terms of employment.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is one of the most important human rights conventions and the first signed by the European Union as a whole. For its implementation, this report requires that accessibility legislation be implemented, that EU-funded programmes and projects comply with this Convention, and that a structured dialogue be established with organisations representing persons with disabilities. For us these rights are fundamental to achieving a just society with equality for people with disabilities, so we voted in favour of the text.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. There are around 80 million citizens with disabilities in the EU, a large part of whom are women, with the result that they are victims of multiple discrimination. The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the first international human rights treaty ratified by the EU, signed by all Member States. In addition, the concluding remarks of the Convention Monitoring Committee have already been positive about the EU's commitment to equality and respect for human rights. By voting in favour, I intend to support the European commitment that, in accordance with the principles of the Convention, all persons with disabilities and their families should fully enjoy human rights in an inclusive society. I believe it is essential to focus on the gender dimension \u2012 women with disabilities and mothers of children with disabilities – and on the rights of children with disabilities, who are all too often victims of violence, neglect and abuse. Disability can expose those affected by disability to poverty and discrimination in the labour market, and it is up to the European Union to integrate the disability dimension into its gender and child-related policies and programmes and the gender and child perspective in its disability strategies.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In December 2010, the EU acceded to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, thus becoming the first signatory regional integration organisation, representing the first international human rights treaty ratified by the EU as a single entity. Currently, all 28 EU Member States have signed the Convention and 25 have ratified it, with the exception of Finland and Ireland. At the moment, the Netherlands is about to accede to the Convention. I voted to make the institutions of the European Union a role model for the implementation of the Convention. Discrimination on grounds of disability must be addressed in the same way as discrimination on other grounds, including multiple discrimination.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In December 2010, the EU joined the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) as the first regional integration organisation. The CRPD deals with a wide range of rights covering all areas of life, including those which do not fall within the EU's remit. Member States are therefore obliged to implement the Convention equally at all levels, including at regional and national level. The aim of the report adopted today, which I voted in favour of, is, in particular, to address the issues highlighted in the final observations. It prioritises recommendations that fall within the EU's remit and whose implementation could therefore be a problem at national level.  In the field of human rights, it is not possible to establish a sequence and disability discrimination should therefore be treated in the same way as discrimination on other grounds. This is particularly important for women and children with disabilities, the elderly and persons in need of complex support, including those with intellectual and psychosocial disabilities. What distinguishes the CRPD from other human rights treaties is that, in the process of its creation, persons with disabilities and the organisations representing them have been present from the drafting stage.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that we need to ensure and facilitate the full integration of persons with disabilities as they are often excluded from the mainstream of society, and we need to promote and voice their needs. This must go hand in hand with reinforcing their human rights, as I strongly believe that each human being must enjoy all human rights and fundamental freedoms. I believe that the EU acceding to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is an important step forward in the right direction towards truly promoting integrity and voicing the needs of all citizens, so I voted in favour of this resolution. However, I voted against all clauses referring to abortion.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to support this report by my colleague, Helga Stevens. In the UK we have long supported the development of this Convention, and it fits well with the UK approach to supporting people with disabilities, focusing on inclusion and involving disabled people in the decision-making process.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that there are 80 million people with disabilities in the European Union and 46 million of them women and girls, accounting for around 16% of the total female population in the EU, I believe that both the Member States and the Commission must take measures to combat any form of discrimination, including multiple discrimination, discrimination by association and intersectional discrimination on grounds of disability , with special attention paid to women and children with disabilities.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report looks at the state of implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CDPH) to which the EU joined in 2010. Considering that monitoring the implementation of the Convention is necessary for the proper implementation of the reforms to be carried out on the rights of disabled people in the European Union, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-binding and non-legislative report. The report was regarding the implementation of a UN convention on the rights of persons with disabilities. However the report also called for setting standards of social protection measures at EU level. While of course UKIP supports the rights of disabled people, it should only be for elected national governments, in compliance with international law, to decide social protection policy.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the application of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, following the Accession of the European Union to this Convention. All too often, people with disabilities are subjected to discrimination and violence that cannot go unanswered. In particular, it is essential that we implement all the necessary measures for their full integration into the labour market. Training programmes tailored to their needs must therefore be developed within our Member States.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. By ratifying the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the European Union has established a framework that promotes, respects and monitors it. The five bodies in charge - Parliament, Commission, Ombudsman, Agency for Fundamental Rights and the European Disability Forum - must work towards its implementation in European legislation and actions, thereby aiming at better integrating people with disabilities.  Several levels of action need to be considered. First, the labour market. We must ensure that businesses and governments have the facilities and are encouraged to employ people with disabilities. Then there is access to education. Progress still needs to be made on accessibility to infrastructure and recreational and sports activities, which are also drivers of integration. The EU must also ensure that the issue of gender equality is better integrated into its disability policy.   Finally, regular monitoring of the implementation of the convention and an assessment of progress will be required.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text deals with a convention that aims to reduce inequalities between people with disabilities and other citizens through the fight against discrimination and their integration into all areas of society.  The report goes further by addressing the issue of the social well-being of people with disabilities. The objectives of the text are unfortunately misguided, the key themes aimed at integrating people with disabilities into society and applying the UNDPH are polluted by other subjects, such as the inclusion of migrants, gender equality or free movement. Moreover, the text conveys a subjective and therefore confusing definition of disability.  Also, I preferred to abstain on this text.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although we are in favour of an inclusive society for people with disabilities, even though we defend their economic, social and educational rights, stressing that they are entitled to unquestionable dignity, equal treatment, independent living, even participation in public and political life, we are nevertheless obliged to vote against the draft report, on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities , in particular with regard to the closing remarks of the United Nations Commission on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. We are in favour of a united Europe that defends and safeguards the rights of its citizens, without equating them with the migrants who enter Europe every day, constantly making the situation and the future of people with disabilities increasingly difficult.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. "u2012 Given my involvement in the field of disability, being a member of the EU Framework and the EP Network for the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UN CRPD) and Vice-President of the Disability Intergroup, and having also been rapporteur for two of the views on this report, I am therefore particularly pleased that it has finally been adopted. The CRPD is the first treaty of international law and human rights ratified by the Union, and is therefore part of its own legal order. With regard to its implementation by both the Union itself and the Member States, the UN made final comments last year, which essentially established that the Union must harmonize all its legislation in order to be in line with the Convention, as well as ensure accessibility, access to justice and the principle of diversity. This Convention is not the end, it is the principle of the consolidation of the rights of persons with disabilities. In this sense, the Union has to be a leader in these issues and for this it is necessary to unblock the Directive on Non-Discrimination, which has long been paralyzed in the Council.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The UNCRPD Convention is an extremely important document for the protection of the rights of persons with disabilities. The report focuses mainly on the concluding remarks of the United Nations CRPD Committee, which aims to monitor and monitor the application of the Convention. I voted with conviction in favour of this resolution because, in addition to having set out a number of important recommendations for better social protection and social inclusion of people with disabilities, it urges, for the first time, the Commission and the Member States to give due recognition to the fundamental role of family caregivers, i.e. family members of the person with disabilities, and also to ensure that they have adequate access to health services. , taking into account the impact on their health and psychophysical well-being of the care they provide to people with disabilities.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU joined the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in December 2010 as the first regional integration organisation. This is the first international human rights treaty that the EU has fully ratified (and, to date, the only one). I therefore agree with the report that there is no hierarchy of human rights and that discrimination on grounds of disability deserves the same kind of response as discrimination for any other reason, including discrimination for more than one reason, on the part of all Member States. This issue is particularly important for women and children with disabilities, the elderly and people with complex support needs, including people with intellectual and psychosocial disabilities.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) is the first international treaty on human rights to be ratified by the EU and signed by all Member States (even if only 27 have ratified it). Its principles go beyond combating discrimination, pointing to the full enjoyment of human rights by all people with a disability and their families. The report advocates full implementation of the principles of the CRPD, making references to the conditions of people with disabilities, in particular in terms of inclusion in the education system, facilitating the conditions for labour or mobility. It also points out that austerity and impoverishment measures for the population have had very negative consequences, and have taken away rights and access to social services that support these people. It is recalled that the UN, in its report on the implementation of the Convention, warned and expressed concern about the way people with disabilities are treated in Portugal in areas such as justice, health, education, transport or access to independent living. In this context, this report – with which we essentially agree – acquires particular relevance.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union acceded to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in December 2010 as the first regional integration organisation. It was the first international human rights treaty ratified by the European Union as a whole and, to date, the only one. I am of the opinion that there is no hierarchy of human rights, and discrimination on grounds of disability must be treated in the same way as discrimination on other grounds, including discrimination on several grounds. This is particularly important for women and children with disabilities, the elderly and individuals in need of comprehensive support, including those with mental retardation and psychosocial disorders.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report, which contains reasonable and concrete proposals to increase the inclusion of disabled people in the European social fabric and its institutions.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I am in favour of an inclusive society for people with disabilities, although I defend their economic, social and educational rights, stressing that they are entitled to unquestionable dignity, equal treatment, independent living, and even participation in public and political life, I am nevertheless obliged to vote against the draft report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities , in particular with regard to the closing remarks of the United Nations Commission on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. I am in favour of a united Europe that defends and safeguards the rights of its citizens, without equating them with immigrants, who enter Europe every day, constantly making the situation and the future of people with disabilities increasingly difficult.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As enshrined in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the EU has to make every possible effort to combat discrimination based on disability when defining and implementing its policies and activities. The EU should lead the way as regards respect for and promotion of human rights. I therefore strongly support the call on the Commission to consolidate and make a proposal for a genuine structured dialogue between the EU and organisations representing persons with disabilities. Persons with disabilities are often excluded from the mainstream of society and denied their human rights. We must be strongly committed to promoting, defending and reinforcing the human rights of all persons with disabilities. Equal treatment and positive measures and policies for women with disabilities and mothers of children with disabilities is a fundamental human right and an ethical obligation. All persons with all types of disabilities must enjoy all human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with particular attention to the Concluding Comments of the United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, since those comments have highlighted a number of adjustments that needed to be made to ensure that discrimination on the grounds of disability is fought in the same way as discrimination on other grounds. This is especially important for women and children with disabilities, older people and people with complex support needs, particularly those with an intellectual or psychosocial disability.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the first human rights treaty of the 21st century and the first to sign the Union as a whole.  Today we voted on Parliament's response to the Committee's Conclusions on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, as well as the steps we believe should be taken to implement it. And in this report both content and forms are important, because organizations of people with disabilities have been involved throughout the process.  The labour market share of persons with disabilities is 58.5%, compared to 80.5%, of people without disabilities. And these figures are even worse for women, at 44%. Therefore, among all the proposals in the report, I would like to highlight one which calls for support for people's independent lives, equal opportunities and equal access to digital society. It is necessary for the Council to end once and for all the blocking of the Anti-Discrimination Directive and the Marrakesh Treaty.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the first human rights treaty of the 21st century and the first to sign the Union as a whole.  Today we voted on Parliament's response to the Committee's Conclusions on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, as well as the steps we believe should be taken to implement it. And in this report both content and forms are important, because organizations of people with disabilities have been involved throughout the process.  The labour market share of persons with disabilities is 58.5%, compared to 80.5%, of people without disabilities. And these figures are even worse for women, at 44%. Therefore, among all the proposals in the report, I would like to highlight one which calls for support for people's independent lives, equal opportunities and equal access to digital society. It is necessary for the Council to end once and for all the blocking of the Anti-Discrimination Directive and the Marrakesh Treaty.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the report by my colleagues in the Committee on Social Affairs and Employment on the rights of people with disabilities. This is a very concrete text, which aims to send the Member States and the Commission a detailed list of the working priorities that the EU has before it to implement the UN Convention on the Rights of the Disabled, which is – I would like to stress this – the first UN agreement signed by the EU as a legal entity.  The battle that the S&D Group is fighting to facilitate the inclusion of disabled people in working life is a defining feature of our political activity, and I would like to remind you of the clear mobilisation in favour of the application of the Marrakesh Treaty for the visually impaired and the blind.  With this parliamentary act, we are continuing the political pressure to ensure that the rights of disabled people are guaranteed horizontally in all areas of community legislation.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities with particular reference to the concluding remarks of the UN CRPD Committee, because the CRDP is the first international human rights treaty ratified by the EU, and by 27 of the 28 Member States. The fight against discrimination based on disability is also enshrined in the TFEU, and Articles 21 and 26 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights prohibit discrimination based on disability and provide for the equal participation of persons with disabilities in community life. On the basis of these important premises, the full inclusion of people with disabilities represents not only a right and a well-deserved benefit for those concerned, but also a resource for society as a whole, which can benefit from the value and different competences of these people. Their inclusion, regardless of a country's socio-economic, political or cultural situation, is not just about development, it is about human rights. I strongly supported the strong call for the Council to adopt the 2008 directive implementing the principle of equal treatment for persons irrespective of religion, belief, disability, age or sexual orientation.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 There are around 80 million people with disabilities in the European Union. It should be borne in mind that these are full citizens of the Union who have equal rights, the right to dignity, independent living, independence and support from publicly funded systems. In this context, tools such as the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities are essential to protect and ensure the full exercise of their rights. The European Parliament has today endorsed a report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which refers to specific European Commission guidelines falling within the EU's competence, which may pose a problem in the implementation of new recommendations at national level.  Discrimination on grounds of disability must be tackled sharply. This is particularly important for women, girls and children with disabilities, the elderly and those in need of complex support, including people with intellectual and psychosocial disabilities. The EU institutions should be a role model for other Member States in the implementation of the Convention, both in terms of staff regulations and recruitment practices or access to public events held at Parliament's premises.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the report on the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. It is important that everyone's fundamental rights are not called into question. At the same time, Member States have an obligation to ensure that all procedures and rules are respected and that EU funds are spent accordingly.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Labour Party has long championed the rights of those living with disabilities at every level of government. In the UK, there are an estimated 11 million people with a limiting long-term illness, impairment or disability, with the most commonly reported impairments being those that affect mobility, lifting or carrying. Mainstream society often excludes people with disabilities and they are effectively denied their human rights. Labour MEPs are committed to defending, promoting and reinforcing the human rights of all persons with disabilities. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that all people living with a disability must enjoy all human rights that they are afforded.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNDPH) aims in principle to reduce inequalities between people with disabilities and other citizens. However, this report is diverted from its objectives in favour of migrant inclusion or gender equality. Moreover, in the eyes of the rapporteur, the European Commission seems to be the only entity capable of dealing with these inequalities: the sovereignty of States is once again being undermined. In conclusion, although I support the integration of people with disabilities into society and the improvement of their well-being, I am opposed to them being used to favour migrants or to strengthen the powers of the Commission. So I decided to vote against this report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has a progressive and positive approach to persons with disabilities, including the gender and rights approach of girls with disabilities and a recognition of the role that the economic crisis has played in devaluing the provision of quality services for people with disabilities. The objective of this initiative report is to respond to the list of recommendations of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, ensuring that the views of the European Parliament are considered in the report of the European Commission (to be submitted in September). Among other things, the report invites the Union to ratify the Optional Protocol to the Convention, welcomes the proposal for a European Accessibility Law and calls for its rapid adoption, calls on the Commission to review the European Disability Strategy and develop a new Union strategy on the CDPD and a revision of legislation to ensure full compliance and implementation of the CDPD.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as Labour MEPs are committed to defending, promoting and reinforcing the human rights of all persons with disabilities.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. Europe must be a leader in defending the rights of people with disabilities: it is in this sense that I spoke today in voting in favour of this report. For this reason, the European institutions can first set a good example, in particular by making their premises more accessible and by making information available to the public that is more appropriate. Indeed, there must be no hierarchy of human rights. Discrimination on the basis of disability must be treated in the same way as discrimination on other grounds, including multiple discrimination.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. What sets the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) apart from other human rights treaties is that persons with disabilities and their representative organisations were included in the process from the drafting stage onwards.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the first human rights treaty of the 21st century and the first to sign the Union as a whole.  Today we voted on Parliament's response to the Committee's Conclusions on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, as well as the steps we believe should be taken to implement it. And in this report both content and forms are important, because organizations of people with disabilities have been involved throughout the process.  The labour market share of persons with disabilities is 58.5%, compared to 80.5%, of people without disabilities. And these figures are even worse for women, at 44%. Therefore, among all the proposals in the report, I would like to highlight one which calls for support for people's independent lives, equal opportunities and equal access to digital society. It is necessary for the Council to end once and for all the blocking of the Anti-Discrimination Directive and the Marrakesh Treaty.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report was intended to ensure that Parliament's view was included in the Commission's report, which is due to be published in September. The report contains several positive elements, emphasises the rights of women and girls with disabilities and the recognition of the role that the economic crisis has had in providing quality services for people with disabilities. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe the ratification of the treaty has the potential to benefit all EU citizens.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, I support the report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, as I believe it is essential that we do everything we can to ensure the equal treatment, independence and dignified existence of all EU citizens. This is all the more powerful for people with disabilities, who unfortunately continue to face serious obstacles to the exercise of their rights and freedoms.  Full inclusion of people with disabilities is important for society as a whole. I therefore welcome the conclusions and recommendations of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. I support the need to carry out a comprehensive and horizontal review of European Union legislation and funding programmes, the integration of disability-related issues into all EU legislative policies and strategies.  It is also necessary to ensure a permanent structured dialogue with organisations representing persons with disabilities and to introduce requirements for innovative solutions to provide accessible public services.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report. It is terrible that persons with disabilities are sometimes isolated from society and denied their human rights. It is imperative that all persons should benefit from human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with particular reference to the concluding remarks of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, as I will always support and emphasise that all persons with disabilities have the right to live in a society where they have the same opportunities as others in order to enable their full inclusion and participation in society. He estimates that around 80 million people in the European Union live with disabilities, of which around 46 million are women and girls, representing around 16% of the EU's total female population.  I agree with the Report and believe that the EU institutions and Member States should include in their gender equality policies, programmes and strategies the perspective of women and girls with disabilities and gender perspective in disability strategies.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to reduce inequalities between people with disabilities and other citizens through the fight against discrimination and their integration into all areas of society. He goes further by raising the issue of the social well-being of people with disabilities. This logic of systematic integration in a normal environment finds its limits in the face of the constraints of reality: in school, it is the disabled parents themselves who argue that certain disabilities are better cared for in a specialized environment. In professional settings, the ill-defined notion of "reasonable" accommodation may be counterproductive. Moreover, the report, which was largely amended in committee, resulted in a form of affirmative action. Finally, the report recommends exception measures (derogation from health austerity measures).  While I am obviously in favour of the proper integration of people with disabilities into society and an improvement in their well-being, I have opposed the implementation strategy proposed to the Commission in this initiative report and the very approach to disability.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Helga Stevens' report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The Convention stresses that people with disabilities must enjoy the right to equality and non-discrimination at several levels, such as in marriage and family, health, education and information, and protection from abuse and exploitation. These rights must be supported by strong legislation in the Member States. This report was adopted by a majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, including the final comments of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which is responsible for reviewing the implementation of the Un Convention.  Indeed, the EU joined the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CDPH) in December 2010. All 28 Member States have signed the convention and 26 have ratified it. With ratification, the EU is now subject to review by the Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and is required to produce an initial report on the state of implementation of the Convention.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Mrs Stevens' report. The EU was the first regional integration organisation to accession to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in December 2010. With this ratification, the EU is now subject to the control of the 'Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities' (hereinafter referred to as the 'CRPD Committee').

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report calls for better implementation of the UN Convention for the Protection of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Although the UN Convention is absolutely worthy of support, I am abstaining on this report, as the situation of integrating people with special needs is very different in the various Member States, so I do not think that harmonisation is effective.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as Labour MEPs are committed to defending, promoting and reinforcing the human rights of all persons with disabilities.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 An estimated 80 million people with disabilities live in the EU. Of these, 46 million are women. The EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and Freedoms explicitly prohibits discrimination on grounds of disability in Articles 21 and 26 and provides for equal participation of persons with disabilities in society. The EU has ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and the UN body has therefore monitored how the EU fulfils its obligations in this area. Problems with access to the labour market still persist for people with disabilities. The employment gap between non-disabled people is 22%, while for women it is 21%. This significantly makes it difficult to live an active, independent life. It was noted that the EU did not hold formal consultations with organisations representing persons with disabilities in 2015 when compiling the progress report. It therefore asks organisations representing these persons to actively participate in future reviews. The EU is invited to ratify the Option Protocol to the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The Commission is invited to take into account the EU's shared commitment to a barrier-free Europe when assessing the social situation in the Member States. There are many barrier-free requirements in all areas in the report, transport, political rights and emergency calls. It will not be easy to work out at least a timetable for bringing all requirements into EU life.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The present report deals with the protection and monitoring of the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, to which the EU acceded in December 2010. By its progressive approach, the report aims to strengthen Parliament’s position in this matter and to concentrate on burning subjects, mainly the protection of women, children and older persons with disabilities, including those with intellectual and psychosocial disabilities, within the context of an economic crisis. Hence, I voted in favour.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. In December 2010, the EU acceded to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD). This Treaty has been adopted by all Member States and is the first of its kind concerning the protection of human rights at international level. However, the optional protocol has not yet been ratified and the report therefore calls for this to be taken into note. By ratifying the CRPD, the EU will be subject to scrutiny by the CRPD Committee, which will invite the EU to produce an initial progress report and to submit regular updates on the Convention. Member States will therefore have to implement the Convention at both regional and national level, demonstrating a continuous promotion of the rights claimed by the CRPD. For these reasons, I welcome the report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with particular reference to the concluding remarks of the UN CRPD Committee.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it is a straight catch-all of the homomist who unfortunately does not just devote himself to his noble main subject: the improvement of the situation of people with disabilities.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.  While I am obviously in favour of the proper integration of people with disabilities into society and an improvement in their well-being, if I am in favour of the implementation of a convention already signed, in accordance with international law, I am opposed to the implementation strategy proposed to the Commission in this European report.  Paragraph 116, for example, proposes the creation of a European social protection base, whereas social security is an exclusive competence of the Member States. I also have questions about paragraph 58, which stresses 'the need to integrate disability issues into EU migration and refugee policies'.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The substance of the report tends to apply the UN Convention in question (UNDPI) to European law, to reduce inequalities between people with disabilities and other citizens, including the fight against discrimination.  However, the text hijacks the subject by introducing new themes such as migrants, gender equality and free movement. It remains vague on the definition of disability, which is at the heart of the matter, and defends a number of questionable positions such as the inability of Member States to deal with the issue of disability.  I condemn the approach taken in this report and the commission's presumption to want to implement a UN text. I voted against it.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is one of the most important human rights conventions and the first signed by the European Union as a whole. For its implementation, this report requires that accessibility legislation be implemented, that EU-funded programmes and projects comply with this Convention, and that a structured dialogue be established with organisations representing persons with disabilities. For us these rights are fundamental to achieving a just society with equality for people with disabilities, so we voted in favour of the text.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the Convention in the EU.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I agree that people with disabilities have a hard time doing so, but finding this fact in the form of a European Parliament resolution will not improve their situation. Moreover, social policy is a matter for the Member States.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report stated that that the UN CRPD Committee’s concluding observations on the EU’s implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD), published in 2015, represent an important sign of the EU’s commitment to equality and respect for human rights and offer guidance for legislative and policy actions across the EU’s sphere of competence. I support full implementation at EU level and sufficient resources to be allocated for this.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is part of the EU legal order. It is binding on the EU and all its Member States. However, its consistent implementation and application requires more active action by EU bodies. All Member States must consistently fulfil the convention's obligations and adopt strategies that create, as far as possible, appropriate and appropriate conditions and an environment for the active involvement of disabled persons in all spheres of work, socio-economic, social and political life. In addition, it is necessary that the Commission and the Member States make maximum use of communication with the organisations concerned representing disabled persons and ensure, in close cooperation, regular reporting on the fulfilment of the obligations under the Convention.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, in particular with regard to the closing remarks of the United Nations Commission on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 7/7/2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. While the purpose of this text is quite positive, as it aims to reduce the inequalities and discrimination suffered by people with disabilities, while improving their social well-being, we oppose other topics covered, such as the inclusion of migrants, gender equality or free movement.  On the other hand, the concept of disability is not sufficiently precise, which leads to a misunderstanding about the appropriate treatment to be provided. This definition rejects the objective conception of disability, thus contradicting French law (Article L 114 of the Code of Social Action and Families).  We disapprove of the text's very critical view of the Member States, questioning their willingness/ability to improve the situation of people with disabilities, as well as the additional interference in state social prerogatives (including the collection of statistics) or the submission to the United Nations by the review carried out by the Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.  The text wants to develop systematic integration in a normal environment without taking into account certain concrete elements. We also condemn the positive discrimination that sometimes emerges from this text.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report that deals with a very important issue, which is the protection of the rights of persons with disabilities. It is clear that the state plays a decisive role in helping people with disabilities. Statistics show that without social benefits from the state, more than 68.5% of people with disabilities would live in poverty. Meanwhile, women are at greater risk of poverty and social exclusion as a result of multiple discrimination, whether physical, psychological or sexual. In the report, we call on the Commission to consider establishing a framework at EU level to ensure the effective exercise of the rights of persons with disabilities, to promote their autonomy, to ensure accessibility and employment opportunities, and to eliminate all forms of discrimination. I supported the report in the vote.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, there are still barriers that make life harder for people with disabilities. We must remove obstacles and create an inclusive society, free from all discrimination. I believe that this will reduce poverty and improve the growth of the quality of life for people with disabilities and for all those who can take care of them.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I think it is worth supporting that the austerity measures in the area of disability policy must be avoided. However, this report is being misused for gender mainstreaming and migration policy. That is why I abstained.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Union joined the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in December 2010.  The purpose of this report is to assess the Union's progress in this area. It is based on the principle that there is no hierarchy of human rights. Thus, discrimination on the basis of disability must be treated in the same way as discrimination on other grounds, including multiple discrimination. This approach is particularly important for women and children with disabilities, the elderly or people with intellectual and psychosocial disabilities.  The document calls on the Commission and Member States to take the necessary steps to integrate disability into all EU laws, policies and strategies. I'm voting for this report.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. I am obviously in favour of the proper integration of people with disabilities into society and an improvement in their well-being. If we cannot oppose the implementation of a convention already signed, in accordance with international law, I strongly oppose the implementation strategy proposed in this initiative report and the very approach of the handicap that is made of it.  That is why I voted against this report, its dogmatic vision and its subjective conception of disability. In the end, this text does not really serve people with disabilities.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as a matter of human rights and equal protections. Persons with disabilities have a right to inclusion in society in both labour and social environments, and this report implements these rights, as well as highlighting the rights of persons with disabilities to advocacy of their own well-being.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – An estimated 80 million people in the Union suffer from disabilities to a lesser or greater extent, more than half of them women. By acceding to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the EU has undertaken to report on a regular basis on the progress it is making in the pursuit of the full integration of disabled people into our society.  Parliament's report lists the forms of discrimination that people with disabilities still face. Recommendations are also formulated to facilitate better integration of disabled people. People with disabilities should have the same rights as all other citizens. It is therefore clear that more efforts are being made to ensure appropriate and inclusive education, to ensure that freedom of movement in Europe is also consistently safeguarded for people with disabilities, to strengthen the implementation of EU legislation on direct access to information and communication for people with disabilities and to ensure that electronic and mobile health services are easy to use across Europe.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities was the first international treaty ratified by the European Union as a whole and is thus subject to the control of the Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The Convention covers a wide area of rights and extends to all areas of life, some of which do not fall within the competence of the Union. Member States are therefore required to equally implement the Convention at all levels, including regional and national. The Committee assessed the Union in the framework of the accelerated procedure and summarised in its recommendations that the declaration requires regular updating. Particular attention should be paid to the Union institutions themselves, which are to be a model for the implementation of the Convention. I believe that there is no hierarchy of human rights and discrimination on grounds of disability must be treated in the same way as discrimination on other grounds, including discrimination on several grounds. This is particularly important for women and children with disabilities, the elderly and individuals in need of comprehensive support, including those with mental retardation and psychosocial disorders. In view of the above, I agree with the proposal on the table.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which calls for the human rights of all persons with disabilities to be promoted, defended and reinforced. Persons with disabilities are often excluded from the mainstream of society and denied their human rights. It is essential to make sure that all persons with all types of disabilities enjoy all human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In December 2010, the EU joined the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) as the first regional integration organisation. The CRPD is one of the human rights treaties that has the most States Parties and signatories. The Convention has been signed by all 28 EU Member States, with the exception of Finland and Ireland, 25 Member States have rat confirmed it and the Netherlands is close to accession to the Convention. Following accession to the Convention, the EU, like other States Parties, had to prepare an introductory report on the implementation of the Convention. This was submitted by the Commission in June 2014, to which the CRPD Committee responded in May 2015. In its reply, the Commission largely took into account Parliament's recommendation adopted in May 2015. The EU is obliged to reply to the CRPD Committee's questions in this case by September 2016. The EP has therefore decided to draw up an own-initiative report in order to include its opinion in the reply to be submitted by the Commission. I voted in favour of the report submitted by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Although we are in favour of better integration of people with disabilities and improved well-being, we oppose this text and the approach presented to it on this subject. Firstly, the report calls for even more submission of Member States to the EU and flouts their sovereignty. The EU behaves like a state, takes over state social prerogatives, and the report even goes so far as to present the Commission as the only solution to the resolution of the problem of disability. In addition, he takes advantage of the theme of people with disabilities to talk about other topics such as the integration of migrants, gender equality or free movement. But above all, it does not define the notion of disability which seems to be based only on a subjective conception, which is in opposition to the definition given by French law.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2010, the European Union joined the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which entered into force in the Legal System of the Union on 21 January 2011. The Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities covers a wide range of rights corresponding to various areas of the daily lives of persons with disabilities, and the concrete application of the protection of some rights falls outside the union's rife, and it is also up to the Member States to ensure their correct implementation.  From the application to that Convention, it is mandatory to submit periodic reports every four years on their application. To this end, I vote in favour of this report, as I consider it important to assess the "state of the art" of the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in order to identify potential shortcomings and to present solutions to ensure the protection of the rights of persons with disabilities.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. While we are obviously in favour of the proper integration of people with disabilities into society and an improvement in their well-being, if we cannot oppose the implementation of a convention already signed, in accordance with international law, we strongly oppose the implementation strategy proposed to the Commission in this initiative report and the approach to the handicap that is proposed. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Labour Party has long championed the rights of those living with disabilities at every level of government. In the UK, there are an estimated 11 million people with a limiting long-term illness, impairment or disability, with the most commonly reported impairments being those that affect mobility, lifting or carrying. Mainstream society often excludes people with disabilities and they are effectively denied their human rights. Labour MEPs are committed to defending, promoting and reinforcing the human rights of all persons with disabilities. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that all people living with a disability must enjoy all human rights that they are afforded.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which the European Union joined in December 2010, and which was drafted in conjunction with people with disabilities and the associations that represent them. This report aims in particular at better integrating people with disabilities into the labour market and improving accessibility, particularly within the European institutions.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with the Council Decision of 2009 on the conclusion by the European Community of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and considering that, as full citizens, all persons with disabilities have equal rights, including those inalienable to dignity, equal treatment, independent living, autonomy, support by public systems and full participation in society , I welcome the report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD). The full inclusion of people with disabilities is, in fact, not only a right and a well-deserved benefit for those concerned, but also a resource for society as a whole, which can benefit from the value and different competences of these people. The CRPD covers a wide range of rights, covering all areas of life, some of which are outside the competence of the EU. Member States are therefore required to apply the Convention at all levels, including regional and national levels. It is therefore necessary to achieve enhanced political cooperation, including human and financial resources to ensure compliance with the obligations and implementation of the CRPD recommendations.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 There are an estimated 80 million people in the European Union with some form of disability who are entitled to equal rights and equal treatment. Discrimination on grounds of disability should be treated as a priority. This is particularly important for women and children with disabilities, the elderly and persons in need of complex support, including those with intellectual and psychosocial disabilities. By voting in favour of this report, I wanted to contribute to this.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities elaborates in detail the rights of persons with disabilities and sets out the code of implementation. The EU acceded to the Convention in December 2010. I voted for this report that concentrates on the matters highlighted in its Concluding Observations with a special regard towards women and children with disabilities, older persons and individuals with complex support needs.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, because I believe that the EU must be at the height of its own requirements in the field of respect for and safeguarding fundamental human rights. There are nearly 80 million people with disabilities in the Union who, as equal citizens, have the right to equal treatment, an independent lifestyle and full participation in society. Let us recall that they do not have equal access to education and training that adequately take into account their needs and allow them to maximise their potential. The right to inclusive quality education must be guaranteed to all. I am also firmly behind the idea of including disability-specific indicators in the Europe 2020 strategy. Erasmus+ provides, for example, additional financial support for mobility for students with disabilities. However, this should be enshrined in all aspects of the programme. The European Youth Strategy must also focus on the needs of young people with disabilities.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ My support for this report stems from the recognition that protecting the rights of the disabled is an integral part of the EU’s commitment to human rights, particularly as there are approximately 80 million EU citizens with disabilities. The report reflects the results of the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) in the EU. Not only does it welcome the fact that, for the first time, the EU’s fulfilment of its international human rights obligations has been reviewed by a UN treaty body, but it also reflects the consideration that the EU is committed to equality and respect for human rights. I also support the report because it underlines the aspects that could be improved in this regard.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which incorporated proposals from my Sinn Féin colleague Martina Anderson who authored the associated opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE).  The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) was ratified by the EU in 2010, covering a large range of rights for people with disabilities, ranging from the workplace to transport. Accession means the EU is now scrutinised by the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The CPRD Committee published its concluding observations on the initial report of the EU in August 2015, which require the Commission to respond with a report within a year. The purpose of this own-initiative report is to ensure that Parliament’s views are taken into account in the Commission’s response (due in September). Among other things, the report calls for the EU to ratify the Optional Protocol to the CRPD, welcomes the proposal for a European Accessibility Act and calls for its swift adoption. It calls on the Commission to review the European Disability Strategy and develop a new EU CPRD strategy; and calls for a review of all EU legislation and funding programmes to ensure full compliance and implementation with the CPRD.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained because it is in principle good to avoid austerity measures in the area of disability policy, but it is not justifiable to indirectly support gender mainstreaming and an expanded migration policy.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. People with disabilities have the right to live in a society where they are guaranteed equal opportunities with others. The report highlights the need for the last Member States to complete the ratification of the UN Convention and, as an example for The Member States, the EU institutions must implement equal opportunities for all, including recruitment, staff regulations and universal accessibility.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and its Optional Protocol were adopted on 13 December 2006 at United Nations Headquarters in New York and were opened for signature on 30 March 2007. 82 signatures of the Convention and 44 of the Optional Protocol were obtained, as well as ratification of the Convention. Never has a United Nations convention brought together such a large number of signatories on the day of its opening to signature. In addition, it is the first comprehensive human rights instrument of the 21st century and the first human rights convention to be opened for signature by regional integration organizations.  The report shows a clear signal in This Parliament's commitment to the full integration of persons with disabilities and can mark a before and after in the recognition of their rights. Our commitment is clear, so I ask the Member States and the Commission not to delay their work for the effectiveness of rights and to adopt a disability pact to ensure the integration of the rights of persons with disabilities into all Union initiatives.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled. There is no hierarchy of human rights and I believe that discrimination on grounds of disability must be combated in the same way as discrimination for other reasons. This is particularly important for women with disabilities and children with disabilities, the elderly and people with complex needs for assistance, including those with intellectual and psychosocial disorders. The full inclusion of persons with disabilities is not only the right of the persons concerned and what they belong to, but also the benefits for society as a whole. It is for this reason that the EU institutions and the Member States should step up their efforts to ensure that all people with disabilities are provided with rights and services. Equal rights must be guaranteed for all persons, and no member of the public can be left behind, since access to justice is a fundamental right and a fundamental principle of the rule of law. It should be noted that, in order to ensure full protection of the rights of persons with disabilities, it is essential to guarantee such persons freedom of choice – how to live them and how to best exploit their potential. Women with disabilities and men and their family members need special support, including childcare assistance, to fully enjoy their maternity and paternity rights.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The wish list of the European Parliament's report on the "implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities" cannot hide the fact that unpopular EU policy does not exclude disabled people either. Even the reliefs requested for disabled countries in a memorandum, such as in Greece, concern only severe disability or extreme poverty, sharing the latter among the disabled, as already inadequate benefits have been reduced by 50%. Cuts in health – welfare, their inability to pay for medicines and consumables makes it difficult or interrupts their treatment. Disability pensions, allowances, benefits are cut and linked to property criteria, while invalidity rates are also cut.  Flexible work particularly affects the disabled as their health requires a stable environment. Many who work in privatised former public companies are laid off. Staff and infrastructure shortages in public special education have driven 200,000 disabled children out of education. In view of the above, the European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party voted white in the above report, underlining the need for: Mass recruitment of disabled people, with full rights. Exclusively state, free health - welfare - special education system, without any business action. Free medicines, treatments, prevention, rehabilitation without conditions and conditions. Free inclusion in education. Support for the unemployed as long as unemployment lasts.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-binding and non-legislative report. The report was regarding the implementation of a UN convention on the rights of persons with disabilities. However the report also called for setting standards of social protection measures at EU level. While of course UKIP supports the rights of disabled people, it should only be for elected national governments, in compliance with international law, to decide social protection policy.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report focuses mainly on the concluding remarks of the United Nations CRPD Committee, which aims to monitor and monitor the protection of the rights of persons with disabilities.  I, along with other members of my group, have tabled amendments aimed at helping to improve the protection of people with disabilities in a number of areas, including education and work. For example, we have fought for greater accessibility to education and training programmes as well as erasmus+, youth guarantee and EURES initiatives, as well as requiring a social protection base in the EU, so that the right to an adequate standard of living and social protection for people with disabilities is respected.  For the above reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report as the implementation of this Convention promotes, protects and guarantees the full and equal enjoyment of all human rights and fundamental freedoms and helps to promote respect for their innate dignity. In order for people with disabilities to participate fully and effectively in society in the same way as others, a step must be taken, which is well covered in this report. My view has always been that there are a number of development projects that focus primarily on people with special needs. I also agree with the establishment of capacity-building mechanisms and the exchange of good practices between the various institutions, both within the EU itself and between its members. I supported the report as a whole, and my support was not given to some of the proposed amendments relating to discrimination and financial work, because in this part the fundamental rights of persons with disabilities are being violated – the correct use of funds and compliance with the rules of the Structural Funds are in the domain of the Member States.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ A truly tolerant and inclusive society must face the fact that people with disabilities are its stakeholders who still face discrimination and inability to access and exercise their basic human rights in many segments of their daily lives, such as the right to education, access to adapted accommodation, access to health and social services, in particular healthcare-friendly care, and the inclusion in the labour market and are largely victims of violence, especially women and girls.  In my view, we need to step up our efforts to make people with disabilities recognised as equally valuable and important stakeholders of society and to provide them with adequate protection. Only by enabling them to participate fully and equally in all social processes can we discover their full potential that can contribute to overall progress.
