As the already aggravating circumstances of disability and all the barriers this entails, people with disabilities face many difficulties and struggles, we need to improve their lives effectively and actively in all Member States in line with the humane face of Europe, which respects and cares for every member of society.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. I am, of course, in favour of the proper integration of people with disabilities into society and an improvement in their well-being. I also support the implementation of a convention already signed, in accordance with international law. But I am opposed to the implementation strategy proposed to the Commission in this initiative report and to the very approach to disability that is being made of it.  Moreover, the text gives pride of place to the permanent interference of the EU in a total non-respect of the sovereignty of the Member States. In these circumstances, I prefer to abstain.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 All persons with disabilities have inalienable rights as citizens, including dignity, equal treatment, independent living, autonomy and full participation in society. The EU's accession to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) is therefore significantly important, both symbolically and practically. It must now be implemented, so that all people with disabilities fully enjoy human rights, in an inclusive society. Certain categories of disabled citizens, such as women, children, the elderly and immigrants, are often the victims of double discrimination and therefore deserve special protection and attention. It is essential to promote their full participation in the labour market, so that they can have a dignified, independent and active life. Women's shoulders are usually also borne by the burden of caring for disabled family members, which often forces them to give up their working and working lives. It is essential that the Union integrates the disability dimension into its gender-related policies and programmes and gender perspective into its disability strategies. I therefore support the resolution calling on the European institutions to achieve full social inclusion of people with disabilities.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. People with disabilities are often marginalised and denied their human rights. It is necessary to promote, defend and ensure the implementation of the human rights of all persons with disabilities. We must not allow people with disabilities to be denied fundamental freedoms.  In December 2010, the EU joined the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities as the first organisation of regional integration. It was the first, and so far only, international human rights treaty fully ratified by the EU. The optional protocol has not been signed or ratified. The EU is under the supervision of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities following ratification. The Convention is one of the human rights agreements with the largest number of states parties and signatories. The Convention was signed by all 28 EU Member States and ratified by 25, except Finland and Ireland. At the time of drafting this report, the Netherlands is close to joining the Convention. The Convention covers a wide range of rights concerning all aspects of life, some of which are not within the COMPETENCE of the EU. Therefore, Member States should equally implement the Convention at all levels, including regional and national.  I welcome the report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and hope that Parliament will continue to work in the future to promote human rights.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The CRPD is the first international human rights treaty to be ratified by the EU and signed by all Member States (although only 27 have ratified it). Its principles go beyond combating discrimination, pointing to the full enjoyment of human rights by all people with a disability and their families. The report advocates full implementation of the principles of the CRPD, making references to the conditions of people with disabilities, in particular in terms of inclusion in the education system, facilitating the conditions for labour or mobility. It states that austerity and impoverishment measures for populations have had very negative consequences, and have withdrawn rights and access to social services that are the support of these people. The Committee responsible expressed concern about the way people with disabilities are treated in Portugal, in matters ranging from justice, health, education, transport or access to independent living, as well as concern about how the crisis has affected the lives of these people. It is considered that, in essence, the report is positive, the reason for the vote in favour.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am aware that disabled people are often victims of exclusion from society. This is happening even though they are full citizens entitled to the same opportunities as the rest of us. I supported the report on the implementation of the UN Convention, as it is unacceptable for up to 80 million Europeans to face unequal treatment and thus damage their dignity. I consider it essential that consultations be established at European and national level between the organisations representing people with disabilities, businesses and legissers. Action must be taken against all forms of discrimination and, in particular, the issue of violence against people with any kind of disability. I have expressed my support for initiatives aimed at communicating with the general public and influencing the perception of these people. It is an incredible pity that society is not exploiting the potential offered by this group of people and that disabled citizens face alarmingly high unemployment rates. I therefore voted in favour of better use of the European Structural and Investment Funds, which can greatly help the situation. Furthermore, I voted in favour of integrating the rights of persons with disabilities into other policies and programmes, because this is the only way to improve the life, self-sufficiency and dignity of this vulnerable population.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU acceded to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in December 2010, as the first regional integration organisation. This is the first international human rights treaty that the EU as a whole has ratified, a tangible sign of the global vocation of this organisation of nation-states. With the ratification of the Optional Protocol to this Convention, the EU is now subject to the control of the Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities ("CRPD Committee"). This is a technical aspect which, however, helps to strengthen the Union's action in support of people with disabilities, who must be given greater benefits and, above all, must be able to feel that they are Full European citizens. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which the European Union joined in December 2010, and in particular the final comments made by the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-binding and non-legislative report. The report was regarding the implementation of a UN convention on the rights of persons with disabilities. However the report also called for setting standards of social protection measures at EU level. While of course UKIP supports the rights of disabled people, it should only be for elected national governments, in compliance with international law, to decide social protection policy.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union joined the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) in December 2010. It was indeed the first international human rights treaty that the EU fully ratified.  The CRPD has the highest number of signatory countries compared to all other human rights treaties. All 28 EU Member States are signatories to the Convention and 25 of them have already ratified it. This shows well that there cannot be a hierarchy of human rights and that discrimination on grounds of disability deserves the same kind of response that has discrimination for any other reason. This is even more relevant when we talk about women and children with disabilities, the elderly and people with complex support needs, including people with intellectual and psychosocial disabilities.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the first human rights treaty of the 21st century and the first to sign the Union as a whole.  Today we voted on Parliament's response to the Committee's Conclusions on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, as well as the steps we believe should be taken to implement it. And in this report both content and forms are important, because organizations of people with disabilities have been involved throughout the process.  The labour market share of persons with disabilities is 58.5%, compared to 80.5%, of people without disabilities. And these figures are even worse for women, at 44%. Therefore, among all the proposals in the report, I would like to highlight one which calls for support for people's independent lives, equal opportunities and equal access to digital society. It is necessary for the Council to end once and for all the blocking of the Anti-Discrimination Directive and the Marrakesh Treaty.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report was to assess the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The integration of people with disabilities is an important issue and the Union must do everything possible to make it a success.  To this end, I call for the European Union to fully implement the recommendations of the Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and allocate sufficient resources to do so.  The report also contains a series of recommendations made to the European Commission as well as to the Member States. In line with these recommendations, I have voted in favour of this report and I call on the Commission and the Member States to follow up. This is a matter of respect for people with disabilities.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. It is clear that, despite considerable efforts, people with disabilities still face discrimination and exclusion. The text highlights mobility, access to justice, the creation of conditions for the independence of women with disabilities, accessibility to communication tools and a number of other problems and challenges. Parliament believes that a broader approach is needed to make a real improvement in the situation of people with disabilities. It is necessary not only to think about specific measures, but to think in advance when adopting legislation what impact they will have on people with disabilities. It is necessary to provide for funding for the development of organisations with disabilities and for ensuring services that allow people with disabilities to live a full life.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union (EU) joined the UNITED NATIONS Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) in 2010, this being the first international Human Rights Treaty ratified by the EU, signed by all Member States and ratified by 27. And the importance of implementing the CRPD is noted, as there is a large number of citizens with disabilities living in the EU, as described in the report: around 80 million people, including 46 million women and girls, representing 16 % of our total female population. And it is these figures, which are repeated on a global scale, that make it the Convention with the highest number of signatory countries when compared to other Human Rights Treaties.  Although this Convention covers a wide range of rights, some do not fall within the EU's sphere of competence, so Member States should apply it uniformly in their territories.  Because I agree with the rapporteur's position that there is no hierarchy of human rights, as well as because discrimination on grounds of disability deserves the same kind of response as discrimination generated for any other reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, including the final comments of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Indeed, the inclusion of people with disabilities in society is not only an issue for development, but contributes to respect for human rights.  The final comments of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities on the EU's implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities published in 2015 are a strong signal of the Union's commitment to equality and respect for human rights and provide guidance for the Union's legislative and political actions.  If the recommendations of the Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities are to be welcomed, they must be fully implemented at EU level.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Stevens report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. This convention is an important stage as it is the first and so far only international human rights treaty that the EU has ratified as a whole. The report, for which I voted in favour, is a very technical text that allows the implementation of the decisions contained in the Convention. I would like to stress the fact that some rights of the CPRD fall outside the competence of the EU; Member States are therefore obliged to implement the Convention at all levels.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has a progressive and positive approach to persons with disabilities, including the gender and rights approach of girls with disabilities and a recognition of the role that the economic crisis has played in devaluing the provision of quality services for people with disabilities. The objective of this initiative report is to respond to the list of recommendations of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, ensuring that the views of the European Parliament are considered in the report of the European Commission (to be submitted in September). Among other things, the report invites the Union to ratify the Optional Protocol to the Convention, welcomes the proposal for a European Accessibility Law and calls for its rapid adoption, calls on the Commission to review the European Disability Strategy and develop a new Union strategy on the CDPD and a revision of legislation to ensure full compliance and implementation of the CDPD.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. I am in favour of the EU ensuring that its obligations were imposed on it when it concluded in 2010 the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. It is important that we fully recognise and support the special needs of disabled people. In this way, we ensure that this group of citizens can maintain a life without unnecessary restrictions and with a high degree of self-realization. That is why I voted in favour of the own-initiative report. However, it is up to the Member States to decide what kind of social safety net should be deployed in each country and to administer it.  That is why I abstained from voting in favour of the proposal that the EU should introduce mini-standards for social policy aimed at people with disabilities. It is and must remain national competence.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with particular reference to the concluding remarks of the United Nations Committee on the Protection of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The report shows the progress made for people with disabilities and the extent to which the agreement has been implemented. In 2010, the EU acceded to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is one of the most important human rights conventions and the first signed by the European Union as a whole. For its implementation, this report requires that accessibility legislation be implemented, that EU-funded programmes and projects comply with this Convention, and that a structured dialogue be established with organisations representing persons with disabilities. For us these rights are fundamental to achieving a just society with equality for people with disabilities, so we voted in favour of the text.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 This text outlines the state of implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, while making recommendations to Member States to ensure greater inclusion of disabled people in society. I believe that there is no hierarchy of human rights and that discrimination based on disability must be combated in the same way as discrimination based on other reasons. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour because this report is an important testimony to the EU's commitment to equality and respect for the rights of disabled people and provides guidance for future European policies.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities was an important step in ensuring these rights. Discrimination against persons with disabilities is a reprehensible act, so it is recommended that legislation promoting equality and condemning discrimination is recommended. There are approximately 80 million people with disabilities in the EU, of whom 46 million are female, and women with disabilities are often victims of multiple forms of discrimination.  There must be a real commitment to policy-making and actions that ensure a sound education that helps people with disabilities to develop their skills, fostering positive integration into the labour market. Decent work is essential for these people to have a remuneration that allows them to enjoy an independent life.  I voted in favour because I believe that the EU should strengthen awareness campaigns of the community at large and the business world by focusing on the potential and contribution to society of the full integration of people with disabilities. Active participation of people with disabilities in the economic and social life of the community is essential to prevent them from being marginalised.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I do not recognise the EU's competence in this area.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report as my party has at every level of government long championed the rights of those living with disabilities. In the UK, there are an estimated 11 million people with a limiting long-term illness, impairment or disability, the most commonly reported impairments being those that affect mobility, lifting or carrying. Mainstream society often excludes people with disabilities, who are effectively denied their human rights as a result. I and Labour MEPs are committed to defending, promoting and reinforcing the human rights of all persons with disabilities.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report dealt with the situation of persons with disabilities very broadly and made many stimulating and concrete proposals to safeguard their rights. Unfortunately, however, it referred to documents that threaten the principle of subsidiarity, which we have repeatedly pointed out here in the European Parliament, with many colleagues. In particular, it is the controversial Istanbul Convention, which has been ratified by only half of the Member States, and also the years later blocked anti-discrimination directive on the implementation of the principle of equal treatment (so-called ETD). The report also promotes sexual and reproductive rights for women, but also for girls with disabilities, regardless of member states' legislation. I therefore abstained.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 An estimated 80 million people with disabilities live in the European Union and the number of people with disabilities is increasing as the average age of the population increases. I would like to thank the rapporteur for the report that has been tabled, which highlights very succine and factually the problems and shortcomings faced by persons with disabilities. Like the rapporteur, I would like to point out that the full inclusion of persons with disabilities is not only a right and a well-deserved advantage for the individuals concerned, but also an asset from the point of view of society as a whole, because the values and diverse skills of these persons can be beneficial to them. I supported the current resolution because it does not only deal with the dry state of play, but comes up with a number of proposals and measures that could greatly help those directly affected. I was pleased to welcome the fact that, for the first time, the UN body has examined the EU's compliance with its international human rights obligations and recommended that the EU and its Member States take the necessary measures to integrate disability into all legislation, policies and strategies. In this context, I expect the Commission and the Member States to take measures to prevent any discrimination against persons with disabilities.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague Helga Stevens' report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD). I very much appreciate her work in the EP and her need to overcome the difficult obstacles of disability. The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is still the only human rights convention to which the EU has subscribed as a whole. The European Union cannot forget people with disabilities and should support the Member States in their efforts. The inclusion of people with disabilities puts the report on the level of human rights and highlights the overall contribution of such a process to society. The report calls for the elimination of discrimination and the adoption of a so-called European Accessibility Act (draft legislation on accessibility and adaptation of products and services for the disabled). It also ignores the fact that certain groups or categories of people with disabilities, e.g. from migrant backgrounds, are particularly disadvantaged, but also more women compared to men. The report also left a number of redundant and ideologically biased recommendations from the point of view of sexual and reproductive health, or a proposal to cut structural funds in the event of a breach of the obligation to respect fundamental rights.  Nevertheless, I supported the report in the final vote.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. In December 2010, as the first regional integration organisation, the European Union acceded to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. This is the first international human rights treaty that has been ratified by the European Union as a whole. The optional protocol has not been signed or ratified. With the ratification of the Convention, the European Union is now under the control of the Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The report deals as a matter of priority with recommendations falling within the competence of the European Union, which makes it possible to expect complications of implementation at national level. Particular attention is paid to the institutions of the European Union, which must lead by example in the implementation of the Convention. This includes the Staff Regulations and employment and retention practices, as well as public events organised by or on its premises by the European Parliament. There is no hierarchy in the case of human rights, and discrimination on the basis of disability must be treated as all other forms of discrimination. This is particularly important for women and children with disabilities, the elderly and individuals with multifaceted support needs, including those with special needs in the intellectual and psychosocial fields. For this very part, I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Persons with disabilities need to be guaranteed effective protection of their rights in all areas of life. Making human rights available in such sensitive cases must not only focus on civil, economic, political, social and cultural rights, but must also help to overcome the disadvantages of such persons and contribute to the more effective and faster inclusion of citizens with disabilities in society.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I rejected the resolution on the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The resolution believes that reproductive rights are one of the fundamental freedoms enshrined in the Vienna Declaration and the 1993 Programme of Action and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. In addition, the resolution recognises a 'right to equality' and 'a right to marry', such as, finally, the 'right to start a family' and even 'the right to comprehensive reproductive health care, including family planning and maternal health services'. There is no obligation to have a right, and there can be no obligation to start a family with someone, nor can there be a right to have offspring.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. In December 2010, the European Union joined the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. It was the first, and so far only, international human rights treaty fully ratified by the Union. The objective and purpose of this report is to focus on those recommendations which are within the competence of the Union and where implementation at national level may be difficult. The Convention covers a wide range of rights concerning all aspects of life, some of which are not within the COMPETENCE of the EU. Therefore, Member States should equally implement the Convention at all levels, including regional and national. I support the proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament, as I believe that the Union, as a signatory to the Convention, has a duty to ensure the full involvement and active participation of persons with disabilities and organisations representing them in all decision-making processes in matters concerning persons with disabilities. There is no hierarchy of human rights and it is necessary to combat discrimination on the grounds of disability in the same way as discrimination on any other basis.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with particular reference to the conclusions of the United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. As an alternate member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I supported the initiative calling on the Council and the Commission to take better care of the needs of people with disabilities and to take them strictly into account when reviewing EU regulations, such as passenger rights in different modes of transport and in drafting legislation, for example on passenger rights in multimodal travel. In 2010, the European Union committed itself to a barrier-free Europe under the European Disability Strategy.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although we are in favour of an inclusive society for people with disabilities, even though we defend their economic, social and educational rights, stressing that they are entitled to unquestionable dignity, equal treatment, independent living, even participation in public and political life, we are nevertheless obliged to vote against the draft report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities , in particular with regard to the closing remarks of the United Nations Commission on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. We are in favour of a united Europe that defends and safeguards the rights of its citizens, without equating them with the migrants who enter Europe every day, constantly making the situation and the future of people with disabilities increasingly difficult.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In addition to the content, this convention is of paramount importance for reasons of principle, as it is the first – and until now the only – international human rights treaty to be ratified by the EU itself in December 2010. In accordance with the Treaty, the EU undertook to report on the implementation of the Convention and to review it regularly. I supported this report, which points out, inter alia, that persons with disabilities are still often excluded from mainstream society and deprived of their human rights. Analysing the reasons reveals that while some of the commitments fall within EU competence, their implementation in the Member States is insufficient. The members of the Socialist Group are committed to the protection and development of the human rights of persons with disabilities.  I agree that persons with disabilities, as full citizens, are entitled to equal rights, inalienable dignity, equal treatment, independent living, autonomy, support for publicly funded schemes and full social engagement. It should be noted here that articles 21 and 26 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union explicitly prohibit discrimination on grounds of disability and provide for equal participation of persons with disabilities in society. I can only imagine this in a stronger European Union, and I trust that we can stand united on a growing number of issues.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Member States are among the main defenders of the rights of persons with disabilities worldwide. In December 2010, the EU was the first regional integration organisation to sign the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNCRPD), with the Convention also signed by all Member States and ratified by 25 of them. With a view to ratification by the EU, the Commission presented the initial report in June 2014, and the European Parliament expressed its views on the report. The UNCRPD Committee sent its comments and the Commission's reply will be submitted by September 2016. This report shall include the observations of the European Parliament on those documents and its own proposals. These include the concrete implementation of the Convention by the European institutions, the fight against discrimination on the basis of disability (especially among women, children, the elderly and persons with intellectual and psycho-social disabilities), the proper arrangement of jobs and public spaces, equal treatment, the involvement of organisations in the development of specific legislation.  Parliament's views were attended by the EMPL, LIBE and PETI Committees, as well as the European Ombudsman, the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, the European Disability Forum. I express my support for the adoption of this important document.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the text. The aim of this report is first of all to focus on the issues highlighted in the final observations. It focuses on recommendations that fall within the Union's jurisdiction and which, therefore, could pose difficulties in implementing at the national level.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The inclusion of persons with disabilities, an estimated 80 million persons in the EU, is not only a fundamental right but also an asset for society as a whole, and all Member States must work on guaranteeing equal access to training and education, and real opportunities to achieve professional and personal development. This is why I voted in favour of the resolution on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which outlines the state of the EU’s fulfilment of its international human rights obligations and offers guidance for further necessary legislative and policy actions. This is the first time that the EU has been reviewed by a UN body, which is a real proof of the EU’s commitment to equality and respect for human rights and its will to achieve further progress.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 About 15% of the world's population, or about a billion people, live with a disability and almost 80% of them live in poor or developing countries, are often unknown data, which also require the European Union to work to protect these people. It is important to ensure the full implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in all areas and policies of the European Union and to involve people with disabilities and their organisations in the processes that affect them. Strong action is needed to combat sexual violence against women and children with disabilities and it is essential to provide assistance to people with disabilities even in 'post-emergency' situations. Anti-discrimination strategies must also be initiated, which are a key element in 2019 for sustainable and fully inclusive development.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with particular reference to the concluding remarks of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The resolution aims to prevent victimisation and take steps to combat all forms of discrimination. Forms of discrimination include: multiple discrimination, discrimination on grounds of association, multidimensional discrimination on the grounds of disability, in particular for women and children with disabilities, the elderly and people with complex support needs, and discrimination related to intellectual and psychosocial disabilities and people whose disabilities change over time.  I would like to stress that the rapporteur is focused on recommendations that are within the competence of the Union and will pay particular attention to the Union institutions themselves, which will be a role model in the implementation of the Convention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. We must be aware that we still live in a society that treats people with disabilities as different. I supported the report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with particular emphasis on the conclusions of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, because people with disabilities are still exposed to inequalities and neglect in the labour market. As many as 80 million Europeans suffer from a lighter or more severe form of disability, and in the future we can expect these numbers to increase further as europe's population ages. The Convention covers a wide range of rights in different areas of life not covered by EU competence. Member States are therefore required to implement the Convention equally at all levels. The standards set out in the Convention must be implemented across the EU. By creating strong legal frameworks for the implementation of the Convention, the EU will stress that it takes seriously its commitment to respect and the implementation of human rights.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has a progressive and positive approach to persons with disabilities, including the gender and rights approach of girls with disabilities and a recognition of the role that the economic crisis has played in devaluing the provision of quality services for people with disabilities. The objective of this initiative report is to respond to the list of recommendations of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, ensuring that the views of the European Parliament are considered in the report of the European Commission (to be submitted in September). Among other things, the report invites the Union to ratify the Optional Protocol to the Convention, welcomes the proposal for a European Accessibility Law and calls for its rapid adoption, calls on the Commission to review the European Disability Strategy and develop a new Union strategy on the CDPD and a revision of legislation to ensure full compliance and implementation of the CDPD.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with special regard to the Concluding Observations of the UN CRPD Committee. The reports warns that there are an estimated 80 million persons with disabilities in the European Union, making these citizens more vulnerable to poverty and all kind of abuses. This text calls upon Member States and European institutions to improve accessibility and fully include persons with a disability in society and in employment to enable them to follow a fully independent life and, as a result, ensure the fulfilment of basic human rights within European borders. It stresses the need to introduce European directives and legislation and ensure the implementation of existing measures. As a result and bearing in mind the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, amongst others, we fully support the document.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is the transposition of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The aim of this text was to reduce inequalities between persons with disabilities and others, but this report is too ambiguous about the definition of "disability".  There is no delimitation of the scope of the directive. Indeed, in this report, the good objectives mentioned above are quickly misguided to address other issues such as the reception of migrants, gender equality and free movement. On these themes as well as on disability, the report makes a mistake. Introducing egalitarianism between people with disabilities and others, they must be able to do everything and like everyone else, which is a dogmatic vision of integration into society (forced inclusion in an open environment).  While I am, of course, in favour of the proper integration of these people with disabilities, I am opposed to the strategy put in place by the Commission in this area.  I voted against it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has a progressive and positive approach to persons with disabilities, including the gender and rights approach of girls with disabilities and a recognition of the role that the economic crisis has played in devaluing the provision of quality services for people with disabilities. The objective of this initiative report is to respond to the list of recommendations of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, ensuring that the views of the European Parliament are considered in the report of the European Commission (to be submitted in September). Among other things, the report invites the Union to ratify the Optional Protocol to the Convention, welcomes the proposal for a European Accessibility Law and calls for its rapid adoption, calls on the Commission to review the European Disability Strategy and develop a new Union strategy on the CDPD and a revision of legislation to ensure full compliance and implementation of the CDPD.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Colleagues, I supported the report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which covers all aspects of the problem and contains the necessary recommendations to the institutions and Member States to make significant progress in improving the situation of almost 80 million groups of European citizens with disabilities. The founding legislation requires the Union to combat any form of discrimination on grounds of disability and confers on it the power to adopt legislation to address such discrimination. Moreover, our principles should go further than eliminating discrimination. Our actions must be aimed at creating an inclusive society in which people with specific abilities can be realised as equals to other citizens. The rapid uptake of digital and information technologies provides a wonderful opportunity to make easier use of the specific opportunities of people with disabilities, to better exercise their rights and freedoms, to lead independent and active lives.  I agree with the recommendation that greater attention should be paid to women and girls with disabilities who are at greater risk in our societies. As a leading defender of human rights, the EU is in a power to make tangible progress for this group of decent citizens.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I support initiatives to draw attention to the difficulties faced by people with disabilities and to the attention of people with disabilities to their potential and the contribution they can make, including through specific educational programmes in schools; I stress that the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is important, in particular, because it changes the views that have developed in cultures, i.e. recognises that people with disabilities are transformed into barriers to the socio-economic environment rather than their disabilities.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with special regard to the Concluding Observations of the UN CRPD Committee. The CRPD covers a large range of rights, spanning into all areas of life. It deplores the discrimination and exclusion that persons with disabilities still face today and underlines the need to ensure that discrimination in all aspects on the grounds of disability is prohibited in the European Union. I voted in favour because I am of the opinion that disability-based discrimination must be tackled in the same way as discrimination on other grounds, including discrimination on more than one ground. This is especially important for women and children with disabilities, older persons and individuals who have complex support needs, including those with intellectual and psychosocial disabilities.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and its Optional Protocol were adopted on 13 December 2006 and the Union acceded to that convention in December 2010. The 28 Member States of the Union signed the Convention and 26 have ratified it. In this context, this report is being carried out, which deals with those issues which involve difficulties at national level and are therefore better dealt with at European level. The report stresses that institutions should be a model in the implementation of this convention and the need for a hierarchy of human rights, since discrimination on the grounds of disability should be addressed in the same way as discrimination on other grounds, which is particularly important for women and children with disabilities , older people and people who have complex supportive needs, particularly those with an intellectual or psychosocial disability. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the first human rights treaty of the 21st century and the first to sign the Union as a whole.  Today we voted on Parliament's response to the Committee's Conclusions on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, as well as the steps we believe should be taken to implement it. And in this report both content and forms are important, because organizations of people with disabilities have been involved throughout the process.  The labour market share of persons with disabilities is 58.5%, compared to 80.5%, of people without disabilities. And these figures are even worse for women, at 44%. Therefore, among all the proposals in the report, I would like to highlight one which calls for support for people's independent lives, equal opportunities and equal access to digital society. It is necessary for the Council to end once and for all the blocking of the Anti-Discrimination Directive and the Marrakesh Treaty.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is one of the most important human rights conventions and the first signed by the European Union as a whole. For its implementation, this report requires that accessibility legislation be implemented, that EU-funded programmes and projects comply with this Convention, and that a structured dialogue be established with organisations representing persons with disabilities. For us these rights are fundamental to achieving a just society with equality for people with disabilities, so we voted in favour of the text.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the Labour Party has long championed the rights of those living with disabilities at every level of government. In the UK, there are an estimated 11 million people with a limiting long-term illness, impairment or disability, with the most commonly reported impairments being those that affect mobility, lifting or carrying. Mainstream society often excludes people with disabilities and they are effectively denied their human rights.  The report pays special attention to the EU institutions themselves, which are to be a role model in implementing the Convention. This includes staff regulations and recruitment and retention practices as well as public events hosted by Parliament and on the Parliament’s premises. I am of the opinion that there is no hierarchy of human rights and disability-based discrimination must be tackled in the same way as discrimination on other grounds, including discrimination on more than one ground. This is especially important for women and children with disabilities, older persons and individuals who have complex support needs, including those with intellectual and psychosocial disabilities.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report. The EU became the first organisation to accede to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in December 2010. This is the first (and so far only) international human rights treaty that the EU as a whole has ratified.  All 28 EU Member States have signed the Treaty; 25 of them have ratified it, Finland and Ireland have not. When writing this document, the Netherlands is about to join the Convention. The Treaty covers a wide variety of rights in all areas of life, some of which are outside the EU's competence. That is why Member States must introduce the Convention equally at all levels, including at regional and national level.  We believe that human rights do not have a hierarchy and that discrimination on the grounds of disability should be addressed in the same way as discrimination on other grounds, including discrimination on more than one ground. This is particularly important for women and children with disabilities, the elderly and those in need of complex support, including those with intellectual and psychosocial disabilities.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The integration of people with disabilities into our society remains a challenge.  The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities ratified by the EU in 2010 takes stock of its implementation and the final observations of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.  Unsurprisingly, the report notes that many disparities remain, particularly between Member States. People with disabilities face multiple forms of discrimination and forms of violence that can be added to each other, especially when you are a woman, a child or a refugee...  The creation of a European framework could provide guarantees on the effective implementation of the rights of people with disabilities, the promotion of their personal autonomy, accessibility, access to employment, social integration and autonomy, as well as the elimination of all forms of discrimination.  The focus is also on accessibility to transport and buildings in new construction projects.   This report is a force for proposal and shows the long way to go. I voted in favour, dreaming that this type of proposal could actually be implemented by the Member States. Unfortunately, this is far from a priority and in reality the EU has little influence on these issues.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The CRPD is the first international human rights treaty to be ratified by the EU and signed by all Member States (although only 27 have ratified it). Its principles go beyond combating discrimination, pointing to the full enjoyment of human rights by all people with a disability and their families. The report advocates full implementation of the principles of the CRPD, making references to the conditions of people with disabilities, in particular in terms of inclusion in the education system, facilitating the conditions for labour or mobility. It also points out that austerity and impoverishment measures for the population have had very negative consequences, and have taken away rights and access to social services that support these people. The report is essentially considered to be positive.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting because some of the passages in this resolution are still unclear to me.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. – As a champion of the rights of persons with disabilities and a link member to the CRPD (UN Committee of the Rights of Persons with Disability) for the Committee on Culture and Education, I welcome the adoption of this report. The Labour Party has long championed the rights of those living with disabilities at every level of government. In the UK, there are an estimated 11 million people with a limiting long-term illness, impairment or disability, with the most commonly reported impairments being those that affect mobility, lifting or carrying.  The report pays special attention to the EU institutions themselves, which are to be a role model in implementing the Convention. This includes staff regulations and recruitment and retention practices as well as public events hosted by Parliament and on Parliament’s premises.  Mainstream society often excludes people with disabilities and they are effectively denied their human rights. I am of the opinion that disability-based discrimination must be tackled in the same way as discrimination on other grounds, including multiple discrimination. This is especially important for women and children with disabilities, older persons and individuals who have complex support needs, including those with intellectual and psychosocial disabilities.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this own-initiative report. It involves an important international convention, the first one to which the EU was a signatory. It is important that the rights of persons with disabilities are protected and that they can be included in our society. It is important that reports such as this one safeguard this.  This report points out some difficulties that need to be addressed with regard to the implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) and includes useful recommendations on potential improvements. Furthermore, the report is complete and well-structured, including specific rights and obligations, as well as recommendations towards the EU institutions.  Finally, I welcome the request to systematically raise implementation of the CRPD when dealing with third countries, where this is relevant and applicable. In sum, I can only applaud the EU’s continuous support for persons with disabilities.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 People with disabilities must have full access to all rights in any situation. It is one of the hallmarks of a society that respects the dignity of every person. However, sexual and reproductive rights in many countries also include the so-called right to abortion, thereby taking away the human dignity of the unborn. This is a matter of principle for me, and my conscience will not allow me to vote in favour of any proposal that considers the act of killing an unborn human foetus to be a right for another person. That is why I was unable to support the proposal in the final vote and abstained.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This resolution sets out the issues and conditions for the full implementation of the rights of persons with disabilities, whose protection and safeguarding of them is our top priority. Of course I supported it, voting in favour.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU acceded to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in December 2010, as the first regional integration organisation. This is the first international human rights treaty that the EU has ratified as a whole and remains the only one to date. With ratification, the EU is now subject to the control of the Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. This report has the primary objective of focusing on the issues highlighted in the concluding remarks of the UN CRPD Committee, in particular the recommendations that fall within EU competence. Among the most important points in the report is the need to ensure full accessibility for people with disabilities in the labour market, education and training programmes and erasmus+, youth guarantee and EURES initiatives; the removal of architectural barriers from public buildings and workplaces; recognition of the importance of caregivers; and, finally, the establishment of a social protection base in the EU, so that the right to an adequate standard of living and social protection for persons with disabilities is respected. I voted in favour of this report so that European citizens with disabilities are increasingly protected.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The wish list of the European Parliament's report on the "implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities" cannot hide the fact that unpopular EU policy does not exclude disabled people either. Even the reliefs requested for disabled countries in a memorandum, such as in Greece, concern only severe disability or extreme poverty, sharing the latter among the disabled, as already inadequate benefits have been reduced by 50%.  Cuts in health – welfare, their inability to pay for medicines and consumables makes it difficult or interrupts their treatment. Disability pensions, allowances, benefits are cut and linked to property criteria, while invalidity rates are also cut. Flexible work particularly affects the disabled as their health requires a stable environment. Many who work in privatised former public companies are laid off.  Staff and infrastructure shortages in public special education have driven 200,000 disabled children out of education. In view of the above, the European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party voted white in this report, underlining the need for: Mass recruitment of disabled people, with full rights. Exclusively state, free health - welfare - special education system, without any business action. Free medicines, treatments, prevention, rehabilitation without conditions and conditions. Free inclusion in education. Support for the unemployed as long as unemployment lasts.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Stevens report because I believe that the full inclusion of persons with disabilities is not only a right and a fair benefit to the persons concerned, but an added value for society as a whole, because it can benefit from the value and diversity of the skills that these people hold. I therefore believe that all persons with disabilities have the right to live in a society in which they enjoy equal opportunities with others, in order to ensure their full inclusion and participation in society.  In particular, I would like to highlight in this report the call on the European Commission and the Council to systematically take into account the needs of people with disabilities in the context of the revision of passenger rights regulations in different modes of transport, as the EU has committed itself to in the European Disability Strategy 2010-2020, which aims to create a barrier-free Europe.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the Report on the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with particular reference to the conclusions of the United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. We must give people with disabilities the opportunity to live in a society where they will enjoy the same opportunities as others and be guaranteed full inclusion and participation. I therefore join the call for a comprehensive cross-sectoral review and evaluation of current and future legislation and EU funding programmes in order to integrate the disability aspect into all legislative policies and strategies and to ensure the effective enjoyment and exercise of recognised rights.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: I voted today in favour of the acceptance of this objection, because I believe that the authorisation granted by the Commission to health claims concerning caffeine on certain foodstuffs is in no way in line with the objectives of the regulation. Indications of increased performance in terms of increased readiness and greater concentration should not only appear in foods intended for children, but also on foods intended for adolescents.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Christel Schaldemose, for all her work on this important issue. The fact that today we made a decision to object to the use of four health claims on caffeine is very important. Why is it important? It is important because we felt as MEPs that these claims, these health claims, would be misused and abused, in particular by the energy drinks industry. We have been doing some work on the energy drinks industry in this House on the issue of how they have been marketing their products to children and we know from many local authorities across the countries that we work within that there are issues about consumption of energy drinks amongst young people. I would like to commend the work of a particular individual, Councillor Norma Hart from Edinburgh City Council, who has done so much work and mounted a campaign on this issue about energy drinks. What I want to end with is the fact that today we did not get this stuff through on nutrient profiling. This is something we have to do in the future.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Madam President, I would like to provide some details from this report. 68% of adolescents regularly consume energy drinks. 25% of adolescents who drink energy drink three or more cans at once. Regular consumption of energy drinks in children and adolescents leads to the development of headaches, sleep disorders and behavioral problems. I think, my fellow Members, that this report is about more than it seems to be about. This is a kind of vision of the current state of the European Union, not only of its state of health, but also of its mental and moral state, that Europe has reached the point where the big capitals who do not fear anything for profit are watering our children with poisons, and for some reason they are in such a state that they need these poisons. We should think very carefully here about the roots, the underlying causes and contexts, and at some time we should finally write something bigger about this.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I just want to say that obviously I voted with the Group on this, there was no real controversy. But I have noticed in recent times that more and more people when shopping are looking at the label of what they buy. I think that is an educational process, so for that reason I have a slight difficulty with the title here – ‘permitted health claims made on foods’. The word ‘claims’ is not really what we should be looking at. It is either a fact or it is not, and it should not be a claim based on some survey or whatever the food producers are undertaking, and often these claims can be misleading. That is why it is so important that we are discussing this today, especially in relation to young children and indeed their parents who want to give them the best possible food.  There are too many claims now that if you take this drink or that drink you are going to be faster and stronger and a great sports person, so they consume more than they should be consuming – and that is another issue, the actual volume. I think we have a lot of work to do, but this is a start and I support it.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We oppose the unelected Commission legislating on this matter. We strongly oppose any introduction of restrictions on the market by the EU. The UK Parliament will be able to decide if and how to legislate on this matter.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection, because authorizing healthy effects on caffeinated beverages would detract from the negative effects these beverages have on consumers, especially young people (who consume these types of beverages the most). Energy drinks, far from having nutritional benefits, are high in sugar and caffeine and are known to cause headaches, sleep problems and behavioral problems in young people who consume them regularly.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This is an objection to a Commission project based on a positive (or even oriented) opinion of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) on caffeine-based products. This would have major therapeutic or health virtues, for concentration, endurance, etc.  Caffeine is often found in sugary or fatty products. With young Europeans already showing tendencies to be overweight, the rapporteur questions the relevance of EFSA's opinion and the Commission's draft. While it is reassuring by claiming to limit pro-caffeine indications to adult products only, it does not specify how it will force the sales channels to distribute them only to adults. In addition, the report points to the shortcomings in the EFSA study: lack of gender distinction in assessing effects on metabolisms, lack of analysis of side effects, etc. Thus, the Commission's project appears to be based on weak public health reasons.  I have therefore naturally supported this objection.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which urges the Commission to place restrictions on the marketing of energy drinks to children and adolescents. The Commission’s draft measure authorises health claims on caffeine relating to an increase in endurance performance, an increase in endurance capacity, increased alertness and improved concentration.  There are concerns however about the adverse effects this could have on consumers, especially on young people. Energy drinks have a high sugar and caffeine content and they are known to cause headaches, sleep problems and behavioural problems in young people who regularly consume them.  Moreover, growth in the energy-drinks market has boomed and children and teenagers are some of the biggest consumers. Warning labels are being ignored whilst the industry’s code of practice, which is merely voluntary anyway, only commits it not to market energy drinks to children under 12. Instead of pushing forward with health claims which help to promote these energy products, the Commission must stop dragging its heels and come forward with the nutrient profiles which have already been agreed upon in legislation, instead of giving energy drinks a leg-up on the market.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this objection as it highlights the risks of misleading the public about the possibility of drinks, high in caffeine, containing health and nutrition claims-signs

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This objection relates to health claims that may be made by caffeine-containing products. These products can be solid foods or beverages.  Caffeine-based products do not need claims to be sold and are not really the work of French manufacturers. The proposed claims (caffeine improves endurance, alertness and concentration) pose a real problem with energy drinks as they are likely to lead to dangerous consumption (especially when mixed with alcohol), however, the French coffee union has told us that these claims are expected by companies (including some French) to boost coffee consumption among young people and that no French company manufactures beverage. That is why I abstained from voting on this resolution.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006 requires that, by 19 January 2009, the The Commission will identify specific nutrient profiles that foods or categories of foods must meet in order to be able to make nutrition or health claims. The Commission has so far not identified these nutrient profiles. According to the draft Commission Regulation, the claim that caffeine increases vigilance and concentration should not be used in the descriptions of foods intended for children and adolescents. The voluntary Code of Practice for the Trade and Labelling of Energy Drinks industry provides only for the non-sale of energy drinks to children under 12 years of age. I agree with the adoption of the draft Commission regulation because it is incompatible with the objective and content of Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006. The Commission should consider restricting the sale of energy drinks to children and adolescents.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this objection to prohibiting "health claims" on caffeine-containing products. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has allowed claims such as "caffeine to improve concentration" to be included.  However, nothing is said about the side effects of heavy caffeine consumption, such as incontinence, or the dangers of caffeine-alcohol mixing.  However, these claims are necessary to revive coffee consumption among young people who often prefer energy drinks with much more serious effects on their health, a boost all the more important than expected by a substantial number of companies.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I objected to the adoption of the Commission's draft regulation. The European Parliament has voted in favour of a ban on certain claims used in the sale of sugary drinks and caffeine-based energy drinks.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Some studies show that 68% of adolescents and 18% of children regularly consume energy drinks, mostly in the form of cans. A single 250 ml can contain up to 27 grams of sugar and about 80 milligrams of caffeine. These are widely used soft drinks whose consumption has been associated with headaches, sleep disorders and behavioral problems in children and adolescents who use them regularly. My vote in favour of the objection put forward in Parliament today is based on the belief that it may be harmful to allow nutritional claims to be present on sugar-containing drinks and energizing drinks containing caffeine, which promote their ability to increase their attention or concentration. I am convinced that the use of nutrition claims can, in this case, encourage excessive consumption of energy drinks, which is why I strongly supported the ENVI Committee's motion for a resolution.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of administrative objection to health claims about caffeine, as it aims to make visible, among other things, that energy drinks generate undesirable habits/patterns of consumption among young people. It specifically identifies adolescents as the main sector of energy drink consumption and the undesiness effects on excessive sugar intake according to WHO recommended values.  In addition to other substances and additives, a recommendation is established for the correct labelling and identification of certain products that may affect proper development at an early age.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which states that sugary and energy drink labels should not highlight the mention that they help to increase alertness or concentration, as they could encourage high sugar consumption among adolescents, who are the largest group of consumers of them and since transfer is essential for the consumer. The aim is also to prevent health claims that are not suitable for children and adolescents. It includes both caffeinated beverages and energy drinks that also contain a large amount of sugar. And I don't think these kinds of drinks should carry any kind of health claims.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report relates to an objection under Article 106 to authorized health claims relating to foodstuffs. This applies to products containing caffeine. EFSA has given a favourable opinion on several claims (coffee increases vigilance, concentration, endurance...). Nevertheless, this opinion has several defects (doses taken into account, no difference between men and women, no consideration of side effects ...). However, the rapporteur points out here that the consumption of these caffeine-based products also affects the youngest, that they are often very sweet drinks and that more than a third of young Europeans are already overweight. The Commission has restrictions on the protection of this young audience.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the resolution is balanced and devoid of particular critical issues I therefore intended to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Commission has submitted a proposal for a regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 432/2012 to add four health claims concerning the effect of a large amount of caffeine on food. The four healthy demands are "Caffeine contributes to increased endurance," "Caffeine contributes to increased capacity," "Caffeine helps increase alertness" and "Caffeine helps improve concentration." Energy drinks are virtually the only foods that have a high enough caffeine level to be able to use these health claims. However, it is children and adolescents who account for the majority of consumers of energy drinks, who also have a high level of sugar per can. Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006 required the establishment of nutritional profiles with which food or certain categories of foods must have nutritional or healthy properties. This would ensure that products that contain a high level of caffeine and a high level of sugar cannot use health claims. However, this requirement is not being met. I have therefore supported the objection for the Commission to withdraw its proposal.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament opposes the amended Commission Regulation on certain permitted health claims made on foods, with the exception of those referring to the reduction of disease risk, children's development and health. The European Parliament does not support the Commission regulation, as the Commission has not yet established these nutrient profiles. The resolution states that adolescents are the largest group of energy drink users (68% of teenagers and 18% of children regularly consume energy drinks), while 25% of adolescents who consume energy drinks drink three or more cans at the same time. The voluntary Code of Practice for the Trade and Labelling of Energy Drinks industry provides for the non-sale of energy drinks to children under 12 years of age. It is also stressed that a 250 ml can of energy drink can contain up to 27 g of sugar and 80 mg of caffeine. Parliament considers that the commission's draft regulation that caffeine increases vigilance and concentration should not be used in food profiles for children and adolescents.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. According to European surveys, 68% of teenagers and 18% of children already drink energy drinks regularly. Drinks often consumed as soft drinks among young people can contain up to 27 grams of sugar and 87 milligrams of caffeine per can. Moreover, according to the warning on the label of the products, their consumption is not recommended for children and pregnant mothers at all. On the basis of the European Commission's draft, these drinks could have been marketed with inscriptions that increase alertness and have a positive effect on concentration capacity. The European Food Authority has found the scientific basis for the claims to be proven. However, by regulating health claims on foodstuffs, the legislator's intention was not to promote products, but to inform consumers properly. In the case of children and minors, we must act with even greater responsibility. With controversial messages, we can not make popular drinks, the consumption of which is also recommended for adults in limited quantities. The health of young people must not be a victim of economic interests. On this basis, I voted in favour of parliament's objection.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. If I agree with EFSA on the virtues of caffeine, I do not think it is useful to advocate it especially among young people, because often this product is included in sugary sodas, even though far too many young people are already overweight. Caffeine-based products do not need positive claims from health agencies to sell, and therefore I vote for this objection.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which urges the Commission to place restrictions on the marketing of energy drinks to children and adolescents. The Commission’s draft measure authorises health claims on caffeine relating to an increase in endurance performance, an increase in endurance capacity, increased alertness and improved concentration.  There are concerns however about the adverse effects this could have on consumers, especially on young people. Energy drinks have a high sugar and caffeine content and they are known to cause headaches, sleep problems and behavioural problems in young people who regularly consume them.  Moreover, growth in the energy-drinks market has boomed and children and teenagers are some of the biggest consumers. Warning labels are being ignored whilst the industry’s code of practice, which is merely voluntary anyway, only commits it not to market energy drinks to children under 12. Instead of pushing forward with health claims which help to promote these energy products, the Commission must stop dragging its heels and come forward with the nutrient profiles which have already been agreed upon in legislation, instead of giving energy drinks a leg-up on the market.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This objection relates to health claims that may be presented by caffeine-containing products. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has issued a favourable opinion to claims that caffeine helps to improve concentration, alertness and helps increase endurance capacity. This objection is a reminder that caffeine-based products contain a relatively high amount of sugar and that non-moderate consumption of these products can be dangerous to health with a risk of being overweight. However, the Commission's draft includes restrictions, including prohibiting the use of these claims on products targeting children and adolescents. That is why I abstained on this objection.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The energy drink industry’s voluntary Code of Practice for the Marketing and Labelling of Energy Drinks only commits not to market energy drinks to children under the age of 12. Adolescents represent the largest group of energy-drink consumers, 68% of whom regularly consume energy drinks. These beverages can contain up to 27g of sugar per 250 ml, more than the World Health Organization’s recommendation that adults and children receive no more than 10% of their daily energy intake from free sugars and that a further reduction to below 5% (approximately 25g) per day would provide additional health benefits. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has also found evidence that a high intake of sugar in the form of sweetened beverages might contribute to weight gain.  Therefore, I voted against the adoption of the draft Commission regulation since excessive consumption of energy drinks has been linked to headaches, sleep problems and behavioural problems in children and adolescents who regularly consume them. Member States should introduce rules on the marketing of beverages and food with high caffeine content to children and adolescents so that the use of nutrition and health claim will not be ambiguous or misleading.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's objection to the Commission's amendment regulation establishing a list of authorised health claims relating to food. This regulation would allow for information for consumers on the potential to improve concentration as well as an increase in the endurance and physical abilities of caffeine-based products. Energy drinks are caffeine-based products. The problem is that such health information on energy drinks would likely influence the consumption of young people.  However, these drinks are very often the subject of health warnings and are also very sweet. Increased consumption could be harmful to young people. So you have to be careful.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which urges the Commission to place restrictions on the marketing of energy drinks to children and adolescents.
