The Commission’s draft measure authorises health claims on caffeine relating to an increase in endurance performance, an increase in endurance capacity, increased alertness and improved concentration.  There are concerns however about the adverse effects this could have on consumers, especially on young people. Energy drinks have a high sugar and caffeine content and they are known to cause headaches, sleep problems and behavioural problems in young people who regularly consume them.  Growth in the energy-drinks market has boomed and children and teenagers are some of the biggest consumers. Warning labels are being ignored whilst the industry’s code of practice, which is merely voluntary anyway, only commits it not to market energy drinks to children under 12. Instead of pushing forward with health claims which help to promote these energy products, the Commission must stop dragging its heels and come forward with the nutrient profiles which have already been agreed upon in legislation, instead of giving energy drinks a leg-up on the market.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the objection to the draft Commission regulation as I do not agree with the ideas set out in the resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the objection is to urge the Commission to withdraw the draft regulation presented and to consider introducing restrictions on the sale of energy drinks to children and adolescents. The M5S Europe Delegation therefore voted in favour of the objection in the hope that the use of health declarations for caffeine would be reassessed.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. – We oppose the adoption of the Commission's draft regulation, as we consider that this draft Commission Regulation is incompatible with the purpose and content of Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. 1924/2006.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the objection under Article 106 to the permitted health claims made about food.  In recent years there has been an attempt to weaken the previously existing regulations, which have introduced a positive measure to protect citizens. It is particularly important to protect those social groups that are directly threatened by the lack of specific food standards, such as adolescents.  Since this objection works for the benefit of the citizens, I have decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am very pleased that Parliament has been united for the second time in rejecting the inclusion of nutrient profiles. In my opinion, today's victory is a great victory, because it has once again reiterated that the Union is not in favour of these profiles, which are not only not useful to the citizen, but tend to misdeed his choices. As I have been saying for a long time, I am strongly opposed to these profiles, which give the state the task of stating whether a product is healthy or unhealthy, without assessing the amount of consumption of that product and the diet of the person who consumes it as well as the lifestyle. Each product, more or less healthy, must be evaluated in its context, and I therefore think it is wrong that, with nutrient profiles, it should be decided a priori which food is good and which is bad.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion for a resolution and noted no objections.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the need to take measures to strengthen consumer health protection by ensuring greater safety on the quality and provenance of food products. However, I believe that this proposal is not a necessary measure for the protection of health and that it is appropriate for the Commission to draw up a list of health claims on food consumption.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of the objection against accepting health claims on energy drinks, because I believe they are misleading and encourage increased consumption. It is not primarily the caffeine in energy drinks that is unhealthy, but the sugar that is associated with, among other things, obesity and diabetes. However, writing health claims on food requires that the entire content be taken into account, not just individual substances. In this case, this is particularly problematic because one of the largest target groups for these products is children and young people. However, I do not believe that the sale of energy drinks should be completely banned, but only that claims aimed at increasing consumption should also take into account negative aspects. I hope that the Commission will complete its mission as soon as possible to develop nutrient profiles to improve the use of health claims.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection, because authorizing healthy effects on caffeinated beverages would detract from the negative effects these beverages have on consumers, especially young people (who consume these types of beverages the most). Energy drinks, far from having nutritional benefits, are high in sugar and caffeine and are known to cause headaches, sleep problems and behavioral problems in young people who consume them regularly.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The document concerns the approval of health claims concerning caffeine. The opposing party justifies it as incompatibility with the objectives of the basic act, arguing that vigilance and concentration statements cannot apply to children, including teenagers, stressing that teenagers are the largest group of consumers of energy drinks. Furthermore, the resolution provides that, in the absence of the nutritional profiles to which the Commission was required under the Food Claims Regulation (1924/2006), caffeine claims may be applied to energy drinks which have a higher sugar content. According to experts, the opposition is non-composed and exaggerates certain aspects. Contrary to the assurances in the text, this measure applies to all caffeinated products, not just energy drinks. Energy drinks account for only 1% of the eu's total soft drinks market, and calories from all drinks account for only 3% of all calories consumed in the EU. In addition, EFSA estimates that the vast majority of calories in a teenager's diet come from chocolate, coffee and tea. Personally, I believe that some of the concerns raised in the document are well-known. Experience with the use of caffeine can create the illusion that the consumption of caffeine and its containing products (including energy drinks) is good for health. Nevertheless, I believe that the substantive content of the document should be deepened, so I abstained.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Misleading health claims are a threat to all citizens, especially children. Claims that caffeine increases focus and concentration, among other things, for products containing high levels of caffeine like energy drinks should not be allowed. This objection aims to stop foods which are unhealthy from claiming that they have health benefits. I strongly agree that these foods should not be targeted at children and adolescents. I voted in favour of this objection pursuant to rule 106 as I believe that the health of our citizens is a main priority and such health claims are incorrect.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution proposes to oppose new health claims on the benefits of caffeine. In its proposal, the European Commission authorises health claims relating to improved concentration and physical performance for caffeine-based products. These claims take the form of positive advertising on sugary drinks and energy drinks, of which young people are the main consumers.  Considering the health risks associated with excessive consumption of sugar and caffeine, I supported this objection from the European Parliament and asked the Commission to review its draft act.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose the unelected Commission legislating on this matter. We strongly oppose any introduction of restrictions on the market by the EU. The UK Parliament will be able to decide if and how to legislate on this matter.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to refusing permission for caffeine-based products, such as energy drinks, to indicate health benefits on their packaging. I think this objection sends a negative message to European citizens. The European Union is going through a difficult period and is increasingly being called into question. More and more people are denouncing its overly bureaucratic nature. It is therefore not desirable to add yet another standard. The European Union is accused of producing rules at all costs, without taking into account the true expectations of citizens: so let us not start by regulating energy drinks!  I believe that the ban on such health indications on caffeine-based products is not a matter for the European Union, but for the Member States, which will be able to legislate with full account of their consumption habits.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. According to European surveys, 68% of teenagers and 18% of children already drink energy drinks regularly. Drinks often consumed as soft drinks among young people can contain up to 27 grams of sugar and 87 milligrams of caffeine per can. Moreover, according to the warning on the label of the products, their consumption is not recommended for children and pregnant mothers at all. According to the European Commission's draft, these drinks could have been marketed with inscriptions that increase alertness and have a positive effect on concentration capacity. The European Food Authority has found the scientific basis for the claims to be proven. However, by regulating health claims on foodstuffs, the legislator's intention was not to promote products, but to inform consumers properly. In the case of children and minors, we must act with even greater responsibility. With controversial messages, we can not make popular drinks, the consumption of which is also recommended for adults in limited quantities. The health of young people must not be a victim of economic interests. On this basis, I voted in favour of parliament's objection.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation supports the objection to health claims against drinks containing caffeine, mainly energy drinks. These claims would mean that the product is indicated that it contributes to an increase in alertness and an improvement in concentration. Our main motivation for objecting to this proposal is that it goes against the spirit of health claims legislation: allowing a claim gives the impression that these products are healthy or promote health, which in this case is difficult to defend. Another reason to support the objection is the high sugar content contained in such energy drinks and the fact that children and young people are in practice important consumers of these products. Even in the light of the fight against obesity in children and young people, allowing dubious health claims for these products is not a good thing. Finally, efsa's opinion shows how difficult it is to establish thresholds for safe caffeine consumption for children and teenagers. It is important to point out that the objection is not opposed to the placing on the market of the products concerned, but to the granting of a health claim for these products.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this objection because I believe that sugary drinks and energy drinks containing caffeine should not be allowed to exercise vigilance or concentration. Such claims encourage excessive consumption of this type of beverage and result in increased consumption of caffeine and sugar (a 250 ml can of energy drink can contain up to 27 g of sugar and 80 mg of caffeine) by children and adolescents, who are already the main consumers of energy drinks. Studies indicate that 68% of adolescents and 18% of children drink it regularly. The consumption of energy drinks presents risks in terms of obesity or medical complications in the longer term. It is also thought to be related to disorders such as headaches, sleep disorders and other behavioural disorders in children and adolescents who regularly use energy drinks.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has issued a favourable opinion to claims that caffeine helps improve concentration, alertness and endurance. However, the consumption of these caffeine-based products, which are often very sweet drinks, also affects the youngest, a third of whom are already overweight. However, the Commission's draft includes restrictions to protect this public.  EFSA's opinion has several defects regarding the doses taken into account for the study: no consideration of differences in male/female metabolism, no information on the side effects of heavy caffeine consumption. To the extent that the aforementioned allegations are expected by French companies, which otherwise do not manufacture energy drinks, I preferred to abstain on this objection.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this file because this proposal refers to caffeine in energy drinks, which is somewhat misleading. It deals with all caffeine-containing products and actually has a much wider range. Moreover, energy drinks account for only 1% and also calories account for only 3% of the calories consumed in the average diet of EU citizens, and the most caffeine consumed by adolescents actually comes from sources other than energy drinks. I agree with the objection that greater attention should be paid to sugar and the profile of nutrients in children and adolescents. However, I do not agree that this objection is the right way, nor the place for this discussion. This issue falls into a much broader and important discussion regarding nutrition, overweight and consumer awareness and general education in this regard.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution opposes the adoption of the Commission's draft regulation and calls on it to withdraw its draft regulation. We are voting in favour as a whole, and we believe that this draft Commission regulation is not compatible with the purpose and content of Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. 1924/2006.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. According to European surveys, 68% of teenagers and 18% of children already drink energy drinks regularly. Drinks often consumed as soft drinks among young people can contain up to 27 grams of sugar and 87 milligrams of caffeine per can. Moreover, according to the warning on the label of the products, their consumption is not recommended for children and pregnant mothers at all. According to the European Commission's draft, these drinks could have been marketed with inscriptions that increase alertness and have a positive effect on concentration capacity. The European Food Authority has found the scientific basis for the claims to be proven. However, by regulating health claims on foodstuffs, the legislator's intention was not to promote products, but to inform consumers properly. In the case of children and minors, we must act with even greater responsibility. With controversial messages, we can not make popular drinks, the consumption of which is also recommended for adults in limited quantities. The health of young people must not be a victim of economic interests. On this basis, I voted in favour of parliament's objection.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this objection, it intends to urge the Commission to withdraw the draft regulation presented and to consider introducing restrictions on the sale of energy drinks to children and adolescents. 68% of adolescents and 18% of children regularly consume energy drinks and as many as 25% of adolescents who use them drink three or more consecutive cans. I believe that a 'health statement' should be used for substances for which an 'improvement' link with regard to health aspects is clear. The inclusion of a health statement, such as "caffeine helps to increase mental lucidity", has an impact on consumption and can push the target market to consume more product. I supported the objection.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. I agree that energy drinks should not bear claims that caffeine "contributes to increased surveillance" and to "improve concentration" because such labelling could encourage young people to consume these sugar-rich drinks and are associated with sleep and behaviour problems in children and adolescents. Adolescents are precisely the largest group of energy drinkers: 68% of adolescents and 18% of children regularly consume these drinks. A 250 ml can can contain up to 27 g of sugar and 80 mg of caffeine. The World Health Organisation (WHO) recommends that adults and children do not get more than 10 % of the daily dose of energy from free sugars and that a reduction to less than 5 % (about 25 g) per day would have additional health benefits. I also agree that Member States should consider introducing rules on the marketing of high-caffeine beverages or foods with caffeine in addition to children and adolescents.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution objects to an initiative of the European Commission to amend Regulation (EU) No 432/2012 establishing a list of authorised health claims relating to food that do not refer to the reduction of the risk of disease or child development and health. By January 2009, the Commission should have established the specific nutritional profiles that foods or certain categories of food must respect in order to be able to make nutritional or health claims, as well as the conditions for the use of nutrition and health claims with regard to nutritional profiles. The Commission has submitted a draft regulation in which allegations are present that caffeine contributes to increasing surveillance and improving concentration. It is therefore considered that the Commission's draft regulation is not compatible with the purpose and content of Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006, which states that 'nutrition and health claims should not ... encourage or justify the excessive consumption of a given food'. The European Food Safety Authority has concluded that there is not enough information to establish a safe level of caffeine consumption for children. The problems arise mainly in relation to the consumption of energy drinks by adolescents. We voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission should have set specific nutritional profiles by January 2009 to which certain types of food must correspond in order to be labelled as nutritious or beneficial to health. However, the European Commission has not yet set these nutritional profiles. The Voluntary Code of Practice for the Sale and Labelling of Energy Drinks, which is intended for the energy drinks sector, only provides for a commitment not to sell energy drinks to children under the age of 12.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution opposes the adoption of the Commission's draft regulation and calls on it to withdraw its draft regulation. I am voting in favour as a whole and I believe that this draft Commission regulation is not compatible with the purpose and content of Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. 1924/2006.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. According to European surveys, 68% of teenagers and 18% of children already drink energy drinks regularly. Drinks often consumed as soft drinks among young people can contain up to 27 grams of sugar and 87 milligrams of caffeine per can. Moreover, according to the warning on the label of the products, their consumption is not recommended for children and pregnant mothers at all. According to the European Commission's draft, these drinks could have been marketed with inscriptions that increase alertness and have a positive effect on concentration capacity. The European Food Authority has found the scientific basis for the claims to be proven. However, by regulating health claims on foodstuffs, the legislator's intention was not to promote products, but to inform consumers properly. In the case of children and minors, we must act with even greater responsibility. With controversial messages, we can not make popular drinks, the consumption of which is also recommended for adults in limited quantities. The health of young people must not be a victim of economic interests. On this basis, I voted in favour of parliament's objection.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. According to European surveys, 68% of teenagers and 18% of children already drink energy drinks regularly. Drinks often consumed as soft drinks among young people can contain up to 27 grams of sugar and 87 milligrams of caffeine per can. In the case of children and minors, we must act with even greater responsibility. With controversial messages, we can not make popular drinks, the consumption of which is also recommended for adults in limited quantities. The health of young people must not be a victim of economic interests. On this basis, I voted in favour of parliament's objection.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted against the objection to the amendment of the Regulation establishing a list of authorised health claims for foods other than those relating to the reduction of the risk of disease and the development and health of children for two main reasons. First, the European Food Safety Authority has produced a scientific report concluding that energy-qualified beverages are not actually a health risk, as long as they are taken in moderation. Secondly, because I do not think the solution is to point out or label more cans of drinks but not to educate children and young people well about the properties of these drinks.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's draft regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 432/2012 on the compilation of a list of permitted health claims on foodstuffs, other than those referring to the reduction of disease risks and the development and health of children, because I believe that the proposal to introduce health claims into caffeine content products is profoundly wrong both from a scientific and a political-educational point of view. Although caffeine has positive effects on the resistance and level of concentration of the individual, excessive intake nevertheless presents important contraindications in terms of anxiolytic effects, tachycardia and arrhythmia and stomach disorders. From an educational point of view, given the widespread use of sugar-rich energy drinks among adolescents, such health claims would increase the consumption of these drinks by children and adolescents, who should not be exposed to sugar consumption above a certain threshold. Finally, I remain opposed to the introduction of nutrient profiles in the EU, as they are misleading and unfit to protect the health of citizens. I think that there are no good foods and bad foods but healthy diets and unbalanced diets, as taught by the Mediterranean tradition.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted to protect consumers from misleading health claims found on energy drinks. Energy drinks should not be marketed as healthy, and especially not to children.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of administrative objection to health claims about caffeine, as it aims to make visible, among other things, that energy drinks generate undesirable habits/patterns of consumption among young people. It specifically identifies adolescents as the main sector of energy drink consumption and the undesiness effects on excessive sugar intake according to WHO recommended values.  In addition to other substances and additives, a recommendation is established for the correct labelling and identification of certain products that may affect proper development at an early age.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted to protect consumers from misleading health claims found on energy drinks. Energy drinks should not be marketed as healthy, and especially not to children.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this objection, which opposes the proposal to allow health claims relating to increased stamina and concentration capacity for caffeine-based products (including energy drinks). Such claims for these products would be dangerous in terms of public health. They would encourage the excessive consumption of these energy drinks, especially among young people, while they are also subject to health warnings and should be consumed in moderation, for example in view of their high sugar content.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. According to European surveys, 68% of teenagers and 18% of children already drink energy drinks regularly. Drinks often consumed as soft drinks among young people can contain up to 27 grams of sugar and 87 milligrams of caffeine per can. With controversial messages, we can not make popular drinks, the consumption of which is also recommended for adults in limited quantities. The health of young people must not be a victim of economic interests.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. I believe that the draft Commission regulation is not compatible with the aim and content of Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006 on nutrition and health claims made on foods. Further, there should be rules on the marketing of beverages with high caffeine content or foods with added caffeine to children and adolescents.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I had no objection to its contents.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the parliamentary objection because I believe that we should act with even greater responsibility in the case of children and minors. With controversial messages, we can not make popular drinks, the consumption of which is also recommended for adults in limited quantities. The health of young people must not be a victim of economic interests.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is not acceptable to have products targeting children and adolescents through misleading health claims. I fully support the effort to stop these health claims from being used.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the Commission's draft regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 2012/2013; 432/2012 establishing a list of permissible health claims made on food, other than those relating to the reduction of the risk of disease and the development and health of children, as this requires the Commission to withdraw its draft regulation. This avoids authorization for the use of health claims in the case of caffeine, and prevents energy drink producers from using health claims on their energy drinks that are predominantly consumed by adolescents in quantities exceeding the recommended daily intake of caffeine, which is also the case for products labelled "sugar-free". Therefore, I support this objection.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This objection relates to health claims that may be made by caffeine-containing products. These products can be solid foods or beverages. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has issued a favourable opinion on the following claims: "caffeine helps to improve concentration", "caffeine helps to improve alertness"; "Caffeine helps to increase endurance capacity", "caffeine contributes to an increase in endurance performance".   THE EFSA opinion has several defects: doses taken into account for the study, no consideration of differences in male/female metabolism, no information on the side effects of heavy caffeine consumption (for example incontinence).  A previous EFSA opinion had also been the subject of a motion resolution by Sylvie Goddyn, Mireille d'Ornano and myself to call for a ban on positive claims and information on the risks of caffeine and alcohol mixtures.  We are pleased that the parliamentary majority is following our suggestions. Caffeine-based products do not need claims to be sold and are not really the work of French manufacturers. I therefore supported that objection.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the Commission's draft regulation on the list of health claims authorised for food. The Commission's proposal authorises health claims relating to improved concentration and increased endurance and physical capacity through caffeinated products, such as energy drinks. However, it seems absurd that such products, which are forced to warn of the health risks associated with their consumption, can claim to offer health benefits. For vulnerable populations, this can lead to excessive consumption of such products, which are also very high in fast sugars.    This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection in order to prevent caffeine-containing energy drinks from promoting alertness or concentration, and to limit their consumption by children and adolescents who are particularly vulnerable. This could lead to an incentive to consume these drinks, which are also very popular with teenagers, even though they contain a lot of sugar.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This resolution is directed against EFSA's scientifically sound findings and recommendations on caffeine in general and against the marketing of energy drinks in particular. I do not think it is expedient to throw scientific knowledge overboard and to take an entire industry hostage on an issue on which EFSA has a rarely clear opinion. I am therefore voting against this resolution.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to protect consumers from misleading health claims being used on energy drinks.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. According to European surveys, 68% of teenagers and 18% of children already drink energy drinks regularly. Drinks often consumed as soft drinks among young people can contain up to 27 grams of sugar and 87 milligrams of caffeine per can. Moreover, according to the warning on the label of the products, their consumption is not recommended for children and pregnant mothers at all. According to the European Commission's draft, these drinks could have been marketed with inscriptions that increase alertness and have a positive effect on concentration capacity. The European Food Authority has found the scientific basis for the claims to be proven. However, by regulating health claims on foodstuffs, the legislator's intention was not to promote products, but to inform consumers properly. In the case of children and minors, we must act with even greater responsibility. With controversial messages, we can not make popular drinks, the consumption of which is also recommended for adults in limited quantities. The health of young people must not be a victim of economic interests. On this basis, I voted in favour of parliament's objection.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. The ÖVP delegation abstained from the vote on the objection to health claims. EFSA already found in 2015 that caffeine is also safe for children and adolescents if the limit values are met. This assessment is not sufficiently taken into account in the objection. It should also be noted that the protection of minors is a competence of the Member States. The one-sided emphasis on energy drinks in the objection is incomprehensible: the data generally apply to products containing caffeine. Health claims alone do not increase consumption. They are intended to inform consumers.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This resolution called for the introduction of restrictions on the marketing of energy drinks to children and adolescents and on food relating to caffeine. I call on the Commission to establish nutrient profiles and to remind them of the definition of health claims. I voted in favour of this resolution since I believe that through this report a better legal framework can be established for health claims.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Human health must be a key priority in the policies of all EU Member States. In this regard, I consider that energy and sugary beverage manufacturers should not advertise on products the benefits of the caffeine contained therein and the presence of other harmful food ingredients.  Statistics show that 68% of adolescents and 18% of children regularly consume energy drinks, with 25% of these adolescents drinking three or more of them in one intake. This shows that not only stricter mechanisms for the distribution of these products to young people are needed, but also specific conclusions of the European Food Safety Authority on acceptable levels of intake and messages of impact on the body. Information on labels, as part of the product marketing strategy, is key to consumer confidence, which in turn relies on a preliminary assessment by the controlling competent units of product quality and legitimacy. It is a fundamental right of the consumer not to be manipulated for the composition of products and its direct effects on the human body– a presumption that is lacking and should be enshrined in the voluntary Code on the marketing and labelling of energy drinks.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this resolution. Of course, it asks to protect children from marketing that tries to make them absorb products containing a lot of caffeine, and wants more generally to protect the health of consumers. But it does not condemn clearly enough the Commission's procrastination in this area.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the objection under section 106: authorized health claims relating to food. This objection relates to health claims that may be presented by caffeine-containing products. These products can be solid foods or beverages.  The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has issued a favourable opinion on the following claims: "Caffeine helps to improve concentration", "Caffeine helps to improve alertness". "Caffeine helps to increase endurance capacity," "Caffeine contributes to increased endurance performance."  These claims pose a real problem for energy drinks as they can lead to dangerous consumption (especially when mixed with alcohol).  However, the French coffee union points out that these allegations were expected by companies (some of them French) to boost coffee consumption among young people and that no French company manufactures energy drinks.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted FOR. This text challenges the statements of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) validated by the Commission. They report that caffeine is good for health, helps with concentration, improves alertness and increases endurance performance. However, they do not specify that caffeine-based products, both liquid and solid, are widely consumed by young people and do not have the same effects on their health. EFSA's opinion does not take into account the differences in metabolism between the ages, nor the problems that caffeine can cause. I support this objection which brings these nuances.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection, because authorizing healthy effects on caffeinated beverages would detract from the negative effects these beverages have on consumers, especially young people (who consume these types of beverages the most). Energy drinks, far from having nutritional benefits, are high in sugar and caffeine and are known to cause headaches, sleep problems and behavioral problems in young people who consume them regularly.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the objection. I do not agree with the call to restrict the sale of energy drinks to young people. Energy drinks are not alcohol and it is up to parents to see how suitable energy drinks are for children.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The Commission has failed to fulfil its obligation under Regulation No 1924/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 December 2006 on nutrition and health claims made on foods. The Regulation ordered it to establish specific nutrient profiles of certain foods and their labelling so that they could be labelled as nutritious or health-beneficial. These are mainly energy drinks that contain excessive amounts of substances (caffeine, sugar) that do not benefit children and young people who often take these drinks. The EP therefore rightly objected to the Commission Regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 432/2012 on the list of authorised health claims made on foods other than those referring to the reduction of disease risk and to children's development and health. The Commission should fulfil its obligation to establish nutrient profiles and to consider restricting the sale of energy drinks to children and young people.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the motion for a resolution on the Commission's draft regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 432/2012 on the establishment of a list of authorised health claims made for food, with the exception of those relating to the reduction of the risk of disease and the development and health of children, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 6/7/2016, and because this report is well documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text.  This text is an objection to health claims that could be written on products, solid or liquid, containing caffeine. For example: "Caffeine helps to increase endurance abilities". On the one hand, however, these products affect and endanger the youngest, on the other hand, the restrictions envisaged do not provide for a control measure for the sale, only for the registration of the claim.  Moreover, the study seems very imprecise and we know nothing about side effects, differences by sex, etc. Some Members of our group had already put forward a motion for a resolution calling for a ban on positive claims and information on the risks of blends containing caffeine and alcohol.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We have today discussed a motion for a resolution highlighting the harmfulness of caffeine and sugar contained in energy drinks, and in particular we are calling for the Commission to come up with a proposal on how to better draw attention to the health risks associated with their consumption, especially for children and adolescents. According to the study, a 250ml can of energy drink can contain up to 27g of sugar and 80mg of caffeine, with it being shown that the largest group of drinkers are adolescents, with around 25% of them drinking three or more cans of these drinks at the same time. Excessive consumption can lead to sleep and behavioral disorders, not to mention headaches. In particular, as a doctor, I supported this proposal in the vote.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The Commission should draw up a nutrition table as early as 2009. This has not yet happened. The report calls on the Commission to take action at long last. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. According to Article 4 of Regulation (EC) 1924/2006, the Commission was to define specific nutritional profiles by 19 January 2009 that foodstuffs must comply with before giving rise to nutritional or health claims. She's finally done it. But the regulation it proposes allows health claims for the virtues of caffeine in energy drinks (redbull). The report opposes this regulation, arguing that these products can contain up to 27 g of sugar and 80 mg of caffeine for a 250 ml can of energy drink. And that they are already widely consumed, especially by young people (68% of teenagers regularly consume this type of drink). And even though "energy drinks have been linked to headaches, insomnia and behavioural problems in children and adolescents who consume them regularly." I'm voting for this report.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This objection applies to products containing caffeine. These products can be solid foods or beverages.  Caffeine-based products do not need claims to be sold and are not really the work of French manufacturers. That is why I voted for this objection.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As an active advocate and member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection of the European Parliament, I cast my vote in favour of this motion in order to ensure that consumers receive accurate information on the products they choose to purchase. Producers must truthfully advertise the health information of their food products in order for consumers in the single market to be well-informed and treated fairly.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – It is a popular wisdom that caffeine makes people more alert and that it tightens concentration, but on this basis deciding that coffee or caffeine has beneficial effects on health is not recommended and not desirable. Granting a health certificate to caffeine would thus be a free pass for energy drink producers, for example, to claim that their products are beneficial to health. A can of energy drink contains up to 27 mg of refined sugars and 80 mg of caffeine and is popular with young people. About 70% of young people regularly drink energy drinks, which allows young people to exceed the daily allowance with equal ease. In a free society, citizens have the right to unhealthy hobbies. However, excess is damaging and, in the context of a preventive health policy, it is advisable to alert adults and young people to the health risks posed by overuse of certain foods.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Commission has not yet set specific nutrient profiles to which foods or certain categories of food must correspond in order to be labelled as nutritious or health-related, and the conditions for the use of such labels in food or food categories with regard to these nutrient profiles. Adolescents represent the largest group of consumers of energy drinks. I believe that the use of nutrition and health claims must not encourage or justify excessive consumption of food. Energy drinks are associated with headaches, sleep problems and behavioural disorders in children and adolescents who consume such drinks regularly. Each product must bear an exact indication of the ingredients it contains. Consumers must not be misled and care must be taken to maintain their confidence in products. I fully agree with the proposal on the table.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission adopted a draft regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 432/2012 establishing a list of authorised health claims concerning food other than those affecting the reduction of disease risk and the development and health of children. In its report, the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety criticises the provisions of the draft on energy drinks and recommends that Parliament ask the Commission to withdraw its draft regulation and consider the possibility of introducing restrictions on the marketing of energy drinks to children and adolescents. I supported the motion.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. We abstain on this objection even though we do not believe that caffeine-based products need to be subjected to health claims to be sold. Indeed, the European Food Safety Authority, EFSA, has issued a favourable opinion for several of them: "caffeine helps to improve concentration", "caffeine helps to improve alertness", "caffeine helps to increase endurance capacity". But EFSA's opinion does not take into account the doses taken into account for the study, differences in male/female metabolism and side effects. In fact, ENF MEPs had previously put forward a motion for a resolution calling for a ban on positive claims and information on the risks of caffeine mixtures with alcohol.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Under Article 10(1) of Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006, health claims on food are prohibited unless they are authorised by the Commission in accordance with this Regulation and included in a list of permitted claims. Under that Regulation, the Commission should have established, by January 2009, the specific nutritional profiles that foods or certain categories of food must comply with in order to be able to bear nutrition or health claims, as well as the conditions for the use of nutrition and health claims with regard to nutritional profiles, in particular as regards the caffeine content contained in energy drinks.  According to the opinion drawn up by the European Food Safety Authority, there is not enough information to determine a safe level of caffeine consumption for children and adolescents. However, these account for about 25% of all consumers who consume two or more cans, to which problems such as headaches and sleep disorders are associated. In this regard, I am voting in favour, because I believe that this proposal for a Regulation should be revised to restrict access for children and adolescents to energy drinks.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The EFSA opinion has several defects: doses taken into account for the study, failure to take into account differences in male/female metabolism, no information on the side effects of heavy caffeine consumption (for example incontinence). I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted to protect consumers from misleading health claims being used on energy drinks.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This objection relates to the Commission's proposal to establish a list of authorised health claims relating to foodstuffs, other than those referring to the reduction of the risk of disease as well as development and child health. In its proposal, the Commission wanted to authorise health claims relating to improved concentration and increased stamina and physical capacity for caffeine-based products. Such a text would have allowed products, such as certain energy drinks, which are sometimes subject to health warnings, to be able to claim health benefits. So I voted for that objection.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting on this motion for a resolution regarding permitted health claims made on foods because I do not agree with the final version of the resolution that was proposed for voting in the plenary.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on the list of permitted health claims on foodstuffs, excluding those aimed at reducing the risk of disease and the development and health of children, since, by validating this motion for a resolution, the Commission is obliged to withdraw its proposal for a regulation as it is not compatible with the purpose and content of Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. 1924/2006. This motion for a resolution is adopted in the context that the Commission has not yet established specific nutritional profiles for certain foods, in particular large-scale energy drinks. I think it is extremely important that this information is displayed and clear, in order to know exactly which of these products are or are not beneficial to the public.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which urges the Commission to place restrictions on the marketing of energy drinks to children and adolescents. The Commission’s draft measure authorises health claims on caffeine relating to an increase in endurance performance, an increase in endurance capacity, increased alertness and improved concentration.  There are concerns however about the adverse effects this could have on consumers, especially on young people. Energy drinks have a high sugar and caffeine content and they are known to cause headaches, sleep problems and behavioural problems in young people who regularly consume them.  Moreover, growth in the energy-drinks market has boomed and children and teenagers are some of the biggest consumers. Warning labels are being ignored whilst the industry’s code of practice, which is merely voluntary anyway, only commits it not to market energy drinks to children under 12. Instead of pushing forward with health claims which help to promote these energy products, the Commission must stop dragging its heels and come forward with the nutrient profiles which have already been agreed upon in legislation, instead of giving energy drinks a leg-up on the market.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour because nutrient tables should pay particular attention to the inclusion of sugar in the nutrition table.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to prevent misleading information about food products aimed at children and adolescents.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose the unelected Commission legislating on this matter. We strongly oppose any introduction of restrictions on the market by the EU. The UK Parliament will be able to decide if and how to legislate on this matter.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the objection is to urge the Commission to withdraw the draft regulation presented and to consider introducing restrictions on the sale of energy drinks to children and adolescents. The Commission provides the conditions and restrictions of use for the use of four different health statements for caffeine, but I am not convinced that this provides sufficient protection. A health statement should be used for substances for which an 'improvement' link to health-related aspects is clear. The inclusion of a health statement, such as "caffeine helps to increase mental lucidity", has an impact on consumption and can push the target market to consume more product. We already know that 68% of adolescents and 18% of children regularly consume energy drinks and as many as 25% of adolescents who use them drink three or more cans in a row.  I am therefore voting in favour of the objection and I hope that it will re-evaluate the use of health statements for caffeine.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the objection to the Commission implementing act on permitted health claims on foodstuffs on the grounds that their use should not be ambiguous or misleading. This, however, would very likely be the result of claims made on energy drinks containing caffeine. It is established that the use of health claims contributes to an increase in the consumption of energy drinks, which is why it can reasonably be expected that the daily intake of sugar and caffeine will exceed the recommended maximum daily intake. This would, in turn, lead to adverse effects of these beverages on human health and, in particular, adolescents, who are the most massive consumers of energy drinks.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the complaint asking the Commission to withdraw the proposal to amend Regulation No 2012. 432/2012. I consider that the draft new Commission Regulation does not comply with the objective and content of Regulation (EC) No 1999/2013. 1924/2006 on nutritional and health claims used in food advertising, namely ensuring a high level of consumer protection and facilitating their choice of products in such a way that food characteristics are properly labelled. A varied and balanced diet is a prerequisite for good health. Caffeine, as an ingredient in beverages and energy drinks has positive and negative properties, and should be taken care of especially when there is a possibility that they can be consumed by children or adolescents. Energy drinks also contain sweeteners in addition to caffeine. Claims that "caffeine contributes to an increase in endurance, alertness and concentration" do not give full information about the product and its potentially negative characteristics. These health claims favor their use, resulting in caffeine and sugar intake above recommended daily doses, which leads to problems with body weight and obesity. The proposed proposal contradicts the requirement of Regulation 1924/2006 to prohibit the use of health claims encouraging excessive food use and that these claims must not be ambiguous or point to wrong conclusions. That is why I believe that the rules of food advertising should be better regulated by law.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This objection relates to health claims that may be made by caffeine-containing products. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has issued a favourable opinion to the following claims: "caffeine helps to improve concentration", "caffeine helps to improve alertness", "caffeine helps to increase endurance capacity", "caffeine contributes to an increase in endurance performance".  The Commission's draft includes restrictions to protect young audiences. In these circumstances, skeptical of the modalities of the application of the restrictions and the information that will be given regarding the dangers of the mixture of alcohol and caffeine, I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 In Article 4. Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013 1924/2006 it was stated that by 19 January 2009 the Commission establishes specific dietary profiles by which foodstuffs or certain categories of food must comply in order to be able to carry nutritional or health claims and the conditions for the use of those nutritional or health claims for food or food categories with regard to nutritional profiles. Unfortunately, the Commission has not yet identified these dietary profiles. Please note that a 250 ml energy drink can contain up to 27 g of sugar and 80 mg of caffeine. 68% of adolescents and 18% of children consume energy drinks regularly. As the energy drinks industry has committed in its optional Code of Practice for advertising and labelling energy drinks only to not advertising energy drinks to children under 12, I consider that the draft Commission regulation does not comply with the objective and content of Regulation (EC) No 12/2013. 1924/2006 and I oppose the acceptance of the Draft Commission Regulation.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in the final vote on this point because I am not convinced that it is possible to make a clear decision as to whether caffeine is a positive or negative substance for the human body. This also implies my position on the present case.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this objection, which will prevent energy drink manufacturers from mentioning positive effects on them, in their view, related to caffeine or sugar in beverages. Specifically, some manufacturers would like to see sugary drinks and energy drinks containing caffeine take advantage of alertness or concentration. On the contrary, my aim is to recall the risks associated with excessive consumption of these types of beverages and to protect the most vulnerable populations, especially young people, from this excessive consumption.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose the unelected Commission legislating on this matter. We strongly oppose any introduction of restrictions on the market by the EU. The UK Parliament will be able to decide if and how to legislate on this matter.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the objection to the European Commission's proposal to allow health claims that caffeine promotes alertness and concentration. I believe that these health claims should not be used for energy drinks. The Commission provides an exception for products targeting children and adolescents, but energy drinks are mainly consumed by adolescents. The Commission's condition of use is ineffective, because how can we ensure that these products are not sold to young people?  Indicating that these beverages promote alertness and concentration may lead to an increase in their consumption and, as a result, a likely excess of the recommended daily dose of sugar and caffeine. These drinks contain a lot of sugar and can lead to headaches, insomnia and behavioural problems in children and adolescents who consume them regularly.  Given that already 25% of teens who consume energy drinks drink three or more cans at once, it seems inappropriate to encourage even greater amounts, which is why I supported the objection.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Commission has submitted a proposal for a regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 432/2012 to add four health claims concerning the effect of a large amount of caffeine on food. The four healthy demands are "Caffeine contributes to increased endurance," "Caffeine contributes to increased capacity," "Caffeine helps increase alertness" and "Caffeine helps improve concentration." Energy drinks are virtually the only foods that have a high enough caffeine level to be able to use these health claims. However, it is children and adolescents who account for the majority of consumers of energy drinks, who also have a high level of sugar per can. Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006 required the establishment of nutritional profiles with which food or certain categories of foods must have nutritional or healthy properties. This would ensure that products that contain a high level of caffeine and a high level of sugar cannot use health claims. However, this requirement is not being met. I have therefore supported the objection for the Commission to withdraw its proposal.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection because it is a public health issue, especially for our teenagers and children. 68% of adolescents and 18% of children regularly consume energy drinks. According to the World Health Organization, the intake of fast carbohydrates should be limited to 10% of daily energy intake. WHO estimates that reducing the intake to less than 5% per day would have additional health benefits.  That is why I am opposed to the adoption of the Commission's draft regulation and ask Member States to consider introducing rules on the marketing of high-caffeine drinks or caffeine-added foodstuffs for children and adolescents.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this objection. Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006 requires that, by 19 January 2009, the The Commission will identify specific nutrient profiles that foods or categories of foods must meet in order to be able to make nutrition or health claims. So far, however, this has not been done. Meanwhile, the current draft Commission regulation is incompatible with the objective and content of Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006, as it does not restrict the sale of energy drinks to children and adolescents. Parliament recalls that 68% of teenagers and 18% of children regularly consume energy drinks, while 25% of teenagers who consume energy drinks drink three or more cans at the same time. And these are large quantities, knowing that a can of 250 ml of energy drink can contain up to 27 g of sugar and 80 mg of caffeine. The consumption of energy drinks therefore poses health threats.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which opposes the proposal to allow health claims relating to increased stamina and concentration capacity for caffeine-based products.  Such claims could apply, for example, to energy drinks; however, this type of drink is the subject of health warnings and it is unthinkable that this product will then be able to benefit from these health claims.  Remember that this type of drink should be consumed in moderation, especially in view of their high sugar content. Such claims would encourage their consumption and endanger the health of consumers, especially young people.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of administrative objection to health claims about caffeine, as it aims to make visible, among other things, that energy drinks generate undesirable habits/patterns of consumption among young people. It specifically identifies adolescents as the main sector of energy drink consumption and the undesiness effects on excessive sugar intake according to WHO recommended values.  In addition to other substances and additives, a recommendation is established for the correct labelling and identification of certain products that may affect proper development at an early age.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection and I supported amendments one and four in favour of nutrient profiles. It is disappointing that the Commission has not fulfilled its obligations under the Health and Nutrition Claims Regulation to ensure that only healthy foods carry health claims. This particular proposal by the Commission would allow health claims on energy drinks despite their high sugar content. Given the evidence that children regularly consume these drinks, and considering the childhood obesity crisis, it is of great concern that such products with high sugar content could be labelled ‘healthy’. In addition to nutrient profiles, we urgently need effective policies to reduce the marketing of unhealthy foods to children as part of a preventative approach to health care.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection, because authorizing healthy effects on caffeinated beverages would detract from the negative effects these beverages have on consumers, especially young people (who consume these types of beverages the most). Energy drinks, far from having nutritional benefits, are high in sugar and caffeine and are known to cause headaches, sleep problems and behavioral problems in young people who consume them regularly.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this because I do not recognise the EU's right to legislate in this area.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this objection as we must protect consumers from misleading health claims being used on energy drinks.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since 2016, uniform rules on the use of health claims on food have been in place in the EU. All claims must be scientifically proven and the results are being investigated by the European Food Safety Authority. Personally, I believe that there is a need to promote instruments for the protection of public health that distinguish the interests that are really needed, because the Member States already regulate and protect weaker categories of people.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this objection against a delegated act on authorised health claims on food. The fewer acts the Commission adopts, the better.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 In a 250 ml energy drink can contain as much as 27 g of sugar and 80 mg of caffeine. The study found that 68% of adolescents and 8% of children consume energy drinks regularly. According to draft Commission Regulation D44599/02, food products targeting children and adolescents must not use claims that caffeine helps increase alertness and improve concentration. Article 3 Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013 1924/2006, states that dietary or health claims do not serve to encourage or condone excessive consumption of food. I support the proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament opposing the adoption of the Commission's draft regulation, as I find the claim that energy drinks increase concentration and help with learning is worrying. It is problematic for a number of reasons: due to the problem of obesity, the effect of caffeine on the body, the formation of taste in children and the mixing of energy drinks with alcohol. Children and young people are victims of advertising campaigns, and our task is to protect them.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution opposes the adoption of the Commission's draft regulation and calls on it to withdraw its draft regulation. We are voting in favour as a whole and we consider that this draft Commission regulation is not compatible with the purpose and content of Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. 1924/2006.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. According to European surveys, 68% of teenagers and 18% of children already drink energy drinks regularly. Drinks often consumed as soft drinks among young people can contain up to 27 grams of sugar and 87 milligrams of caffeine per can. Moreover, according to the warning on the label of the products, their consumption is not recommended for children and pregnant mothers at all. According to the European Commission's draft, these drinks could have been marketed with inscriptions that increase alertness and have a positive effect on concentration capacity. The European Food Authority has found the scientific basis for the claims to be proven. However, by regulating health claims on foodstuffs, the legislator's intention was not to promote products, but to inform consumers properly. In the case of children and minors, we must act with even greater responsibility. With controversial messages, we can not make popular drinks, the consumption of which is also recommended for adults in limited quantities. The health of young people must not be a victim of economic interests. On this basis, I voted in favour of parliament's objection.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report places excessive emphasis on energy drinks while not addressing soft drinks and pleasure items such as cola, cocoa or chocolate. These products also contain a significant amount of caffeine and sugar, so they can be harmful to children's health in larger quantities. According to the Draft Regulation of the European Commission, caffeine helps to increase alertness and concentration, but should not be used in foods intended for children and adolescents. I did not support the elements calling for the definition of the nutrition profile, as I believe that these values cannot be clearly defined at EU level in this form. According to the draft, each food or group of foodstuffs should comply with nutrition profiles in order to be able to be supplied with nutrition or health claims and that the European Commission should draw up the conditions for the application of nutritional or health claims applicable to food or groups of foods in respect of nutrient profiles. This means that food is labelled with a good or bad label, which I consider to be particularly dangerous for local products.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We oppose the adoption of the Commission's draft regulation. We believe that it is not compatible with the objective or with the content of Regulation (EC) No. 1924/2006. This lunchtime, we are in the position of a ban on certain claims used for the sale of sugary and caffeine-based energy drinks. We would like to see these advertisements and all mentions on packaging that target children and teenagers disappear and boast a gain in concentration, performance or vigilance. 68% of adolescents and 18% of children regularly consume these beverages and the consequences of excessive absorption of these products in young people can be dangerous to their health.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection to including a new health claim about the benefits of caffeine to the Commission’s list of health claims about foods that producers are allowed to make, a list which informs consumers about the recommended daily intakes of certain foods. While I do support the Commission’s work on promoting good dietary practice to protect public health, I believe that Member States, rather than the EU, should be able to decide about the marketing of food and non-alcoholic beverages. In addition, recommending the consumption of caffeine in some cases is likely to favour the consumption of energy drinks and consequently encourage the excessive daily intake of sugar and caffeine.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament's resolution on the Commission's draft regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 2012 432/2012 establishing a list of permissible health claims made on food, other than those relating to the reduction of the risk of disease and the development and health of children, calls on the Commission to consider imposing restrictions on energy drinks targeting children and adolescents. However, the Commission has not yet established nutritional profiles by which food or a particular food category must comply in order to be able to carry nutritional or health claims on them and the conditions for the use of those nutritional or health claims for food or food categories.  In its scientific opinion, the European Food Safety Authority also concluded that there is insufficient information available to determine the safe level of caffeine intake for children and that an intake of 3 mg per kilogram of body weight per day is unlikely to be a problem for the safety of children and adolescents. Therefore, I voted alone against this resolution.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the objection under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure, which concerns the motion for a resolution on the list of permitted health claims made on foods, with the exception of claims relating to the reduction of disease risk and to the development and health of children. To date, the Commission has not yet defined specific nutrient profiles with which foods or certain categories of foods must be harmonised in order to bear nutrition and health claims and the conditions for the use of nutrition and health claims for food or food categories in relation to nutrient profiles. As many as 68% of teenagers and 18% of children regularly consume energy drinks. Children and teenagers who regularly consume energy drinks have been found to regularly experience headaches, insomnia and behavioural problems. The Commission should consider introducing a restriction on the marketing of energy drinks to children and teenagers. The mere non-binding advice against the marketing of energy drinks to children under the age of 12 is not a sufficient measure.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of administrative objection to health claims about caffeine, as it aims to make visible, among other things, that energy drinks generate undesirable habits/patterns of consumption among young people. It specifically identifies adolescents as the main sector of energy drink consumption and the undesiness effects on excessive sugar intake according to WHO recommended values.  In addition to other substances and additives, a recommendation is established for the correct labelling and identification of certain products that may affect proper development at an early age.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. In this report, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) considers that caffeine helps with "concentration, vigilance and endurance". However, the rapporteur rightly points out that caffeine-based products affect the youngest and that they are mostly sugary or very sweet drinks. As some of these young people are overweight, these drinks could be dangerous. Thus, the Commission provides restrictions to protect the public. In what form? We do not know and this is problematic. In addition, the report does not take into account metabolic differences between men and women, or the dangers of overconsumption of caffeine (incontinence).  There is no need to make claims about coffee products. However, these claims are to the benefit of the French coffee market, which is also very responsible for the sale of these drinks.  So I choose abstention.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of administrative objection to health claims about caffeine, as it aims to make visible, among other things, that energy drinks generate undesirable habits/patterns of consumption among young people. It specifically identifies adolescents as the main sector of energy drink consumption and the undesiness effects on excessive sugar intake according to WHO recommended values.  In addition to other substances and additives, a recommendation is established for the correct labelling and identification of certain products that may affect proper development at an early age.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The Commission has not yet identified these nutrient profiles.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection pursuant to Rule 106: permitted health claims made on foods. Energy drinks have been linked to headaches, sleep problems and behavioural problems in children and adolescents who consume them regularly. I voted in favour of the objection because I believe that the claims that caffeine helps to increase alertness and that caffeine helps to improve concentration should not be used for foods targeting children and adolescents, who are the largest group of energy-drink consumers.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection, because authorizing healthy effects on caffeinated beverages would detract from the negative effects these beverages have on consumers, especially young people (who consume these types of beverages the most). Energy drinks, far from having nutritional benefits, are high in sugar and caffeine and are known to cause headaches, sleep problems and behavioral problems in young people who consume them regularly.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted with great conviction in favour of this objection. If you know that 68% of teenagers and 18% of children drink energy drinks regularly, that there is insufficient information available to establish a safe level of caffeine consumption for children, and that 25% of teenagers who drink energy drinks drink three or more cans in succession, then you know that urgent work is under way here.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has submitted a draft regulation in which allegations are present that caffeine contributes to increasing surveillance status and improving concentration. It is therefore considered that the Commission's draft regulation is not compatible with the purpose and content of Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006, which states that 'nutrition and health claims should not ... encourage or justify the excessive consumption of a given food'. By January 2009, the Commission should have established the specific nutritional profiles that foods or certain categories of food must respect in order to be able to make nutritional or health claims, as well as the conditions for the use of nutrition and health claims with regard to nutritional profiles. The European Food Safety Authority has concluded that there is not enough information to establish a safe level of caffeine consumption for children. The problems arise mainly in relation to the consumption of energy drinks by adolescents. We voted in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Since the report is also an invitation to the Commission to finally draw up a nutrition table, which should have been drawn up by 2009, and to pay particular attention to the inclusion of sugar in the nutrition table, I will vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported in the vote the resolution by which Parliament vetoed the Commission's proposal that energy drinks should contain health claims on the packaging. As a doctor, I know how high sugar consumption has a negative impact on the health of young people in particular. It is energy drinks that contain a large amount of sugar, and their drinkers are often adolescents, even children. I consider the promotion of the sale of these drinks by claims of their positive effects to be incorrect.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection to the commission's draft regulation on nutrition and health claims on food, because it is against labelling that could mislead consumers. Claims that caffeine contributes to increasing surveillance and improving concentration cannot be used in foods intended for children and adolescents.  It should be recalled that, in its scientific opinion on caffeine safety, the European Food Safety Authority concluded that there is not enough information to establish a safe level of caffeine consumption for children, but that this daily consumption would probably correspond to 3 mg per kilogram of body weight. For example, a 250 ml can of an energy drink can contain up to 27 g of sugar and 80 mg of caffeine. I therefore disagree with the possibility that energy drinks can be labelled as healthy, especially when 18% of children consume them regularly.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The resolution vetoes the Commission's proposal that it would allow the presence of nutrition claims on sugar-containing drinks and energising drinks containing caffeine, with the aim of promoting and emphasising the ability to increase attention or concentration. Such ads could encourage excessive sugar intake by adolescents. It is precisely adolescents who represent the largest group of energy drink consumers. It is estimated that 68% of adolescents and 18% of children regularly consume energy drinks. It's not just about caffeine, energy drinks also contain a lot of sugar. A 250 ml can of energizing soft drink can contain up to 27 grams of sugar and 80 milligrams of caffeine; such soft drinks have been associated with headaches, sleep disorders and behavioral problems in children and adolescents who regularly use them. I voted in favour of this resolution, which states that indications that 'caffeine contributes to increase mental lucidity and helps to improve concentration' should not be used for foods intended for children and adolescents. I do not think that these types of drinks should have any kind of health indication.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on non-tariff barriers to trade for food exporters in the EU's internal market by Czeslaw Adam Siekierski on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (O-000073/2016 - B8-0707/2016) (2016/2681(RSP)).

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski
text: Author. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Dear! In recent years, we have seen an increase in protectionism among the Member States of the European Union. This is partly due to the economic crisis. This problem also affects trade in agri-food products, where non-tariff barriers against specific groups of exporters are increasing.
