We have already signalled the seriousness of this problem with various organisations. We have also taken various actions, including organising seminars and workshops in the European Parliament in June 2015 and February this year. At that time, we based, among other things, on a report by a recognized research company carried out as part of the project "Single Europe – Varied Food" conducted by the Federation of Agricultural Industry Associations, a member of the European organization Copa Cogeca. The report shows the increasing prevalence of non-tariff barriers for food exporters.  The most popular ways of inhibiting exports are: increased frequency of sanitary inspections, press campaigns with negative overtones, the need for many years to keep records related to transactions, additional certificates, short validity of permits, etc. It is estimated that more than 30% of products exported between EU countries face non-tariff import barriers. The losses resulting from the additional measures to be taken by exporters in relation to these barriers are estimated at around 4% of the total value of exports. This is a very worrying phenomenon because it threatens the proper functioning of europe's largest and most important project, the Single Market. The increasing introduction and conflict of non-tariff barriers for food exporters by Member States in the internal market undermines one of the four fundamental freedoms of the Union, namely the free movement of goods. These measures not only discriminate, but also affect competitiveness in the internal market in a way that may have a negative impact on the economy of the Union as a whole. This is all the more important given the serious crisis currently facing the European agri-food sector and, in order to resolve which, inter alia, the smooth functioning of the internal market is necessary. Protectionist measures may also have a negative impact on the functioning of small and medium-sized enterprises in the agri-food sector in the internal market. I would therefore like to ask the European Commission, on behalf of our Parliament's Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, the following inquiry. Firstly, what legal action does the Commission intend to take against Member States that apply discriminatory practices to food exporters in the Union? Secondly, has the Commission analysed the above-mentioned problems and is it considering introducing EU rules prohibiting practices that negatively affect food imports into a Member State within the single EU market?  The idea is to ensure the proper, fair, transparent functioning of the Union's internal market for the sake of food producers, sellers, but also consumers.  Thirdly, in the context of the internal market strategy adopted by the European Commission in October 2015, I would like to ask whether the Commission is considering proposing decisive measures that would limit member states' use of protectionist measures and illegal practices in the internal market.  Will the Commission examine the possibility of introducing Union legislation prohibiting such practices on food imports, in order to ensure the proper, fair and transparent functioning of the Union's internal market and for the sake of food producers, retailers and consumers, and when does it intend to do so?

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Parliament for raising this question. The Commission shares the concerns presented by Mr Siekierski. The single market for food should not be hampered by unjustified or protectionist measures. Such measures can negatively affect the competitiveness of the food supply chain and restrict retailers’ sourcing decisions. Enforcing respect of mutual recognition – meaning that goods lawfully marketed in one Member State enjoy the right to free movement and can be sold in another Member State – ensures the smooth functioning of the single market for goods, including food. Finally, to tackle the issue of national technical regulations used as straightforward barriers, the Commission is committed to boosting the application of the mutual recognition principle, still not used to its full potential. As announced in the Single Market Strategy, the Commission intends to revise the mutual recognition Regulation in 2017. It will also adopt an action plan on mutual recognition. The Commission also stands ready to investigate, under competition rules, any agreements between operators that would lead to discrimination against imports from other Member States. To conclude, let me say that that the efficient monitoring of the application of EU law is an important part of the Commission’s better regulation agenda. The Commission is committed to taking action against the violation of European law. It will continue pursuing the most efficient and effective means to speedily resolve problems and ensure the correct functioning of the single market.

name: Albert Deß
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. 'The single market of the European Union is a single market in which the free movement of goods, services, capital and persons is guaranteed and in which European citizens are free to choose their place of residence and to pursue work, training or entrepreneurship without hindrance.' That is a quote from a description of the European Commission, Commissioner. We are miles away from that! On 1 July, it was 48 years since the European internal market was achieved, and I sometimes have the impression that we are moving away from this internal market. Germany, my own country, is closing itself off with additional national markings for construction products. The unhindered entrepreneurial activity of a master butcher from Kehl – on the German side of the Rhine – who, with his catering service, brings products across the Rhine to Strasbourg for around EUR 500, consists in observing ten pages of regulations with reference to 15 internet addresses. Today, when a family from Strasbourg calls the catering service in Kehl to bring meat and sausages to the football match, he must say: you should have told me that ten days ago, because there is a ten-day registration deadline. Commissioner, that cannot be the case. Farmers who register a cow seven days late but who are hampered by the internal market in Europe must not be penalised.

name: Marc Tarabella
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr. President, this issue is obviously relevant, and it is very good to consider it as well. It must be noted that the non-tariff barriers that have been set up and are still being erected by some Member States continue to violate the principle of free movement of goods. Beyond this problem, which is still important in the internal market with regard to goods, I obviously welcome the Commissioner's words, which are encouraging. I think we need to move in the direction of a better movement of goods. I would like to draw attention to another related issue, because if we are faced with a difficulty in the internal market to move goods better, whether food or not, we also have another problem, which concerns the import and lack of control over imports from third countries. I take an example, that of the lighter used to light the cigarettes of European smokers. 80% of lighters sold in the EU do not comply with EU rules. It would therefore be necessary to have more resources to operate independent controls and to stop trusting the industry, which self-professionally decertifies the compliance of objects it produces. So this is clearly another problem, and if it is to be solved, of course, it is related to the one we are talking about today.

name: Beata Gosiewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Non-tariff barriers for food exporters introduced by some Member States in the internal market of the European Union restrict the free movement of goods guaranteed by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Many obstacles are nothing more than discrimination against food exporters in the European Union and disrupt the proper and transparent functioning of the EU internal market. Commissioner, you have said that you agree with the comments. Why, then, if the problem arose not today, has not taken effective action to prevent these obstacles for exporters? Does the Commission monitor so-called technical, additional regulations or additional obstacles introduced by individual European Union countries, and does it intend to take any concrete effective action to prevent this?

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Dear President, this issue arose on the basis of a single study done for Poland, which concluded that the main non-tariff barriers increased the frequency of sanitary controls, requirements for additional certificates, mandatory specific texts on packaging, obligation to keep documentation in the country of destination, etc. Among the countries listed, which have the strictest non-tariff barriers are the Czech Republic, Germany, Slovakia, Hungary, Spain, the Netherlands, Sweden, France, Finland, Austria and Italy. That's what that study says.  However, this study also speaks to some non-carin barriers that I personally think should be included, for example the obligation to publish information about the origin of the product because this is something we need to know, we need to know where the products come from, what these products are like and what the composition of these products is. However, we have a single market, we have a single agricultural policy, we have a duty-free union and we have to have and create a real duty-free system with all the additional regulations that include all this that this study has stated, and preferably some other elements because I think that this way, how some states function with each other and boycott each other and create administrative and other obstacles, does not make any sense. We need, and in this quite concrete context, a truly single market with all the elements and with all the regulations.

name: Stefan Eck
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. The EU's success story, even though it has now cracked down, is based primarily on the free movement of goods in the European internal market. The creation of barriers to trade inevitably leads to distortions of competition, and protectionist barriers to trade only harm the European idea. The Commission should therefore intervene directly if a country wants to hinder internal trade by means of excessive special rules. However, fair competition also requires agreement and compliance with common standards. It is precisely when importing meat and other foodstuffs that we must ensure that the same quality and animal welfare standards are respected by all Member States, and this should apply not only to products from the EU, but also to goods from third countries. I would like to wish you a relaxing summer break, without the negative effects of climate change, so that we can then start renovating our European house together, because a renovation is long overdue.

name: Jordi Sebastià
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we are talking about barriers for food exporters in the European single market, within what our market should be. And the Valencians know what these barriers are, and the Andalusians and the Aragonese and the Catalans, because we see our trucks stopped crossing the French border and the fruits and vegetables they contained scattered on the ground. I have denounced these attacks on the Commission. I have been told that you will act with a decision, but we do not see the effects. The cases are repeated: intolerable aggressions within our European Union. That way we can't build a real single market. The single market has to take care of it, protect it and make it strong every day. It's not a plant that's abandoned to its fate. Every moment must be worked on, States must be required to monitor it permanently and to react firmly to these barbarities and to these obstacles that my colleagues are denouncing, which prevent it from being a reality.  But, there is much more, because the single market does not protect our producers. They are suffering abuses of the marketing chain, they receive prices of misery for their products and we do not have a European standard prohibiting such practices. A single market requires single rules, requires harmonisation of social and labour conditions, in order to avoid competitions that cause such clashes. Is the Commission going to move in that direction? A single market cannot work with 28 different rules which, soon, dear colleagues, and we have talked a lot about in this session, will be 27 after brexit and can be much less if we do not react. Because this situation also explains Brexit, it also explains anti-Europeanism. Because our producers do not feel covered by the European Union, our farmers wonder what benefits it brings them, why they encounter these absurd barriers when they just want to do their job well. And, unfortunately, dear colleagues, on many occasions I do not find what answer to give you. I, who am deeply Europeanist, do not know what answer to give them. I hope the Commission will give them to me.

name: David Coburn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this is a problem of the EU’s own making. When you harmonise, when you impose uniformity by regulation, you build in opportunities for scamming and mischief making. This could easily be avoided by a much simpler approach: mutual recognition. If a food can be safely and enjoyably eaten in one Member State, this must be true of all. British, German and Romanian people do not have different bodies from one another: physiologically they are the same. If a food is safe to eat and is of merchantable quality in one Member State, then the same is true in all its neighbours. This is the concept which underlay the Cassis de Dijon judgment: fit for sale in one Member State means fit for sale in all. But, for reasons I simply cannot explain, the simple, transparent, practical approach was rejected in favour of harmonisation. Please, Commissioner, just for once, learn from your mistakes and ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, this afternoon, in addition to the huge interest – there are about 20 MEPs present as usual, critics of the European Union obviously see these scenes sometimes, brackets closed – terrible crimes have now been uncovered here. It means that there are nation states that have ideas that their own populations should consume food produced on their own land, produced by their own farmers, rather than ingested food from other countries, remote places, where appropriate. I think that 90 out of 100 Hungarian people perfectly agree that hungarian people are better off supporting Hungarian farmers, eating Hungarian apples, and that is why I encourage everyone to buy foreign food on a local market from a local producer, not in various Tesco and other supermarkets. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Thank you for accepting my blue card. I want to ask you if you agree with me that you are an ordinary demagog here in this Parliament when you talk about the presence of Members of Parliament because I am one of those who sits most in this Parliament, and I know that when this question of mine is over, you will very likely come out of this conference room and go to Hungary or elsewhere. Therefore, I ask you, do you really perform in this conference room in an extremely demagegical, populist way? I think it's completely clear to everyone.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI)
text: Blue card answer. – This is your big problem, that everyone is branded a populist, a demagog, a xenophobe, an extremist, a racist who does not agree 100% with your imperial expansion and your dictatorial ideas. That's why they're where they are, that's what the British have satisfied, that's why they've left, and that's why your structure is going to collapse like a house of cards. Stop insulting other people, look at you a little bit more...  (the President has withdrawn the floor from the Member)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mrs Morvai, I would like to thank Mrs Morvai for her work Unfortunately, we are a bit tight in time, so I can only allow a blue card. Incidentally, Mrs Morvai, that was not the answer to Mr Jakovic's question. He was just referring to whether you're there every Thursday afternoon. I often lead the meetings. If everyone were there as often as you were, there would be fewer than 20.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The clarification was certainly very helpful. (Applause.)  First of all, I would like to thank the initiators of the question, because in the meantime we are indeed very much concerned with the question of the proportionality of Member States' measures in the field of services. Commissioner Bulc, I am sure you will know that the Commission intends to make proposals in the autumn on the proportionality of Member States' measures in the field of services, but we are not doing the same to a sufficient extent for the market for goods, particularly here in the agricultural sector.  We must think about striking a balance here, because as much as we have an interest in the Member States' actions in services being roughly uniform, we have an interest in this – even in an internal market that has been functioning well for over 30 years and in which the Member States find that when they turn the screw on one or the other screw, we have an interest in it– even in an internal market that has been functioning well for over 30 years. , certain products have more difficulties than others – to reach a uniform range. After all, after the vote in the United Kingdom, it will be seen that the British will one day long for this single market back. In this respect, it should also be improved.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to recognise the opportunity for this debate, it is good that we talk about what is happening in the internal market.  Ladies and gentlemen, the internal market is one of the European Union's greatest achievements. We must be aware of the value of this asset, which benefits us so much and is often attacked by decisions of a national nature. I am in love with what my colleague Mr Sebastia has said: Spanish farmers and ranchers regularly suffer attacks by French farmers on a regular and systematic basis. The strawberry of Huelva, the vegetables of Almería, the wine of la Mancha or the pig of Castile and León see these attacks without a response from the French Government or the Commission.  The absence of European legislation against unfair commercial practices also causes each Member State to develop its own standard, creating differences between countries by the same commercial transactions. The absence of European legislation in unfair commercial practices means that there is harmonisation and therefore an attack on the market ...  (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – Dear Commissioner, dear colleagues, it must be acknowledged that Member States want to enjoy the privileges of the free movement of goods when exporting products they produce, but when it comes to granting the same rights to goods from other countries, goodwill often evaporates. Efforts are continuing to create additional rules, requirements that would restrict the entry of products from other countries into the market in that country. So basically we want to play an unequal game. A good example is that a couple of years ago, britain chose a way of labelling food in traffic light colours. At first glance, this system seemed useful, as it informed consumers about the fat, sugar and salt contained in the products. However, synthetic materials were ignored. Thus, products with more fat produced from natural products would be rated worse than the leaner, but produced using synthetic materials. The question therefore arises as to whether the intention was to take care of the health of consumers or whether certain products were intended to be excluded from the market. The system also sought to detract from sales of products from other countries, as consumers often choose an even worse-rated brand, which they know, rather than one that is not known to them. I support various labelling initiatives that help consumers get caught up, but these systems must also take into account the specificities of food packaging in other countries. In my opinion, the European Commission should be more active in this area and ensure that changes to the labelling of a particular country are communicated to all parties in advance and that they can make their own proposals.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the free movement of goods is one of the four fundamental values of the European Union.  The imposition by the authorities of specific market conditions or requirements aimed at protecting domestic products is, however, a common practice. At the same time, we cannot ignore that the Russian embargo has caused a serious disruption of markets even in states that have not had direct relations with Russia, being invaded by products that are sold below the production price and often under the national brand, thus misleading buyers. This is possible as a result of the fact that farmers in those countries have previously benefited from the crisis intervention measures on the part of the European Commission.  Mandatory labelling of products with the country of origin, monitoring by the Commission of trade flows at the same time as removing non-tariff barriers must be able to ensure both the free movement of goods and to provide guarantees to consumers as to the quality and origin of the products purchased.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the increasing frequency with which Member States impose non-tariff barriers on food exporters in the internal market, in addition to breaking the rules, calls into question one of the european Union's four freedoms, namely the free movement of goods. In addition to the discriminatory effect, these actions have an impact on the competitiveness of food imported into the internal market, helping to lead to a decrease in cross-border trade in food products.  The consequences of such actions have a negative impact on the functioning of the internal market and, not infrequently, lead to the very cessation of undertakings. The Commission must seriously consider the introduction of provisions at EU level prohibiting practices affecting food imports, so as to ensure the proper, fair and transparent functioning of the internal market for food producers and retailers.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am pleased that we have today touched on a very important problem that violates the principle of the free movement of goods. It must not be the case that the Single European Market has discriminatory practices between one country and another. We are talking not only about additional certificates, inspections, negative press campaigns on imported food, but also administrative barriers that generate additional costs and losses. In this area, I believe that the European Commission should be more active, react very quickly and stigmatise this type of behaviour. The slowness or lack of decisive action on the part of the European Commission really gives only further arguments to the nationalists and opponents of the European Union.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we will then have to talk about national laws, which are also emerging as poisonous mushrooms in order to try to fragment and impede the free movement of people and goods. In the current debate, I recognise that you, precisely from the College of Commissioners, are acting with greater interest and will precisely to avoid these barriers. But I believe that the mandate that Mr Juncker gave them, precisely to consolidate and improve the internal market as an element of cohesion of the European Union, should help you and all those Commissioners who are willing to avoid all these barriers. In an insidious way and in a way that is not acceptable, through legislation, through actions or through inactions, we are trying to fragment that common market, which I believe must be reinforced precisely at such a difficult time for the European Union. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I would just like to ask you whether you agree with me that if we do not have mutual recognition then this will lead to further problems beyond Brexit? We would end up with Frexit, Czech-out, everybody else leaving. Do you agree that this is damaging to Europe in general, and that mutual recognition would solve that problem?

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Coburn, I do not think you have listened well to the Commissioner... the Commissioner has explained precisely that the rules will be changed.  Ergo, I think it has nothing to do with brexit—I am absolutely against brexit; I think it's going to cause you, you're already causing them, problems. Us, too.  And, of course, any fragmentation of the single market and the common market will only lead to dissegtion and confrontation and weakening of both the United Kingdom and the European Union. So, I don't agree with that.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: – Dear President, duty-free barriers have existed since free trade exists in the European Union, which is why it is very worrying to note from the oral question that the appearance of duty-free barriers actually intensifies. Duty-free barriers are not only illegal, but weakening healthy competition weakens the European economy and in this case a very sensitive branch of that economy, which is European agriculture.  That is why I welcome the initiative of my fellow MEPs, as they have raised a very important issue, and I particularly welcome Commissioner Bulc's announcement that it will investigate procedures for breaches of European laws and will encourage Member States to recognise products with each other, which should ultimately lead to the reduction of duty-free barriers.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I thank you very much for your very clear and very constructive comments. This is a really highly important issue and I hope you understand that it is important for the Commission as well. If together we get the policy right, as we intend to do, by enforcing the respect of mutual recognition, it will help us reinforce our single market for food and that will mean more investment, more jobs and of course more growth. Let me repeat: the Commission will revise the Mutual Recognition Regulation to make it function better. However, I do not believe that food businesses need more EU legislation. The food safety rules are in place and function well. What businesses need are fewer burdensome and protectionist national regulations. Such regulations should be tackled quickly, ideally through bilateral discussions with the Member States that have adopted these regulations and – hear me clearly – if necessary through formal infringement procedures. I count on your continued support to tackle the challenges ahead together.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE)
text: in writing. – Ladies and gentlemen, agricultural crises are leading to a resurgence of nationalism in trade matters and I believe that there is a growing tendency to compartmentalis markets, which in my view is an attack on one of the greatest achievements achieved by the European Union since its inception, which is market unity. I believe that both from the European Parliament and from the rest of the Community institutions should avoid this. Some Member States are considering labelling systems for the national origin of agri-food products which could be clearly discriminatory against imports from other Community countries. Moreover, other national measures, such as the 'traffic lights' system envisaged by the United Kingdom under which products of recognised nutritional value, such as olive oil, would also be considered harmful, could also be a link for trade in agri-food products. I would also like to call on the European Commission not to stand by in the face of attacks by Spanish trucks on the border with France. These are repeated actions which also call into question the proper functioning of the single market.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The widespread introduction by Member States in the internal market of non-tariff barriers to food exporters and the fact that they are at odds with EU law undermine one of the EU's four fundamental freedoms, namely the free movement of goods. The barriers faced by food exporters on a daily basis concern the requirement to have additional certificates not required by Community law, the increased frequency of health checks and the long retention of lorries, the obligation to keep documents related to the transaction for a long time, the obligation to keep those documents in the country of destination, the short period of authorisations and the frequent change in administrative fees. Additional barriers also apply to negative media campaigns on poor food quality. The Commission should examine as soon as possible the possibility of introducing EU rules prohibiting such practices on food imports in order to ensure the proper, fair and transparent functioning of the EU internal market for the sake of food producers and retailers

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the transfer of personal data to China (2016/2762(RSP)).

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, data protection is a fundamental right in the EU and it also applies when personal data is transferred outside the EU. This Parliament played a key role in the data protection reform which will enter into application in 2018 and further strengthen everyone’s right to data protection. China has not enacted any legislation on the protection of personal data. Under the current and future data protection legislation, personal data transfers to countries that do not ensure an adequate level of protection are possible only if the EU data exporter provides adequate safeguards or if the transfer falls within the scope of one of the strictly interpreted regulations. These safeguards include the use of tools such as standard contractual clauses or binding corporate rules, which are of particular relevance for cloud computing. Now, as in the future, responsibility for the supervision and enforcement of data protection legislation lies with the national data protection supervisory authorities and the courts. National data protection authorities are endowed with effective powers of intervention. They have the power of ordering the blocking, erasure or destruction of data and of imposing a temporary or definite ban on processing. While the Commission has not engaged in bilateral discussions with China on the protection of personal data, it is involved in the work of APEC (Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation) – of which China is a member – on this issue. In particular, the EU is engaged in a dialogue with APEC to explain the requirements under EU law for binding corporate rules to function as adequate safeguards enabling the international transfer of personal data. Regarding possible data localisation requirements, one point of concern is the question of public security authorities’ access to personal data transferred from the EU to China. The extent of such access affects the validity of safeguards and therefore the lawfulness of transfers to China. As such, it is within the remit of the supervisory authorities of EU Member States competent in the field of enforcement of the Data Protection Directive. China has adopted or proposed a number of laws and regulations dealing with aspects of cyber-security and national security over the past 18 months. The Commission has welcomed the opportunity to comment on a number of them and welcomes China’s efforts to enhance transparency in the legislative process. The Commission has made it clear to China that global businesses need to be able to transfer, and potentially to store, personal data to different locations for commercial, security and supervisory purposes. China’s security concerns related to cyber-security should be addressed in a proportionate way that does not create unnecessary market access barriers or deviate from World Trade Organisation commitments.

name: Axel Voss
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. As you have already mentioned, with China, we are far from achieving an adequate level of protection of personal data, as we are currently negotiating with the United States. However, the transfer of personal data to China is already a reality, namely via cloud computing or via the shipping platform Alibaba, and unfortunately I do not hear anything at all from our national data protection officers, as well as from some colleagues or permanent activists, as we see again and again in the United States.  I therefore ask the Commission: how can we guarantee that the data protection standards for transfers of personal data to China, which are already taking place at the moment, are respected? What role can be attributed to the data protection authorities and data protection officers – who are actually responsible for these matters at the moment – even better than we have done so far? Because I think very little has happened so far.

name: Andrejs Mamikins
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the EU model of personal data protection laws does not yet exist in China. China has not enacted legislation that specifically addresses the collection, storage, transmission and operation of personal information. China has also not entered into any treaty with the EU or anything similar to the EU—US Safe Harbour Framework. The EU data protection model is not the international standard. China and the EU are different in their underlying approach to personal data processing. In China today the data protection recipient is not an individual or a data subject, as in the European Union, but a consumer. There is no data protection authority or any other state agency to monitor the protection of personal data. Courts are apparently the only viable remedy for the protection of individuals in this regard. Over the past few years, China has enacted a series of data protection-related legal texts. This initiative has to be strengthened and tested. While commercial and other relationships need to be stifled on data protection grounds, concrete and specific policy recommendations need to be provided to China. China would have the opportunity to demonstrate that its recent data protection effort is part of a persistent policy and not just a pretext to attract more internal and external information-processing businesses. A list of policy recommendations has been drawn up with regard to, firstly, the basic data protection principle, secondly, the basic data protection individuals’ rights, thirdly, data transfers, and, finally, the enforcement mechanism. The relationship between China and the EU in the field of personal data protection will have to overcome many difficulties but, if both sides genuinely want overcome them, they can succeed.

name: Beatrix von Storch
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the EFDD Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. At the end of the plenary debate, therefore, we are now discussing the standards for the transfer of personal data to China. We, the Alternative for Germany, demand in our policy programme on data protection: "Against other efforts, data protection must be given a high priority and its scope must be extended to all personal characteristics. Freedom of expression and the free development of personality need strong data protection." In its judgment of 6 October 2015 in Maximilian Schrems, the ECJ set out in detail the standards for the protection of personal data. Legal certainty in the transfer of personal data and the protection of such data are crucial for citizens' confidence. If the citizens lose confidence, then we see what they are doing: they are leaving the European Union. Let us therefore insist that, as with the United States, the highest and highest standards must apply to the protection of personal data in China!

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it is a pity that this very interesting and important topic is only now on the agenda, when this hall is almost empty, and the focus on the hall is relatively small even among journalists.  The Republic of China has long been one of the European Union's largest and most important trading partners. However, our rapidly evolving economic, political and cultural cooperation also entails increased data transfer. These include the personal data of citizens of the European Union, which, in my opinion, can also be very dangerous. This country does not have any provisions in its legislation dealing with the collection, storage, processing of personal data. This great deficiency poses a major threat to the European Union and to the European citizens themselves. It is therefore necessary, Commissioner, to ensure that transfers of personal data between us and China comply with the European Union's privacy and data protection requirements.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Commissioner referred to the Data Protection Regulation, which will be coming into effect in two years. Like my colleagues, Mr Voss and Mr Albrecht, I was involved in that, as the rapporteur for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) for a four-year period, and it gives adequate protection for European citizens. Then, of course, we had the situation with the US, with the Safe Harbour being shut down, and that has now been replaced by the Privacy Shield. While all the focus was on the US, we were perhaps negligent in our dealings with China. It has been pointed out that their data protection is certainly inadequate in terms of the protection of European citizens. At the same time, there are increasing flows of data to China – with the increasing use of Chinese products, software, e-commerce, social networks, etcetera – so it is absolutely vital that we engage with the Chinese and maybe try to get some type of extension to the Privacy Shield so that adequate protection is there for European citizens’ data.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, China has no legislation that specifically provides for the collection, storage and transmission and processing of personal information and has not entered into any agreement with the European Union. The european model is a reference point but not yet a globally applicable standard. However, despite the Eu ropean Union limiting transfers of personal data to countries that do not comply with its strict legal privacy adequacy requirements, the exchange of personal data between the European Union and China has become an important reality in contemporary cloud computing environments. China has in fact adopted an aggressive trade policy, setting up international offshore cloud computing zones and extending free trade areas to foreign investors. We must ensure in a short time, that data transfers belonging to European citizens to China are in line with the requirements of our regulations.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, the European Union seeks to deepen trade and investment in order to create a level playing field. Despite many calls to protect personal data rights and improve the security situation, I am still sceptical about the issue. We are witnessing the weaknesses of the rules and regulations being introduced. We need to work to improve the situation in data protection legislation and make sure that the transactions made are executed correctly and are not influenced by the control and interests of third parties. As technology advances and digitisation nowadays, it is even easier than it was 20 years ago to misuse personal data.  It would be irresponsible to allow free transfers of personal data without taking the necessary security measures. We need to make sure that European standards are not sacrificed at the expense of reaching a deal.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, our business with China is getting wider, more frequent, stronger, more complex. Of course we do business with a country that does not have a proper data retention system, and certainly does not have a data protection system. And that's where we come up with a serious problem. We will encounter a problem not only with China, but with many other countries with which we do business, because the data protection of our citizens is always of a very dubious nature.  That's why I'd like to suggest that one day we don't discuss data going across the Atlantic and another time about data going to China. Let's try to do something else. Let's try to create the world's first cybersecurity concepts with the United States and other partners. Because, just as we need physical security, so today we need cybersecurity. I really don't see any reason why the EU and its partners shouldn't start this business right away.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for the very useful contribution to the debate. It is clear that, in today’s digital world, cross-border data flows are indispensable for our economy, businesses and societies. We must pay particular attention to the transfer of personal data. Citizens’ rights, as provided for by the Charter of Fundamental Rights and secondary law, must be fully respected. In this regard, it is important to emphasise that transfers of personal data can take place only if adequate safeguards are used by the data exporter. Such safeguards can be provided, notably, by means of contractual clauses binding the exporter and the importer of the data. These include obligations as regards security measures; obligations to adopt technical and organisational measures to protect personal data against accidental or unlawful destruction or accidental loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure or access; information provision to the data subjects in the event of transfer of sensitive data; notification to the data exporter of access requests by a third country’s law enforcement authority, or of any accidental or unauthorised access; and the rights of data subjects to access certification and erasure of their personal data; as well as rules on compensation for the data subject in the event of damage arising from a breach. The model clauses also require that EU data subjects have the possibility to invoke the rights they derive from contractual clauses as a third party beneficiary before a data protection authority (DPA) and/or a court of the Member State in which the data exported is established. With regard to transfer between different entities of a multinational corporate group, controllers can rely on binding corporate rules (BCRs). These rules are enforceable in the EU: individuals whose data are being processed by an entity in the group shall be entitled as third party beneficiaries to enforce compliance with these rules by lodging a complaint before a data protection authority and bringing an action before a Member State’s court. Under most Member States’ laws transposing the directive, data transfers on the basis of BCRs have to be authorised by the DPA in each Member State from which the company in question intends to transfer data. The Commission will continue to engage in dialogue with China and other international partners in Asia and North and South America to promote the solid principles that underpin our approach to data flows and to the protection of personal data.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. – This is good example to prove that neglecting important European values and principles will ultimately result in harming actual EU interests: providing EU citizens’ and businesses’ data to China, a key partner without any credible data protection laws, but with the largest number of super-computers in the world (even more than in the US) offers the Chinese a clear commercial advantage they will not hesitate to take advantage of. So, for me the issue is not just about principles: it is also about protecting European jobs. I hope the Commission has the right answer, with a viable and reassuring solution to a very practical dilemma.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on the application of the Minimum Wage Act in the transport sector (2016/2815 (RSP)).

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am happy to be here today to discuss the very important and really timely issue of the application of national legislation on the minimum wage in the road transport sector.  As you will know, two Member States recently decided to apply their minimum wage laws to drivers from other Member States active in road transport operations: Germany in 2015 and France from last Friday, 1 July 2016. We need to join our forces and coordinate our efforts to move towards a single European transport area in which road transport services are not only safe and efficient, but at the same time socially responsible. Only then can road transport contribute adequately to a fairer and deeper internal market – one of the key priorities set by President Juncker for this Commission – a market which is shaped by people for people, which respects workers’ rights and contributes to the developing society and economy within the EU.  As regards especially the introduction of minimum wages, the Commission welcomes such national measures. This is clearly in line with the social policy commitments of the Commission. However, such national measures must be fully compatible with EU law, notably the Treaty principles on free movement of goods and the freedom to provide services. This implies, for example, that any restriction of such freedom must be necessary and proportionate in view of the objectives pursued.  Let me be very clear. The Commission fully supports the principle of the minimum wage. However, we consider that the systemic application of the minimum wage by France and Germany to all international transport operations touching their respective territories restricts in a disproportionate manner the freedom to provide services and the free movement of goods. Because of the highly mobile nature of workers in road transport, a driver often works for very short periods of time in several Member States in the course of international transport operations. The application of national measures regarding minimum rates of pay to even a very short—lived presence would create an unjustified and disproportionate administrative burden on road transport operations, without applicable benefits for their workers.  The Commission has already taken the initiative to have in—depth discussions with the French and German authorities on this issue. Unfortunately, we failed to find an amicable solution in that context. The Commission also undertook a thorough legal assessment of their national measures. On this basis, the Commission decided on 16 June to open an infringement procedure with respect to France and to proceed further with the current infringement case with Germany. The German and French cases also demonstrate that the implementation of the Posting of Workers Directive to road transport is raising particular legal questions and particular difficulties. It is also clear that all Member States potentially face these same questions and difficulties. This is why they call for an EU solution. This is necessary to prevent the emergence of uncoordinated national measures, fragmenting the internal market. The Commission already recognised this fact on 8 March 2016 when it adopted its proposal to amend the Posting of Workers Directive. In that proposal, the Commission announced its intention to clarify the application of the directive to road transport in the context of the sector—specific legislation. We are currently working on finding the most appropriate solution at EU level to address these challenges. This is done as part of our review of the road transport legislation. This review should lead to presenting a series of road initiatives in 2017. We intend to take advantage of these legal proposals to propose rules to clarify the application of the Posting of Workers Directive to road transport. Our objective will be to design effective enforcement mechanisms which combine the objectives of the internal market, fair competition and the protection of workers’ rights.

name: Janusz Lewandowski
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The European Union is filled with confessions of love for the common market and competition, but with the second of these declarations of this market and competition there are fewer, not more, as illustrated by the recent agricultural debate. Our question to the Commission draws attention to new forms which, in the intention, may not be provocative, but certainly so. These include the minimum wage in Germany, most recently the rules in France, but not the minimum wage itself, of course, but a reference to transport and transit. I assure you that for the East transit through Germany is a transit with no choice. Drivers must drive through Germany; they are going in anticipation of decent wages, and companies are waiting for decent profits. This is fair competition, beneficial to the recipients of these services. Thank you for your clarification, but it is difficult to find the progress of the work with Berlin and with the other countries that are doing so satisfactory.

name: Jutta Steinruck
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Is it not the Commission's job to be as committed to fair working conditions and the protection of workers as it is to free competition? And it is precisely in the European transport sector that it must be a matter of protecting the existence of both lorry drivers and properly operating companies. It must finally be over that business models are favoured in Europe that are purely aimed at exploitation and purely at undercutting competition. There is so much abuse in the transit sector that there has been no other solution. We have a European labour market in reality, but as long as the Commission does not come up with European rules or wait – the problems have been known for a long time – the Member States must have the right to regulate this themselves. That is precisely what France and Germany are doing, in order to prevent this abuse, which you are all aware of here in the room. Social insecurity and also the day-to-day undercutting competition are fuelling precisely this anti-Europe. Instead of digging trenches here, you should close them. (The speaker refused to answer a question from Mr Jakovic under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are talking today about the minimum wage in the context of international transport, although, contrary to appearances, it is not the level of the wage itself. The hourly rates themselves, imposed in violation of the Treaty by France and Germany, among other Polish entrepreneurs, are only the tip of the iceberg. The rest of this mountain, which could sink the sector in Poland and other Eastern European countries, is frequent checks, the need for costly translation of documents, disproportionate financial penalties amounting to hundreds of thousands of euros, or the obligation to maintain representation abroad. Meeting these requirements is a huge financial effort often exceeding the capacity of entrepreneurs. While the Commission has taken appropriate legal action, the scope of these measures is too narrow. Reducing the problem to transit only is far from enough. What about these rules for cross-border transport and cabotage? Will the Commission address this thread? The question of the future also remains open: what does the Commissioner plan to do to ensure that similar rules do not take effect in other countries? The state of legal uncertainty that we are facing today is the biggest problem. In the current climate, we need the effectiveness and determination of the Commission to carry out its basic tasks like never before.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, our colleague mentioned that the laws in question hit especially hard the competitiveness of numerous small and medium—sized companies. Do you not think – and this is, let us say, my appeal to the Commission – that it should have to inform us on its position concerning the application of minimum wage laws in the transport sector, from the point of view of the need to protect the single market and the freedom to provide...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Frunzulica, I would like to thank Mr Frunzulica for his work on this Unfortunately, this was not a question for the honourable Member, but a request to the Commission. This is an abuse of the blue card. That is why I do not allow an answer.

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: on the alde group. – Mr President, Commissioner, European car transporters have been victims for many months of changing the course of some European Union states, which are starting to build bureaucratic barriers at the border. The so-called fight against social wage dumping is a pretext, but enforced compliance with local regulations is, in particular, a bureaucratic burden for foreign carriers and a controlled liquidation of their competitiveness on the European transport market. The regulatory measures taken by Germany and, more recently, France are in direct conflict with the declared creation of a common trade area in the European Union. The freedom to provide services is one of the fundamental freedoms of all Member States, which must be guaranteed. How are we to understand that the Commission, on the one hand, is preaching the need for a freer market and, on the other hand, has been toothlessly examining our protests against germany's protectionist practices and its minimum wage law for a year? A year of research without visible and heard results!  No wonder France safely took the same path as Germany this month, introducing Loi Macron. Precedent triggers a chain reaction, it's exactly as we feared. Europe, already exposed to the biggest identity and cohesion crisis in decades, continues to fall apart.  What's next? And who, if not the Commission, will stop this protectionism in Europe?  Who will finally have an open dialogue with protesting transport companies operating for months in legal uncertainty? Commissioner, is this really the new Europe we are fighting for? (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – For years, we have seen the introduction of national protectionist provisions restricting access to the single market or providing for disproportionately high penalties or administrative burdens just to get rid of foreign competition. Do you not think that this protectionism, the violation of the Treaties, is leading to chaos in the European Union and increasing dissatisfaction of the European public with membership of the Union?

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I think that, unfortunately, yes, the discontent is here, we are proclaiming, on the one hand, that we want to have fundamental freedoms, we want to have a free market, we are trying to do so from all sides, and on the other hand we are introducing protectionist measures that really do not help us build citizens' trust.  We need to start communicating openly and start making a policy that is based on specific data, on specific statistics and the numbers we need. So let's talk more with the companies and listen to them. And I am thinking of us, all my colleagues and the Commission.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I fully understand the contradiction we are facing here. On the one hand, the interests of many transport companies that operate throughout Europe, across the EU, want ingesbiting their services, having to cross many Member States, but also the legitimate protection of people who often suffer from commercial fraud, because different standards are quite simply undermined between the Member States, people are recruited in their own country through companies, but then often get contracts from their country of origin, but at the same time, for three weeks to nine months – as studies show – are staying in the country for which they do not even get the contract. In the end, I say clearly that when it comes to To achieve both – on the one hand, the possibilities for the free movement of services and the transport of goods, but also to protect the fundamental rights of employees – then we have more to answer than just the question of whether an infringement procedure can be used to respond to the fact that the Commission has for years ceased to be subject to any control over the implementation of EU transport and road transport directives in the Member States, or has not been influenced by the fact that such fraudulent applications can be used by different member States. You said earlier that you are preparing EU-wide measures. I would have been pleased if you had explained them here. For what has happened in France and Germany is self-protection – self-protection that has been established precisely because the EU-wide safeguards, which are quite possible, have been absent over the last few years. One thing we should discuss together is one question: is it right that the four fundamental freedoms have a higher value than the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union? (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mrs Zimmer, you have made it very clear that this move by Germany and France can be called protectionism. Do you think this is a move to strengthen or break up the EU?

name: Gabriele Zimmer (GUE/NGL)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Here we are again at exactly the point that I actually mentioned. What is protectionism? Is the protection of workers' rights protectionism, or is it the application of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the application of social standards? The problem is rather that we do not have comparable social standards in all Member States. Let us fight for this together. That would be the approach and not this conflict, as I have now heard in part from the discussion. If we stand up for it, then we all have something of it.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The European single market is one of the greatest achievements of European integration. Therefore, some Member States are very concerned about measures to restrict the freedom to provide transport services within the European Union. Decisions by the Governments of Germany and France requiring carriers from other European Union countries to apply the minimum wage in transit and international transport are contrary to the principle of freedom to provide services, infringe competition rules, increase the operating costs of European companies and result in the loss of many jobs. Even more harmful are the additional administrative requirements imposed on carriers from other countries, such as the need to keep extensive documentation in the language of the country of destination or the obligation to open a representative office. These actions are contrary to European law and clearly to common sense. I therefore ask the Commission to take more vigorous action to protect the functioning of the single market in the area of transport services. I also ask the governments of the Member States to refrain from these protectionist practices, which undermine the efficiency of European economies and harm us all. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Mr. Mate, you said at the end of your speech that this is how competition is being destroyed, that such practices harm us all. I would like to ask for clarification: to all of us, that is? I don't think we pay any attention here at all, or we are paying too little attention to the needs of european Union consumers. Would you agree that the consumer in the European Union, the one who uses this transport, needs a market where there is competition in order to be able to choose the best and cheapest service?

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Increase the operating costs of European companies and therefore increase the cost of living and the cost of living in the European Union. All this affects consumers, but consumers are the silent majority. Here in this House, we should also defend the interests of consumers, not just wonder whether an adequate level of wages is a right to which everyone in the European Union should aspire. I would also like to say that nowhere is it written that fundamental human rights mean equalisation of wages, because wages depend on labour productivity.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in recent months and at the most serious time of the consequences of the economic and social crisis, we have seen a new silent border war appear on the basis of falsely social legislation which entails new obstacles to the free movement of people, services and goods.  And for the record, that the minimum wage is always welcome and that we rejoice when it was finally introduced to Germany, because the immediate effect of its introduction is to raise the overall wage level — which is already time — to mobilize the scandalous German surplus and to wipe out the minijobs that are doing so much damage in the rest of the states.  The surprise is that this was not the case and that it has been used to build barriers in the field of the road transport sector. And Germany has now been added to France, two central states that have distinguished the the most in the past for trying to benefit their carriers against the rest of the Europeans: the German toll or the threat of jail for overnight stay in the truck for other carriers in France. They already have measures that penalize peripheral carriers: restrictions on the movement of heavy vehicles (weekend bans), the Euroviñeta, etc.  Commissioner, we do not like sanctions and we would prefer that there be a clear European legal framework that would prevent this unstoppable fragmentation of the market by benefiting...

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. Germany and France want a common Europe, a single market, but when it comes to their own interests, these intentions are quickly forgotten and market foreclosure occurs. It is not even primarily a question of the minimum wage, it is about the administrative barriers that these countries have made. In May last year, you sent Germany a letter of formal notice, and after that you did nothing, nothing at all, for more than a year. In June of this year, 13 months later, you sent a letter of formal notice again, which was not necessary at all, because there were no new circumstances, you should have sent a reasoned opinion. This is how you help with this market foreclosure by simply not being active enough. It took you another two months to reply to a letter from several Members. A letter that basically says nothing. Two months, and during this time France closed themselves ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Matthijs van Miltenburg (ALDE).
text: – It is good that the European Commission has launched infringement proceedings against Germany and France. Of course, combating exploitation is important, including in road transport. But it cannot be the case that countries are heading in a protectionist direction under the guise of social aspects and social protection. It cannot be the case that Member States apply the minimum wage to international transport and create all kinds of administrative obstacles to keep foreign hauliers out. We cannot accept that a proliferation of national regulations is hindering the free movement of goods and services in Europe. We see it in France: foreign carriers have to fill out extra forms, appoint a French representative who is available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week to the French enforcement authorities. This really leads to disproportionate red tape and additional costs. Why does France create an intermediate layer by working with representatives? Surely reports of pay can also be made directly to a public service? And how do these representatives deal with privacy-sensitive information? A lot of hassle out there my opinion [the President interrupts the speaker]. The most important thing was yet to come. There's a lot of uncertainty. Foreign hauliers, meanwhile, are risking hefty fines. I therefore call on France to suspend enforcement while the European infringement procedure is ongoing, and I urge the European Commission to do so again. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: Question "blue card." Mr President, you are going back, Mr (van Miltenburg), to the decisions that have been taken by France, in particular to combat fraudulent actions. You think that is excessive. What other measures could you propose to avoid these fraudulent practices?

name: Matthijs van Miltenburg (ALDE)
text: "blue card" answer. "Yes, I think, indeed, that it is excessive. I'll answer you in French. I think that setting up a representative on French territory is excessive, especially with the current means by which one can communicate directly, for example by email, with a company located elsewhere in Europe. I think it is the administrative procedures that block the free movement of goods, at the level of suppliers and service providers. I therefore look forward to the European Commission proposing measures at European level.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, do you know what it means to sleep in a cabin at 50 degrees? Work to pay for the truck, without breaks or return home, in debt slavery typical of feudalism? Putting your health, your life and that of your family, even that of others, at risk because the European Union does not want to apply the legislation against social dumping?  If they knew, if they cared, they would not act with impunity against workers' rights.  Denying the minimum wage to international carriers is the last of their shameful decisions, in contrafiment of the principle by which all workers, without exception, are entitled to minimum and dignified remuneration.  European legislation on social rights is emptying into a hollow shell because of the Commission's arbitrariness.  From here my support for carriers, associations and trade unions in their denunciation of this brutal situation.  I hope that the Commission will reconsider, listen to mobilisations and campaigns, such as Fair Transport Europe and in this Parliament, be legislate so that workers' social rights are protected and controlled.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, for me, two battles are to be fought head-on for more justice and social equity in transport. On the one hand, we must push our national leaders to strictly enforce the existing rules. The European directives on secondment are clear: the minimum wage must be applied to all categories for transport, whether international or for coasting, in order to ensure fair competition between carriers. But we must not stop there. There is an urgent need to work towards a European solution for our carriers, which is adapted to the highly mobile nature of their profession and that can offer them more harmonised social conditions. At a time of Brexit and a worrying rise in populism, this is an indispensable condition for the survival of the European project. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". My specific question is this: France has put up many administrative barriers – let us put aside the minimum wage : French representatives, all documents in French, etc. Imagine that my country, Slovakia, would do so! And the French entrepreneur would have to have everything in Slovak and in the Czech Republic everything in Czech and in Slovenia everything in Slovenian etc. If all the countries did what France did, international transport or European transport would be ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, I am not in favour of red tape. However, for us to have a common market that works, we need clear rules and, above all, we need compliance with the regulations in place. This necessarily requires good information, and good information must be done in the language that can be known. I think it is very important that these regulations are respected, which is why we have ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the difference between wages in eastern Europe and western Europe for the same work is still very large. Western Europeans want to protect their jobs and to keep to their level of salary, but eastern Europeans want to receive a larger salary for their work. In the single European market, conditions such as this inevitably result in the problems we are discussing today.  In my opinion, the main problem to which we have to find a solution is where the boundaries lie between protection against social dumping and unjustified protection of a domestic labour market. I think that restrictive measures are not permitted if their true purpose is not to allow on their labour market people who in their own state receive a lower salary.  In 2015, France adopted a law concerning the application of the French minimum wage to the transport sector, and a minimum wage act came into force in Germany on 1 January 2015. In this case, I support the decision of the European Commission to take legal action against France and Germany about minimum wage legislation in the road transport sector.

name: Bolesław G. Piecha (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Today's debate touches on one of the most appalling and controversial issues in recent times, namely the introduction of protectionist practices within the European Union's common market. The inclusion of foreign transport companies in national minimum wage rules by Germany – not to mention other bureaucratic barriers – and later France is a unilateral and incompatible action both in accordance with Article 56 of the Treaty and with the Posting of Workers Directive. The infringement procedure initiated by the Commission by Germany takes far too long, its scope is too narrow and focuses only on transit services. I am convinced that the Commission can and should do more to protect the integrity of the single market. The Commissioner's response is highly inadequate. The minimum wage is a much-needed tool, but it cannot be used as a means of eliminating competition and circumventing treaty freedoms.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I welcome the open debate on the minimum wage, as well as your words on the unjustified administrative obstacles that the legislation has laid down here in both Germany and France. Dozens of car transporters are waiting for your response and your quick action, who have contacted us with their concerns.  I think it is in the interests of all citizens to protect the competitiveness of our companies, our employers. National measures that protect their market in a way that is contrary to the single internal market are simply not acceptable and, as has already been said here, we cannot confuse the fight against social dumping with the creation of administrative barriers in the internal market that are contrary to the existing rules and which are protectionist. Let us protect the competitiveness of our companies on the European market vis-à-vis third countries, against external social dumping from Asia, which most threatens our competitiveness.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the problem of social dumping affecting the road transport sector in the Union is not going to be solved by State-State measures, as you have already said. It needs an immediate and European solution. That is why we welcome the open of infringement proceedings against the German and French rules on the minimum wage of carriers who, however unilateral, because of the bureaucratic costs and complications incur, are going to make the situation of companies worse. We believe that the infringement procedure is incompatible with the decision taken by the French authorities to begin to monitor compliance with their rule, even if sanctions are not to be applied in this first stage. That is why we are asking quickly in the development of specific European legislation on the mobility of transport workers and the suspension of controls in France until it is clarified whether this rule is in line with Union legislation.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tar éis éisteacht leis an díospóireacht seo tá mé níos trína chéile ná mar a bhí mé nuair a tháinig mé isteach, mar is léir go bhfuil fadhb mhór ann maidir leis an ábhar seo ach nach bhfuil réiteach na faidhbe ró-shoiléir. Ag an am gcéanna, caithfidh mé a rá gur ceart don Choimisiún a bheith solúbtha agus gur chóir dóibh na prionsabail, go háirithe mar a bhaineann le cearta sibhialta agus cearta daonna, a chur i bhfeidhm ach ligean do na Ballstáit a rialacha féin a leagan síos mar tá an tionscal iompair seo an-difriúil ó thír go tír.  Maidir le mo thír féin, tá mé i dteagmháil le húdaráis sa tionscal go minic agus tá fadhbanna móra acu maidir le rialacha na hEorpa mar is oileán í Éire, agus chun dul go dtí an mhór-roinn caithfidh siad ar dtús dul ar an bhfarraige agus caithfear na rudaí sin a chur san áireamh nuair a bhímid ag leagan síos rialacha.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, at a time when the application of minimum wage legislation in the transport sector is being discussed, it should be noted that the application of minimum wages levelled by Member States with stronger economies, such as France and Germany, will necessarily entail economically disadvantageous and even unfair conditions for those other less robust economies or even under financial intervention. I would like to remind you that, according to Eurostat 2014, GDP per capita in Germany was EUR 35 200, in France 32 400, while in my country, Portugal, it was EUR 16 600. This means that attempting to require the application of national minimum wage regulations to all cross-border transport activities will necessarily result in increased losses for transport undertakings, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises which will see their competitiveness particularly impaired, and will prevent the proper functioning of the internal market. I believe that the provisions of German and French law will make it difficult to enjoy the freedoms of the internal market, since, in addition to what I have already mentioned, it will also entail a disproportionate bureaucratic and administrative burden for transport operators. Commissioner, for all this I would like to commend your work and your commitment to the resolution ... (The President withdraws his word to the speaker)

name: Julia Pitera (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Have there been any studies on the impact of the introduction of minimum wage rates? Do these analyses take into account how this will affect the fate of thousands of transport companies? What will happen to those companies that, taking care of the quality of services provided and the working conditions of drivers, have taken out loans to buy modern cars nota bene in other countries of the European Union, such as Germany, France, the Scandinavian countries or Italy? How will these companies cope with the repayment of these financial obligations when they are further burdened with a significant increase in administrative costs? How does the introduction of minimum wage rates, taking into account the potential effects on the labour market in Poland, affect the European Union's policy of reducing unemployment and policies to support small and medium-sized enterprises in the Member States? I do not know convincing answers to these questions. Who would take responsibility if my concerns were confirmed?

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This debate lasts until 5 p.m. Now it's 4.40pm and I think there are still a few people here... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Der Präsident. –
