text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mrs Ouacijewska, I would like to thank Mrs Ouacijewska for her work We have certain rules, we have speaking times. We have a buffer, and we have a certain catch-the-eye number. I have a large number of catch-the-eye messages. And just because you are not taken into account, we cannot change the rules now.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members very much for all their comments.  I have listened very carefully and we have noted every single comment. I can assure you that we will take these comments into account when we proceed with our work.  I would also like to thank you for showing some understanding about the complexity of the issue that we have on the table and of course the sensitive nature of the topic. This is what we need to take into account as well. I would like to stress once more that the establishment of national minimum pay rates is considered by the Commission as a very positive development. We fully understand the objective of the social protection of workers pursued by the German and French authorities. But of course the national measures should not be misused. This is our core message. While protecting workers effectively, they need to respect EU law so as to preserve the proper functioning of the internal market with all the benefits it brings across the EU.  Let me stress that the Commission sent a letter of formal notice to Germany in May 2015 challenging the systematic application of the German minimum wage to all international transport operations and transit. Since then, the Commission has been engaged in a dialogue with the German authorities to reach a satisfactory solution without the need for further procedures. This is by far the best possible approach. I was really hoping we would find a solution during the process, but we have exhausted this possibility and we are now moving on with legal proceedings.  The administrative burdens related to the notification and controlling requirements imposed on foreign operators constitute one of the aspects that have been analysed in the letter of formal notice. In the pursuit of constant improvement, we will seek to find appropriate measures to create efficient, safe and socially responsible road transport services where people are at the heart of EU transport policy. This is the ambitious and challenging goal ahead and we must all do our utmost to contribute to its achievement. This will be the line that the Commission will follow when preparing the 2017 road initiatives. One of its aims will be to enhance the proper enforcement of the existing EU social rules, as well.  Please let us not forget our core objective – the core objective of the EU – which is a single market, the basic foundation on which the European Union is built. I would really like to make sure that, while ensuring the necessary social protection of workers, I also preserve the integrity of, and even further deepen, the single market.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, when you ask for a point of order, the Presidency is compelled to respect the regulations. I know you're in a great hurry to go see today's Euro game, but rest assured that next Sunday my team will send yours home.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr! You shouldn't suggest to me that I'm doing this because of the football game. I will have two groups of visitors here tomorrow and I will be watching the game here in Kehl. I'm in no hurry at all. With regard to the catch-the-eye procedure, I would like to say once again that I am constantly trying to cut back according to reasonably comprehensible criteria. We have a framework and anyone who has not spoken in a debate should refer to Rule 116(12) of the Rules of Procedure. Anyone who has not spoken can submit a 200-word written declaration. But at some point our interpreters have to stop. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Single Market is an area without internal borders, where people, goods, services and capital move freely under the principle of mutual recognition. Unfortunately, in some Western European Member States, laws on the minimum wage in the transport sector are introduced, citing the concept of social dumping, with reference to those in Eastern Europe, who are falsely accused of unfair competition. These rules shall also apply to persons operating only temporarily in their territories. Thus, in Germany, a minimum wage of EUR 8.5 per hour is imposed on foreign freight carriers and persons, and France is preparing to do the same. Such legislation strongly affects the proper functioning of the internal market and the competitiveness of SMEs. Furthermore, the financial possibilities of transport companies in the Eastern States to pay their employees at a certain required level cannot be compared with those of the Western States, a different approach being likely to lead to the end of some transport operators. I believe that measures must be taken at the level of the EU transport market to achieve fair competition by combating fraudulent practices and eliminating illegal labour, the real problems identified. The regulation of a minimum wage would only lead to the division and restriction of access to that market.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. – Minimum wage is currently in 22 of the 28 Member States of the European Union. Yet it was the introduction of German hourly wages that upset the moods of the undertakings concerned in almost all Member States. The procedure is still ongoing, but a conclusion from the European Commission is expected by the end of this year. I welcome the fact that the Commission took immediate action to examine german legislation in the context of the infringement procedure and continue to negotiate with the German State, but there is still uncertainty surrounding a number of issues: questions to which, under Community rules, the German State's minimum wage law is in breach of Community law in its current form, and questions which create a legal conflict without a solution between the national law of two States. , when used at the same time. Thus, a situation has now arisen in which the employer may comply with one national law and the worker cannot comply with the other national law. National law does not override each other, legislation at the same level, so conflict-free enforcement is only possible if there is no overlap between the scopes of the legislation. In the case of the German minimum wage, this cannot be said, since the Hungarian carriers concerned by the application of the minimum wage rule are essentially subject to Hungarian law. I hope that the Commission will take its decision on this critical issue as soon as possible, and that our carriers cannot be kept in limb matter.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. "For once, I support action by my government. It has decided to apply the legislation on seconded work to foreign road hauliers who are coasting in France. For those who simply pass through France on their way, these provisions are not applied, nor for those who make international transport to or from France.  The Commission tells us about excessive, administratively disproportionate measures, interference with free movement and the free provision of services... But what are we talking about? Where do you see a travel or traffic ban? For once, there is an attempt to combat social dumping and unfair competition in practice. Using your own texts! The 96 Directive and the 2014 implementing text! Respecting these freedoms, which you are rebuffing! I demand for my country the freedom to fight against all the abuses that your absurd and ideological texts on sacrosanct competition engender.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I consider germany to apply a minimum rate for transport operations within Germany as harmful and dangerous to the single market, which is why I am pleased that the European Commission is examining the compatibility of these rules with European law. It must be borne in mind that such a solution creates additional and, above all, unnecessary administrative burdens for foreign companies operating on the German market, negatively affects the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises and, moreover, runs counter to the fundamental principles of freedom of movement of goods and the provision of services. In this House, we have repeatedly said that we need more Europe and more solidarity, especially in these difficult times. I therefore believe that a quick and positive solution to this problem can be just an example of how we work together and jointly and severally in Europe, and I therefore encourage the European Commission to clarify these doubts as soon as possible.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Commissioner, we have been observing for several years the introduction of national protectionist provisions restricting access to the single market or providing for disproportionately high penalties or administrative burdens only in order to get rid of foreign competition. The European Commission should stand firmly on the side of the provisions of the Treaties and the fundamental freedoms of the European Union. If this does not happen, it will undermine the general meaning of the creation of uniform EU law. Today, none of us disputes the right of any Member State to introduce a minimum wage in our country. The problem, however, is the scope of this pay for persons employed in other Member States and its compatibility with the freedom to provide services in the internal market. As a member of the Employment Committee, I ask to what extent the Posting of Workers Directive applies to workers in the transport sector. What modes of transport are covered and which transport industries? These questions need to be answered so that carriers and workers in the transport sector can continue their work. Since 1 January 2015, laws have taken effect in Germany and since 1 July this year in France, which clearly show protectionist character. The European Commission has therefore rightly launched an infringement procedure against Germany. However, a year has passed and we have not yet received any concrete answers. How long will this chaos last? On behalf of carriers and transport workers, I ask for a specific answer.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Commissioner, we cannot accept attempts by some Member States to introduce rules that provide for disproportionately high penalties and administrative burdens on companies operating in accordance with the law and fair competition. The competitive advantage of lower labour costs resulting from differences in economic development, wage or social security, better productivity or organisational efficiency cannot be penaled and equated with social 'dumping'. We all agree that abuses in the transport sector must be combated, so we should fight against 'box companies' that employ eastern European drivers on wicked terms. However, Commissioner, let us not accept the actions of Germany and France, which undermine European rules and introduce rules that are incompatible with European Union law, giving arguments to opponents of the EU.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. – Two EU countries have so far imposed a requirement to pay a minimum hourly rate to their standard vis-à-vis foreign carriers. In practice, this means that transit bus and truck drivers will be paid €8.50 an hour by their employers in Germany, even though their companies are based in another country.  For Bulgarian carriers, this is nothing but protectionist measures that will lead to a large administrative and organizational burden, will cause a dramatic increase in their costs and ultimately exclusion from these markets.  I am pleased that, with common efforts, the European Parliament has managed to draw the Commission's attention to finding an answer to this delicate and complex issue between social dumping, protectionist measures and workers' rights. Here's how parliamentary scrutiny of the European Commission leads to concrete results! The Commission is now on the move, which must continue the infringement procedure against France and Germany and do everything possible to prevent fragmentation of the internal market in the EU.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – The infringement procedure against Germany with regard to the minimum wage law (MiLoG act) lasted more than one year. This leads to legal uncertainty and a lack of clarity in European economic activities in the short term. The Commission must find a solution to stop this situation and strike a balance between the social protection of workers and the freedom to provide services throughout the EU, so as to ensure the functioning of the internal market. As regards the transport sector, I believe that the situation of carriers transiting Germany must be dealt with separately from the revision of the directive on the posting of workers in the context of the provision of services. A separate approach to the transport sector would more quickly unblock the situation, as the application of that directive also to the international transport sector poses countless legal problems.  I call on the Commission to urgently come up with a solution for the transport sector in the context of the revision of the next road transport legislative package, in order to prevent immediate distortion in the internal market and to stop the extension of this wage practice in other Member States.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – After Germany decided to introduce the minimum wage and apply it across the board to the transport sector, France also decided to do so. In both cases, decisions are accompanied by an excessive administrative burden on foreign carriers. Member States are thus responding to the Long-Term Inaction of the European Commission by these measures. Although it has opened proceedings with France and is continuing its proceedings with Germany, it has not yet laid down clear rules for the operation of transport operations in the European Union, which would include a balanced functioning of the internal market and ensuring the social conditions of drivers. Unless clear rules are set by the Commission, Member States will continue to implement their measures at national level. In the end, we can also find a situation where we have 28 different national adjustments in the internal market. I therefore call on the Commission to publish as soon as possible a so-called road package to clarify this situation.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – We have just debated non-tariff barriers for food exporters in the internal market, which undermine the principles of the European single market and, in particular, the free movement of goods. Unfortunately, the measures taken by some countries in the area of the minimum wage in the transport sector are another worrying example of the weakening of the internal market, which is, after all, the biggest project and achievement of the European Union to date. In this case, the freedom to provide services is at stake. It is not so much the raising of the minimum wage for drivers carrying out their work on the territory of a country that raises concerns, but also the fact that they also affect transport in transit and international transport. In addition, a number of additional administrative requirements are introduced, such as the obligation to keep records in the language of the country concerned, which clearly hit foreign carriers. The common European market is a huge value that cannot be sacrificed in the name of protectionism. At a time when the euro area and the Schengen area are in crisis and the Union is shaking in fear for its integrity and future after the Brexit decision, the plunge of the last haven, which is a well-functioning internal market, can be depreful to us. I call on the Commission to enforce decisively the laws and principles of the single market.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – A functioning single market needs a dynamic, efficient and socially rights-based transport sector. This means a level playing field between companies and decent pay for employees. However, this balance is currently being called into question by unilateral regulations recently introduced by certain Member States. I therefore condemn the protectionist measures of countries such as France and Germany to introduce minimum wages for carriers operating in their territory. Such measures are anti-European, lead to fragmentation of the single market and discourage the participation of firms in Eastern Europe. We need a set of common rules at Union level, as well as a mechanism to monitor their implementation. With regard to the remuneration of those who work in the field, I reiterate my support for the idea of having a minimum wage, but it must also be clear that differences in economic development at the level of the states do not allow companies in the east to pay their employees to western European standards at the moment.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The minutes of this sitting shall be submitted to Parliament for approval at the beginning of the next sitting, in accordance with Rule 192(2) of the Rules of Procedure. With Parliament's agreement, the texts adopted will already be sent to the addressees. If you wish to raise a point of order again, Mrs Jazaowiecka would like to say so!

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I will admit that today I am very appalled by your behaviour. That is true – you have always worked very solidly. You have always given a very solid voice and have been very fair. But today's Lord's behavior I completely do not understand. This is an important debate. I am amazed that such a subject is enshrined in the last point of our meeting, and you are further shortening this debate by 18 minutes. This is completely inexplicable and completely incomprehensible. I am very sorry for this.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Madam President, thank you very well The agenda is the responsibility of the Conference of Presidents. The fact that we ended up a little earlier in the timetable was due to the fact that in the previous debate there were no speakers in the catch-the-eye procedure at all and I now simply had to cut back, otherwise there would have been an imbalance with regard to nationalities. And Mr Caputo will now complain that an imbalance has now arisen with regard to the S&D Group. However, after Mr Caputo's speech, we are closing in.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I simply wanted to understand the criterion: you gave the floor to eight members of the ALDE and the PPE. There was only one S&D request, mine, and he didn't give me the floor. Moreover, he justified himself by saying that he did not give the floor to those who had previously had it. I did not have it, unlike Mr Kelly. This is therefore totally discriminatory and unjustifiable.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Caputo, thank you very much. I would like to say to you explicitly that, at the beginning, no one from the S&D Group spoke at all. Then you came. I did not allow Mr Dzhambazki to speak at the beginning because he had already spoken. As far as I was here at noon – the services are recording this very precisely – I have not taken into account those who have spoken before. Nor have I allowed eight speakers from the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats to speak, but only three. Three from the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, two from the ALDE Group, although I have had a total of over ten speeches. I am trying to do this reasonably correctly – believe me – although colleagues from my own group sometimes do not make it any easier for me.
